Great theme, visuals, components, and concepts, and this is a game with a ton of opportunities for quality expansions.  Definitely a must-have, especially considering it plays 3-7 players.

Own the [boardgame=35704]Merlin's Company[/boardgame] expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[I]tl;dr: It's hard to beat Shadows in the co-op realm. It provides more gameplay and decisions than simpler co-ops, without being too difficult to beat. The traitor mechanic makes every game fresh and keeps you doubting your friends.[/I]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

[b]Read the full review [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/article/24527544]here[/url].[/b]

Shadows over Camelot is the best co-op game out there, with the possible exception of Escape: Curse of the Temple. You all play the role of knights of Arthur's round table, tasked with protecting Camelot from the forces of evil. Only catch? One of you may be a traitor!

Using cards, quests, teamwork, and planning, you must get white swords on the round table and defeat evil (which is trying to put black swords on the table). Each turn you will progress evil by drawing a black card, adding a siege engine, or losing a life point. Then, you will be able to take a heroic action to try to complete a quest. 

Shadows is a very popular game that has never been a miss when we've brought it out. Though there are a lot of rules to go over, it's been a hit even with non-gamers (a few have gotten overwhelmed). Because it's a coop, there's a lot of ways to help different players -- the presence of a hidden traitor makes everything even more fun! 

This is a great alternative to Dead of Winter and thematically is right up my alley. Though the theme isn't super rich, the board game graphics are immersive and everything makes sense within the theme. Some of the quest items you will recover are Excalibur, the Holy Grail, and Lancelot's Armor, and the knights each have special abilities to help them win quests. 

A few wrinkles to what is otherwise a 10-rated game for me: first of all, with new players the game can go long. Though it accommodates 7, be prepared for that to take a couple hours -- I prefer things with four or five. Secondly, if one player decides not to cooperate, it can ruin the game for everyone (has happened to me, which soured me on the game for a while) -- but then, that's inherent to all co-op games.

Overall, Shadows over Camelot is one of my favorite co-ops, and a game that we have gotten our money's worth from.

RATING: 6
Rating based on one play. I was the traitor, and it's a boring role to play in this game.  The other characters get to fulfill quests and do some trading, which is more exciting. There's no incentive to even pretend you're good. You're essentially best off actively playing against the other players from the very beginning, and then continuing as a traitor when you've gotten far enough. It's still a fun game and I enjoyed myself, but I can't imagine choosing to play this game over my other co-ops (Dead of Winter, Pandemic, etc.).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Definitely one of the most enjoyable co-ops. Most of the bad qualities of a typical cooperative boardgame are absent here. By this I mean that all players have their own will and most importantly can act on it. There is no one mastermind pulling holding all the strings in hand just basically everyone what they should do. This is achieved through with one simple rule. You are not allowed to explicitly discuss the contents of your hand cards. I also enjoyed how tension quickly began to build up on multiple fronts creating a feeling of desperation. This also leaves room for the Traitor to do some subtle moves. The DoW version of the game has a very good production value, too.
 
What I didn’t like however, was that moving your figure on the board counted as an action. Sure, it balances the game, but that makes it more of a design issue. Spending your turn just to move is very unsatisfying. To fix this, the game balance would need to be shifted. I am also a bit unsure about the player elimination. It is not only bad choices that can lead to your peril but bad luck plays a role also. Hence, I think player elimination is a bit too brutal. A major punishment would be a better choice if only everyone can keep playing.

RATING: 9
I absolutely love playing this game. I enjoy cooperative games in general – but here it is the wonderful theme that gets me. I love the Arthurian myths. I have never lost a game of this - either playing as a knight or as a traitor. Granted, the traitor once revealed is extremely powerful (mwa-ha-ha) but was so much fun to play. They totally suspected it was me, and rightly so, but by revealing me I became so much more powerful. 

Even when we play without the traitor mechanic the game is great (and we mostly play without the traitor... which could be my fault, I make a very good – or is it bad – traitor.) My favorite knight in game is Sir Palamedes – because I'm the type of person to sacrifice a life for the team - he fits perfectly with my style of play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First play through and it was very enjoyable.  The theme was great and the production quality was very good!  The traitor mechanic is definitely exciting.  Despite all the fun I had playing it, there were a couple of frustrating aspects:

1) It felt difficult to get white cards for me.  Seems like I was always struggling to get white cards.
2) #1 was exacerbated by the fact that in order to get more I had to travel back to Camelot and in doing so face a potentially disastrous "Travel Card" (Merlin's expansion).

I think these frustrations were aided by the fact that:

1) I had picked to do the Grail quest solo - meaning that I wasn't getting cards from completing quests because the grail quest is a long one.
2) The traitor was actively working against me completing the grail quest - unbeknownst to me until the end.

Definitely looking to add this to my collection.

RATING: 8
I really enjoyed Shadows and want to play more (but cult of the new keeps getting in the way!). I love the use of poker hand style mechanisms. The only pity is that it can be hard for saboteurs to do so secretly (we tend to have to tell the table what options are there for new players) and it can feel restrictive (with movement taking a whole turn). Other games are more elegant but this earns its place as a good quality semi co-op.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I haven't played this enough to have a proper reaction, but my first play through was rough. I played Battlestar Galactica first, years ago, and had high hopes for this co-op game, expecting the theme to be more broadly relatable, the mechanics easier to pick up and the play time of sixty minutes to be more palatable to my new gaming group. And generally, that was true. You're essentially hopping around a giant board trying to create or place poker hands-- three of a kind and a pair, two pairs, a straight, etc.-- with the game's cards. However, every player's turn is also a turn for the evil, and the luck of the draw can be occasionally devastating, but more often than not it's just a frustrating game of tug-of-war where evil always has a leg up because the knights just do things too dang slow. 

If you want to move to a quest, that's your one action. Meanwhile, evil gets to set one of your quests back by a card. You want to contribute to the poker hand? You can only play ONE card, and that's one action. Evil may then immediately counteract you or play another card elsewhere. Where this ends up going feels like an inevitable snowball in evil's favor, and that's before you even mix in a traitor. Until I learn the tricks to it, or general strategies, the game is just too slow and tilted toward evil winning to be appealing or exciting. Sure, if we squeaked out a win in these poor odds, we'd feel really excited, but I don't see that happening often. That's a shame. 

We're going to try our next round with house-ruling every player taking TWO actions per turn, or at least not counting moving to a location as an action. That may snowball towards the good side, but as it stands, the game feels unbalanced already. Not recommended at this time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Overall good game - especially with the right group that gets in the spirit of things.  Traitor is a huge plus, although I could see playing without it if you were playing with kids.  Only downside is the possible endgame where you want to lose a quest to get more black swords.  If you still have more white swords, however, you win.  This can be easily fixed by variants suggested on this website.  Components are beautiful and game is just plain fun - definitely not a brain burner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
In Shadows over Camelot, players becomes subjects of King Arthur who tries to win enough quests to win the game.  Each character has their special abilities and players have to collaborate to win the game.

In the game, there are many quests which the heroes are able to take part in.  Some quests are continuous quests which after the completion of the quest will restart the quest all over again.  Some quests are 1 time quests which the quest will usually be awarded with some artifacts which will help players in the game.

Though most players are your friends in the game, 1 of the players may be the traitor in the game who is out to sabotage other players.  Players can call accused each other as the traitor but penalty would be given if accusations were made to the wrong person.  Win enough quests to win the whole game which the traitor will really try hard to prevent it.

Good points: An interesting game which players collaborate to win the game together.  There are many quests in the game, which players are able to select the most appropriate quest (depending on the hands of the player) to complete.  Flipping over the dark cards (one of the bad actions) can be exciting towards the later part of the game when players prayed hard not to encounter certain cards.

Bad points: It is really hard to win this game.  After playing for quite a lot of times, we can only win the game once.  My friends and I kept playing the game while we lost, but after we won the game once, we are so tired that we never played the game anymore.

Shadows over Camelot is a game similar to Pandemic which players collaborate to acheive the winning objective of the game with a slight difference.  It is similar because players have to do a bad action then followed by a good action.  The bad action will prevent players from winning, but the good action will help players win the game.  The difference being that there may be a traitor amongst all the heroes.  It adds uncertainty to the game and follows more or less the storyline of King Arthur which makes the game more interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Co-op game with a traitor. Great theme. Not too complex and good for gamers of all experience levels. Great components as well. Triggers Monty Python quotes...lots of them.

RATING: 6
Sólo cambio

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The end game is very weird in this game.  Three of the four games I have played, the good guys win by fighting off seige engines while waiting for the dragon to burn down Camelot to get us to 12 total swords.  The other game, we won by actually killing the dragon in a huge mob.

The game where we killed the dragon highlighted another serious problem with the game, which is that it is hard for the traitor to do anything negative without obviously being the traitor.  It turned out the idea to kill the dragon came from the traitor, which leads to the funny mental image of the traitor suggesting all his friends go kill the dragon and then being shocked when they come back alive.  However, it seems that the only thing the traitor can do which doesn't immediately expose themselves as the traitor is to make bad suggestions.  At all other times there is an optimal decision and any deviation immediately exposes the traitor.

RATING: 7
A good game all around. The cooperations in this co-op game is brilliant as well as incorporating the traitor element into that cooperation. Each turn you "advance evil" before taking your turn. And there really isn't any action you can take there that isn't going to make you look the traitor. And probably the most brilliant and devious aspect is that there might not even be  traitor. 
Sadly we rarely get a chance to play with more than just the 2 of us or maybe 1 or 2 more. So it's a game that won't see much play time so it's hitting the trade list. But if you get together regularly with 4+ people don't miss this classic in the genre.

Nachdem ich so viele gute Reviews gelesen und angeschaut habe (besonders das von Tom Vasel) habe ich mir das Spiel gekauft. Die deutsche Version ist Anfang 2013 so gut wie vergriffen, von daher habe ich die Gelegenheit genutzt als es als Neu angeboten wurde.
Das Spielmaterial sieht sehr gut aus. Die Spielpläne, Karten und Figuren laden wirklich zum Spielen ein.
Das Spiel ist ein Koop-Spiel für mindestens 3 Spieler (mit der Verrätervariante sollten es wohl besser ein paar Spieler mehr sein).
Ich werde das Spiel wohl hauptsächlich solitair spielen.

RATING: 6
The theme and artwork take this game a long way, and the mechanic of poker-style hands to match up with quests is really clever and makes the game very accessible, but I don't like the pacing (too often a player sits in the same place and drops a card for multiple turns at a stretch), the downtime, or the weirdness where the players have an incentive to run out the clock by intentionally failing quests if they've got an ironclad white-sword majority.

RATING: 5
If you have never played a cooperative game, this one makes for a good introduction, especially so for those wanting to play with family that includes children and/or non-gamers. Many will find this a fine family game. However, once you branch out to more sophisticated co-op games (Battlestar Galactica being my favorite), you will find this game exposed and lacking.

RATING: 7
Very good cooperative game that plays up to seven players and creates a lot of tension because of the potential traitor among the group.

The tension and suspicion is encouraged by some clever design. Playing sets of numbered cards isn't all that thematic or interesting. However, the fact that in some cases you can choose to play a card face down to draw a new white card creates tons of suspicion.

RATING: 7
This is a really solid game. Don't let everything going on intimidate you, it's actually really simple and allows for a pretty flexible strategic plan. The potential traitor is what really adds to it though by adding a hint of paranoia to the whole experience.

Based on only one session it seems to have the inverse excitement curve to Betrayal at the House on the Hill where it starts off really intense as everyone is struggling to complete the major quests but once those are done it's kind of just grinding out the repeatable quests until they're complete. The traitor also doesn't have too many ways to actually betray the group. The only thing the traitor can really do is play sub-par.

RATING: 8
A solid cooperative game with very good bits and presentation.  The introduction and possibility of a traitor makes this unlike other cooperative games.  Easy to draw players into the game.  For first time players, it may be best not to use the traitor, but it should be required in subsequent playings.  Card draws will impact the outcome and players will have to adjust to the situation.  Keep game play moving or the game will drag and take longer than desired.  [GTI Code: TGCL]

RATING: 9

The production values are great, components good, and it's not hard to teach anyone of age, even if a few of the mechanics do seem a little scattershot.

RATING: 8
Very fun and thematic team game, with a traitor - or not.

The possibility of a traitor is especially fun when you have border-line unscrupulous team-mates, who, despite being on the good guys team, will not trust other team members to get the 'treasures', and so will act super-shifty, despite being on the 'good guys' team.

I've had games where the traitor was playing just a bit sub-optimally, and the rest of the team fell into anarchy without his help.

Overall, with the right group of people, a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the first games with the traitor aspect.
Up to 7 players and 1 may be the traitor.
This is a cooperative game where players play against the game, however one of them may be a hidden traitor sabotaging the parties plan.
You go on quests; excalibur, holy grail, whenever you win a quest you gain benefits, namely white swords that enable you to win the game, or black swords if you lose the quests.
The components are very good, and the game is very interesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A touch stone game that I traded away and regretted to the extent that I have required it again. Yes, there are newer and, argueably, better coop/semi-coop games out there today, but SOC was something of a progenitor to several very good games that have borrowed from its mechanics. 

The reasons I have taken it back into my collection: it looks great, plays quite quickly and can always be relied upon to draw non-gamers into a slightly more involved game with the near universal outcome that they are keen to play more games. It also has that Days of Wonder knack of being a visual and tactile treat to bring to the table.

I own a handful of games I can think of (Zombicide, Bootleggers, A Touch of Evil, Pandemic and Flashpoint) that have the capacity to inspire interest among both gamers and non-gamers alike, and offer an experience that is equally satisfying to both groups. That is high praise indeed.

RATING: 2
When I first purchased this game (it was my first plunge into hobby gaming, after many, many years of M:tG), I thought that it was brilliant, simple, intuitive, streamlined, and engaging.  I was in love with the game before I ever even played it due to the traitor aspect.  This game started out as a 9 for me, but the more I played, the more bored with it I became.  Our actions became predictable and repetitive, and it seems as if this game really does play itself.  My coop game of choice is Arkham Horror, and now I have Pandemic to pull out when I need a gateway co-op game.

If you still enjoy this game, then you probably haven't been in a 7 player match where you are on grail duty.  That is not a game.  The replayability on this fades quickly.  If you must play it, don't use more than 4 or 5 players, for the love of all that which is good in gaming!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A beautiful game by Days of Wonder with impressive components. Game play is fun as you try to beat several quests before the quests beat you. The addition of the traitor makes it much more interesting. I'm beginning to really like this game mechanic of hidden agendas. Bang! is another game that has it but here it is more subtle.... A wholly enjoyable experience for the whole family!

RATING: 7
Licht coöperatief...
Ieder is een ridder, en mogelijks is er een verrader in het spel.
Probeer witte zwaarden te veroveren aan de ronde tafel, oa door questes te winnen.
Elke beurt gebeurt er iets slechts (zwarte kaarten), en kan je iets goede proberen doen.
Gralen verzamelen levert veel op.
Origineel, beetje samen, maar toch apart.

Fijn spel, maar niet om aan te schaffen.
Wel om opnieuw te spelen en verder te ontdekken.

RATING: 8.5

***UPDATE***
This game improves exponentially when playing with the possibility of a traitor.  The rampant paranoia and player-watching that occurs is fantastic.  Feels almost like a more structured version of Werewolf.

RATING: 6.5
(15+2)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Deutscher Spiele Preis 7th Place 2005[/SIZE][/COLOR]

[i]Posted: 7/11/06, Rated: 8[/i]

At first glance, [i]Shadows Over Camelot[/i] presents an impressively daunting façade.  King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table sally forth to triumph over the forces of darkness.  With such lavish production values and so many [i]parts[/i], it was a bit difficult to sell this game as being easy to learn.  Our perseverance was ultimately rewarded.

[i]Shadows[/i] is essentially a set collecting game, one where players work together to build sets one card at a time.  Sometimes these sets are like [i][gameid=1115][/i] hands: build two pairs, or a full house.  These familiar analogies made it easier for me to explain the game to new players.

If that was all there was to the game, then it would be average at best.  Of course, there is more to it.  [i]Shadows[/i] was the first cooperative game I had ever played, where players were trying to beat "the game."  When that goal started to lose its steam after a few plays, we introduced the "traitor" role: each player draws a "Loyalty card" and keeps it in secret.  There are more of these cards than players, and one of them says "Traitor."  One player [i]might[/i] be a traitor trying to thwart the success of the other Knights, but there is no guarantee that the role is actually in the game!  This simple wrinkle adds a healthy dose of paranoia, and can induce some incredible mood swings -- usually from elation to utter despair.

The richly-colored game boards, and the molded pieces help to foster a sense of wonder and adventure.  I can definitely see the allure of painting the game pieces, like the ones seen here:

[ImageID=93329]
I decided to pick up a copy of [i][gameid=20229][/i], and the painted figures do enhance the game experience.  It becomes easier for players to associate with their characters.  Role-playing can be cheesy, but it also adds to the game.

Combine a novel idea for most players (a cooperative game) with superlative production values and a fantastic theme, and [i]Shadows of Camelot[/i] is a grail of a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good cooperation game, with the traitor twist. Can end up in a ridiculous way if all knights play safe and defeat siege engines when white swords are safe.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A cooperative game - Arthur's knights try to protect Camelot, but there's always the possibility of a traitor in their midst.  A great cooperative game, and the traitor is a fine twist.  Best of all, you can play it in an hour and a half, and it's tense all the way.

Over time, the game soured a bit with my group, as they felt they had established a dominant strategy. I think there's still a lot of fun to be had in managing risk and clever card play.

Battlestar Galactica has done the traitor mechanic better at this point; I need to test some house rules to smooth out the traitor. There's just too much variance in, say, a 5-player game, between having a traitor (nearly impossible) and not.

RATING: 4
Blech, I just don't understand this "game."  In the realm of co-op games, this is at the bottom of the barrel.  Its predecessor by several years, Lord of the Rings, did the co-op thing much, much better.

At the risk of sounding like a Knizia fanboi, he is just leagues ahead of other designers.  I'm not guaranteed to always like his games, but I can be sure the game is tightly designed and balanced out of the box.

Shadows doesn't seem like a finished game, save for its presentation.

RATING: 7
One of the most painful near misses for me. Fantastic theme, fantastic artwork, co-op with traitor mechanics sounds awesome. But the actually mechanics are a bit thin and don't always feel thematic. Often times it just feels like collecting and playing sets of cards. And there's isn't much room mechanically for satisfying subterfuge if  you're the traitor. Not that's it's a complete bust but this is one of the only times where I wish someone would copy this theme and put a meatier game into it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Beware, this is NOT a board game, its a card game with a box full of beautiful but unnecessary componants. 

Lots of downtime once a player embarks on a quest as you have nothing to do but lay an ordered set of cards. The randomness of the card draw seems to void the potential for any applied skill. 

There is a danger that once a successful routine is found then that would will set the mould for future games. Experienced players will become frustrated if new comers didn't toe the line for ideal combined play. New comers  may become irritated at being 'advised' what to do.

If this was packaged in its simplest form as a card game with some rule tweaks I might score this a 6. As time passes my resolve to never play this again strengthens along with my beief that the game misfires on all cylinders.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the great grand-dad of two very popular genres.  First it helped usher in the popularity of co-ops (along with Knizia's LotR).  Second and more importantly the game brought the hidden traitor/semi cooperative game into the lime light.  People are quick to dismiss this as a themeless Euro where all you're doing is playing poker hands.  The simplistic ruleset is KEY for players to quickly internalize so they can get to meaty traitor aspect.  Sure the game might have been outclassed later by games like Dead of Winter and Battlestar Galactica...but it is by no means irrelevant.  It's very simple to teach and works well with almost every player count.  This game is a bonafide, modern day classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Many people on this site really enjoyed this game the first few times but quickly lost interest.  With me it was the opposite -- a lukewarm game or two, followed by a steady increase in my opinion of it.  I really enjoy it now.

The traitor makes the game, but I find he has too hard a time to negatively affect the game much without it being blatantly obvious.  This is especially true if you play with no extra loyalty cards -- if you know there's a traitor, it is very easy to spot him unless he's laying low, but in that case he can do almost nothing to hinder the loyal players.

I recommend playing without a guaranteed traitor -- say, one more loyalty card than players. There should [i]always[/i] be the possibility of no traitor, so you can't be so certain of your suspicions.

I do like that, after a game, you really feel like you accomplished something, that a story had been told.  The game will always be talked about at length afterwards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This was surprisingly fun.  Almost wish I didn't trade off my copy.  Our first game we were so scattered on what to do that we just got crushed.  No real leader and I think this game you somewhat need one.  It was tense as the evil built up and overtook the knights.  Much better than Pandamic, but a lesser game than LotR.  I think. 

I would definately play this again, but only with six or more people.  But, I wouldn't want to play this on a regular basis, to keep it fresh.

RATING: 6.5
New similar games are better

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
First cooperative game I played. A fun game with no optimal strategies as far as I can tell, which helps to eliminate the 'alpha-player' problem that some people have with games like Pandemic.
It can be frustrating to be able to do so little on your turn, but at the same time this means that it will be your turn again that much sooner. Plus, everyone is always interested and involved in what everyone else is doing.
Overall a very fun game that works well as a family/gateway game and as a serious gamers game. Just make sure to always shuffle in a traitor.

RATING: 5
You would think after seeing Lord of the Rings that Days of Wonder would have an easy time making at least a moderately enjoyable cooperative game.  It was not to be.  This game is just boring.  Tons of downtime, little cooperation and mostly trivial and unengaging decision does not a good game make.  To elevate this game I think the black cards should have options that, while all painful, requires a choice from the player.  I find this suggestion unique as few German games ask for such decisions.

Nothing truly wrong with Shadows Over Camelot; it elicits neither disgust nor praise from me.  A truly mediocre game.

RATING: 8
I gave Shadows Over Camelot an 8/10 because I enjoy it and it's really fun. It has a few problems, though. It can't be played with just two people, and I don't find it very interesting with three people, so I don't get to play it as often as I like because it's sometimes difficult for me to get groups of four or more together. The random nature of the battles means that the game can be lost from dice rolls, rather than from lack of play skill. I wish there was a way for non-battling players to contribute to the success of a battle (a logistics card, perhaps?).

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Even though it's fairly limited on its own, this is the perfect way to introduce your friends to cooperative gaming, and it's so much fun to play with selfish people who are not yet used to the concept of cooperative board gaming. I think this game blends the perfect amount of challenge and accessibility, making victory realistically attainable, even if you have to resort to desperate measures for the sake of your comrades.
While the there's only a few different quests to embark on within this game, you won't have to worry about the experience becoming too repetitive due to one aspect of the game that always makes it interesting, and that's the prospect of a traitor being present amongst your group.
It's the brilliant addition of a traitor component that keeps me coming back to this game. The constant, looming distrust, and fear of fully committing your resources to any one player that can bring your team to victory, due to the prospect that they may, or may not be a traitor, is what makes every single game interesting and fun. Without that singular, brilliant addition, this game might be a little too limited to fully recommend.

That being said, its limited quests can easily be fixed if Days of Wonder would just release a few more expansions for this game that added more board pieces, but so far the only expansion available only adds new cards and characters, which are all great additions, but don't do much to breathe new life into the game if you aren't already in love with it. I really wish they'd add more quests, and new board pieces.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Just got this game over Christmas season.   No other game like it - it is as if you are playing against a computer  and it is extremely hard to beat.  The game board design and playing peices are excellent and very nice to look at.  When you actually beat the game you have accomplished something!  This is a must have and it offers pretty decent bang for the buck.  We love this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Awesome Game!  Heavy in theme.  You are one of a group of brave knights heading of to battle dragons, save relics or even save your home... Camelot!  Do you have what it takes...?  

This is a great game for a family get together, or when maybe you have a few more than four players.  

Assign the knights.  Takes turns...Evil Action-Good Action.  Quickly respond to Evil actions building by on quests or removing those dreaded catapults.  This game is different from any other game but refreshingly so.  I can't think of another like it.  

This game is a cooperative game and works well at introducing non gamers to games not so much like: Risk/Monopoly.  



Some players that I know have become bored quickly of this game but if you really sink your teeth into it, this game has curve balls to throw and can be a really fun hour.

RATING: 8

It's a game with a fun theme, and incredible social interaction.  Also something you can get non-gamers into.  Battlestar Galactica has refined some of these mechanics, but you can't scoff at the originator.

RATING: 7
Les Chevaliers de la Table Ronde - Dans "les chevaliers de la table ronde", 3-7 joueurs jouent le rôle de chevaliers de la table ronde combattant un mal envahissant. Les roles sont choisis aléatoirement, et chaque personnage dispose d'une capacité spéciale. Les joueurs piochent aussi,au hasard, une carte de loyauté. Il y a 8 cartes de loyauté,dont 7 loyales. La 8eme est celle du traitre. Ces cartes restent face cachée, de façon à ne pas connaitre celui qui possede cette carte traitre ou si personne ne l'a.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I really love the cooperative game/traitor mechanism. This game is a pioneer in these aspects. Always and over the whole course of the game interesting - even if it is not your turn.

Most likely there will be one big tight moment near the end when you have to discover traitor(s). The game gains a lot from the Merlin expansion and the possibility of 2 traitors. Best player count: 7 or 8 with expansion.

All players should know the important cards like Fate, Guinevere, Avalon and the journey cards in the Merlin expansion.

As a traitor you feel a bit restricted at times. Battlestar Galactica handled this aspect better later. Anyway I always really enjoy the game - whether I'm a traitor or not.

RATING: 8

RATING: 4

As a roleplayier, I love co-operative gaming but I'm not sure board games have achieved that properly yet, to my mind.  This does have truly beautiful pieces though; they're really quite exceptional.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
11/23: From the few plays I've had so far, I generally like SoC thematically and gameplay-wise. However, I hate the traitor role for a number of reasons.

As the traitor, I had the hardest time playing sneakily while still trying to hurt the loyal knights. So hard, in fact, that it wasn't fun for me at all. I now dread drawing the traitor, which in my opinion, should be the role you look forward to drawing! If you try to really hurt the knights early on (siege spam, etc.), then you're outed immediately (once it is possible to accuse), and you usually win from siege overrun. However, if you do this, then you are not really keeping with the spirit of the game, and you're ultimately ruining the game experience for everyone else. If you go the sneaky route, you are eventually outed because the other players notice you are traveling too much, offering bad advice, going for Lancelot's armor first, tossing quests, dumping cards at the sword quest, etc. etc. It's way too hard to operate in the darkness (cards are revealed to everyone, etc.), and it's way too easy to win by ruining the game.

In the end, the traitor's problems are my only real complaint. I love the teamwork aspect, the theme, and the fact that you can play this with a large party, so I'd definitely recommend it. Maybe someone that loves SoC will mod the traitor's role someday? I'm sure there's something you could do to give the role more options than just "playing inefficiently."

VERDICT:

One of the better co-op games around, and I recommend it for bigger groups. The traitor role feels incomplete, or at the very least, fairly impotent (especially if you play with a group experienced in SoC). That being said, I'm still usually willing to play it. 

7/10

UPDATE: Played a few more times and I really do like this game.  It can be hard to get to the table as you need some time and also need everyone to agree to play it.  I would say you need at least 5 to play...7 is better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
We mostly played this not as intended, as we usually just told everybody what cards we had and what we were planning to do. In general that's what I like in co-op games: everybody talking about their options, suggesting plans, and together coming up with a strategy to win. With this kind of table talk this game becomes much too easy and boring. You don't have much to do on your turn and in the end you can even guarantee victory several turns ahead: just calculate how many turns you need to finish and then stop drawing events, talking damage and placing catapults instead.

Having a traitor in the group makes the game more interesting, but the traitor himself often didn't enjoy playing much. It's quite difficult to sabotage without revealing yourself. And after being revealed, it's boring to be the traitor.

I realize this is not how it is meant to be played and I'd like to try it again with "in character" talk, but it irks me that it's so vague in what exactly you're allowed to say.

RATING: 6
There is only one game that does everything better as far as cooperation and saving the kingdom goes and that is the early republic scenario of Republic of Rome.  But at the same time, the simplicity of this game is enough for players to quickly learn the system. Probably the closest thing we'll see in the near future to a streamlined version of Republic of Rome.   I don't think the replayability is there (correction - the replayability is not there!) though but we'll see.  Without a traitor, the game falls very flat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Thematic, intense, beautiful. Shadows over Camelot is all these and more when it comes to talking about the greatest cooperative game, but... is it? It puts so much on the table (literally as well) while still being light enough to introduce to newer players. The miniatures are beautiful (it's a shame I have no artistic talent) and the artwork is amazing, showcasing the level of quality that Days of Wonder put into their games. The main gripe is that the game is boring for the traitor unless they can really embrace the theme, and it can drag a lot as everyone tries to stall a loss. Everyone else has decisions to make and discussions to have except the traitor.

RATING: 7
Close cousin to Knizia's "Lord of the Rings" but not as good.  The components and artwork are beautiful, the theme is strong, and the traitor mechanism is a lot of fun.  The first couple of plays are fantastic and exciting.  There is not much variety in the card decks, however, which makes the game repetitive and mechanical after only a few plays.  Everyone should try this game because it truly is a blast the first few times, but I'm not sure how well it will hold up to extended play.  I hope Days of Wonder has some expansions in the works to create more variety!

RATING: 5

The last time I played was with a full complement of players, a few of which were new to the game, and it was dreadfully boring. One of the players actually fell asleep.

Now my 15 yr. old son recently played this with two of his buddies and they loved it. One of his friends went so far as to say it may be his favorite game yet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
UPDATE: The thing that makes Shadows over Camelot unduly frustrating is the fact that Knizia's Lord of the Rings exists. Given that Shadows over Camelot makes so many mistakes that Knizia clearly showed designers how to avoid, it's frustrating to see Shadows stubbornly refusing to learn from what has gone before. It's a mediocre game as it is, but the existence of a 10-rated game that is so similar is so many ways, except that it works, makes Shadow's failure all the more inexcusable.
---
I may have actually been too generous in my review. As we've been playing more, I've come to the concluions that this game - in addition to its mechanical problems - simply isn't fun. It's mind-numbingly tedious with large numbers of players, and the number of decisions you get to make is tiny. Decide to go after the grail ... and you don't have to think again for forty minutes. Days of Wonder and Fantasy Flight have apparently figured that they can compensate for mediocre gameplay with overproduced bits; don't tell them they are right. I am profoundly disappointed with my fellow-reviewers for the unvarnished praise they have heaped on this game.

I wonder how much this has to do with the fact that the Arthurian theme is really just not that compelling anymore. Taking advantage of some of the recent re-imagining (like Gillain Bradshaw or Monty Python) would have made a more engaging game, I think. These days, Arthur is more interesting for its historical place than as drama, and games need drama.

But the longer the game goes, the more I want it to be over.  How can it be so dull when there are seemingly so many rich touches?

I think it boils down to the fact that, really, it doesn't matter what you do.  The bad cards will do what they will and you will conspire with your fellows to make sure you've all made the best moves possible, but the game will end and you will feel like there's nothing you could have done to have changed the outcome.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Shadows over Camelot's lavish production values and distinctively French artwork has "Days of Wonder" treatment written all over it, adding to the already positive buzz concerning this company.

The cooperative gameplay - not entirely unlike that of Knizia's LOTR - benefits greatly from the added twist a possible traitor in the knights' ranks provides.

Whereas Knizia's design is more linear in character, SOC sees Arthur's valiant knights fighting on multiple "fronts". Juggling these various threats and opportunities is part of the fun and prompts plenty of discussion round the table.

Whereas LOTR in my experience encourages one general to direct and coordinate strategy to some measure, SOC sees more independent play. 

I strongly recommend playing with n+1 loyalty cards. Without the traitor dimension the game is reduced to a puzzle lacking that delicious psychological dimension.

However, SOC isn't entirely without problems. I fear the endgame MAY turn out to be anticlimactic, say if victory is assured and the knights actually WANT to lose a number of quests to lose the game. Certainly, LOTR does better in this regard. Mordor almost always is full of suspense.

Furthermore, the late game may well see many knights on catapult-bashing duty. Not terribly exciting, really. Particularly if you're waiting for a couple more black swords for the game to end. Really a problem I'd adress with a set of variant rules were I to play this game regularly. Were this not a problem, I'd rate this game higher.

Now, which of these two siblings do I prefer? Hard to say. I love the traitor role and the ambiguity it provides and the multiple "fronts" (reminds me of some of my favourite wargames, btw) in SOC. Yet for me LOTR scores somewhat higher in the theme category and does a better job telling the story. The quests in SOC, as well as their rewards and penalties, are somewhat too Poker-inspired for my tastes to quite satisfy my Arthurian appetite, if you see what I mean.

On balance, LOTR feels more like a puzzle whereas SOC plays more like a game. After all you're not only playing against the game, but there's possibly also that evil traitor out there...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A fine game although nothing special.  I did enjoy how difficult the game was and how tense the finish ended up.  Other than that the game was a bit too long (close to 2 hours) and felt a bit repetitive at times.  Didn't feel quite as dynamic as Battlestar Galactica, which I'd prefer over this.

Enjoyed my 1 play but wouldn't request it.

RATING: 8
I really enjoy Shadows. I love hidden roles, agonizing decisions, tons of tabletalk, and lots of tension and this game has it all. Whether you're the traitor trying to remain hidden until just the right time, or a loyal knight trying to figure out who the traitor is (and even if there is one to begin with) while struggling against the game itself, this game is filled with tension. It's always enjoyable to watch things heat up toward the end of the game as everyone gets more accusatory and the loyal players are scrambling to find the traitor. Shadows might be a little simplistic in terms of mechanics, but getting into the spirit of the game and the tense atmosphere make this one a keeper.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
This game is fun and balanced (if there is a traitor or an overwhelming possibility of one). The interaction is great, the game is totally innovative. The production value puts this game at the top of my list in terms of aesthetics.  Now for the problems with this game, or more to the point the people playing it. This game is not cooperative. Whoever says that is a fool. You can't play this game cooperative. If you don't play the game with the traitor, the game is totally uninteresting. Sometimes, you have to lose to win without a traitor. Huh? Sounds like the game is 80% finished, and broken without at least an overwhelming possibility of a traitor. If you play the game with the traitor or the idea that anybody could be one, it is not cooperative...it is everyone for themselves against the traitor. My problem with this game is people don't play it the way it should be played. I think players should keep their mouth mostly shut, and their eyes open, instead of the other way around. You should pick the traitor out of the lineup of prospectives based on their actions, not on their thoughts. People seem to talk way too much and ruin the experience. This has gotten to the point where people have talked so much and crushed the game so badly that they have to play with this Squires variant. The problem is not the game, it is the way you play the game. It has to be, because the game is way to simple to be glorious one time and a horrible experience the next.  People should play their hand, and talk about who is the traitor, instead of "Hey, I have a 4 fight card in my hand." One of these days, I will pull a group together that understands this and end up playing a great game.

RATING: 7.5
cooperative games must be played with the right group in order to succeed. I really like co-ops and so does one of my gaming groups in particular (as well as my younger brother whom I game with frequently). I played it twice with my family and it was a big success! We did play without the traitor as they aren’t really gamers, and even though I’m sure the game is much better with the added tension of the traitor, I still liked it a lot. I have since tried it with a couple of friends and they all enjoyed it too. 
I think it’s a very different coop game than the “usual” Pandemic/Forbidden Island/Flash Point: Fire Rescue/Defenders of the Realm etc. which is obviously a good thing as I don't need yet a co-op like those. This one certainly isn't!

I liked how you needed to decide between three bad things to happen before you could do one good thing, and I think the rule that you aren’t allowed to talk about which cards you have on your hand is great (even though it’s sometimes obvious to the others which cards you have when you say something…).
I loved the different types of quests which feel unique. Furthermore, the tension of which black card you draw is tense. The only negative is that the game might run a bit too long and that the ending can be a bit anticlimactic as you can actually plan to win by losing a quest… Still, it’s a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
April 2009: hitting the table all the time; students here at school are requesting it every weekend and recent games have been some of my best gaming experiences in years. Some of my best gaming experiences ever were with this game. 

UPDATE AFTER LEAVING THE RESIDENTIAL HIGH SCHOOL WHERE I PLAYED IT: All and all, I think my group took it so far, so overboard, and so passionately over-the-top that I don't know if I can come back to this as a player again. We were sweating, swearing, worked up, disgusted, elated and it was almost too much. And I wouldn't trade those experiences in the slightest.

The game morphed into a true test of masculinity and self-worth when played with the ruthless 'gifted' teenage students I lived with for several years. Bringing the game to the brink of personal battle was done as a test of one's metal and trustworthiness. At the extremes it became Klingon knights-of-the-round table. And it was glorious. But regular Shadows was becoming 'almost' too easy and adding the Merlin expansion was just too hard with so much inherent group tension.

At this point, I would rather teach the game. I don't think I played at all in my last year at the school because counselors aren't supposed to break students and I think I still had a gear or two more to my game. Maybe I'll play with adults next. And mixed genders! Even if I still think the game shines brightest when played with a cohort of bright, competitive, stressed-out teenage males. The game where we almost all had to give our lives on the last turn to barely, barely edge out our very first victory remains my greatest single moment of gaming elation. We were lost, ...but providence honored our sacrifices.

07/2012: At this point, not getting play since I am no longer living at a boarding school. Dropped rating because I don't feel drawn to play it, but it will always have a place in my collection. 

10/2015: Saving it for when I can bring it out to a new group. This will be fun when my sister's children get older. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
First (and only play so far) was without a traitor, so my rating is based on that.

I get the general impression that a lot of the cooperative games have a tendancy to play themselves, and such tendancy is directly related to the amount of table-talk that is allowed.  Not sayinig that is bad or good, but different.  Shadows over Camelot is fun, for sure, but is another in what may be an overused mechanic - i.e. "beat the game together".

I have a strange feeling that playing with a traitor at the table can result in a much different play experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not a huge fan of collaborative games, but this wasn't bad.  Played this four times over the weekend, two without the traitor option and two with.  I think the viability of the traitor option depends on the number of players. In one game, with only three players, I was the traitor and found it pretty easy to win against the other two.  I could see that a traitor against 4-6 loyal knights could be an interesting game, but I don't think two loyal knights really stand a chance against a traitor.  Once I had gotten Lancelot's armor, I played the Fate card which allowed me to reveal myself as the traitor, as I felt it would be easier to win with the actions available to an open traitor than it would be in hiding.  A valid gameplay decision, I think, but it doesn't seem very thematic.

Also, the endgame suffers once you have enough white swords to win; just stay alive and avoid getting too many siege engines, and you can let black cards pile up on the Black Knight and Dragon Quests to get sufficient black swords to end the game.  Definitely not thematic.  It's as if the Knights of the Round Table were lounging around and saying, "Well, we've completed enough quests this year.  I don't particularly feel like saving a village from a rampaging dragon today."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Shadows Over Camelot is the first game I owned that was collaborative with a traitor mechanic. And at the time, I loved that concept.

The successful games have been with friends that allow themselves to get into the theme a bit and don't treat it totally like a numbers puzzle. Plus, the traitor element is essential to prevent someone from being a bit too heavy-handed with their advice and guidance.

It's great with the right group, but it's the enthusiasm from other people that gets this to the table, and not my own. I'll happily play it, but I'm looking to other options currently.

Update: I eventually traded this one away. Space Alert and Escape are my go-to collaborative games, and if I want a traitor, then The Resistance and Shadow Hunters provide that same experience in a much quicker package. This game just sat on the shelf for too long, so I ultimately traded it away.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I was surprised by how much I enjoyed playing this game and I agree with the others who have played it before that it really depends on the group. Since you know there is a traitor among you it definitely adds to the tension in this co-op game. I found the game to be rather difficult as we barely had 3 swords before we lost. Maybe we got all the bad cards up front, but I do feel luck of the draw between the two decks can really swing this game. I would happily play this again, but I feel it needs a group of gamers to work well as I'm not sure how some of the non-gamers I am around would pick this up given the secretive nature required.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is simple enough to pick up relatively quickly but can be a real mind game when it comes to trying to exposing the traitor (whether real or imaginary).  Depending on the players and the luck of the shuffle, it seems to play differently every time.  It's held my interest for longer than I thought a game of its type would.  As with many cooperative games, planning is definitely a must at the beginning and throughout the game--and it can help expose the traitor.

The main problem I have with this game is that some players try to "quarterback" the game excessively, which takes the fun out of it for me.  If everyone playing is at about the same level of vocalness, it works much better.

The best quote I've heard during a SoC game was directed at King Arthur right after he revealed himself as the traitor:  "No wonder Guinevere is sleeping with Lancelot!"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Keep - Collection
Great game with huge replayability.  It plays a lot better with 6-7 players.  Don't include the traitor until you have that many.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite co op games. Terrific theme with beautiful miniatures. The traitor element is unique and fun and surprisingly well balanced. The game has a tremendous amount of depth yet is still easily picked up by novice gamers. It will take a few game plays to understand the nuances of the game and to know what to look for with a particularly defensive traitor, but that only makes the game better in my opinion. Being a big fan of Arthurian legend, it can be a little stressful to see Camalot in such dark times, but if a game makes me passionate, that can't REALLY be a bad thing, can it?

RATING: 7
Very enjoyable cooperative game.  The element of the traitor adds a great level of tension.  Haven't played enough to see if the cries of "too hard" or "too easy" are justified.  I certainly don't see the "too easy" argument.  I'm more inclined to think a traitor with only a few players makes the game very difficult to win.  However, instead of taking on lots of rules, I think it's just best to avoid playing this game with only three or four players.  The game seems to click better with more players, anyway.  Five or six might be the sweet spot.

Update: Still fun, but for semi-cooperative games, I would always play Battlestar Galactica instead of this one.  That said, it isn't as easy to get BSG to the table as it's quite a bit more complex.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Kooperativ. König Artus und die Ritter der Tafelrunde. Gut!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The first time I played this, I felt like I was indifferent to the game but willing to give it another shot because I was playing with a random crowd of people who were either baffled by the rules or teetering on the brink of a nervous collapse.

Fast forward two years or so, and I give it another try, with a group of people I am confident are neither dimbulbs or emotionally stunted rageaholics and ... nope, I just don't like this game. Like Pandemic, it's a jumped-up set-collection game. Unlike Pandemic, it lacks the stripped-down elegance, speedy run time, and knife's-edge tension that makes for a quality co-op experience. It's 45 minutes of fun in a two-hour package. The game itself went down to the wire, but there were long stretches where I was limited by the shape of my hand to obvious and uninteresting plays (since the quests are slow, incremental progress in, for all intents and purposes, moving a marker up and down a track) on my turn, which is an experience not practically dissimilar to [i]downtime[/i].

The possibility of a bad guy in the mix adds a bit of spice but I think the difficulty of making a good game with the traitor mechanic is understated -- you have to design a game where the traitor can subtly but not undetectably bring down the team, and you have to balance the risk and reward of unmasking him/her. Ideally, you would also create incentives for everyone to muddy the waters. A game like this [i]could[/i] work in interesting ways but I have yet to see a game where it [i]does[/i].

Personally, I find games where the opportunity to defect (in a game-theoretic sense) is an organic decision by the player in response to emergent incentives (cf. Republic of Rome, Incan Gold, Article 27) to be more interesting than games where you simply get assigned a white or black hat from the get-go.

I see little reason to play this game in a world where the Resistance series (which even includes an Arthurian themed game ferchrissake) exists; The Resistance is itself an overrated game but it distills the interesting part of Shadows into an appropriate running time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Simply a great co-operative game in that you have the choice of playing fully co-op, co-op with a traitor or co-op with POTENTIALLY but not necessarily a traitor. Solo play (with several loyal knights) is also possible and can be made challenging enough to keep you on your toes.

Unlike some other games, Shadows over Camelot is not unforgiving, so you are allowed to mess up some things and even the worst black (bad) cards cannot spoil the game for you just after it started. (I know of games that CAN ruin all your setup work by poor card draws early on.)

To make this game work optimally, some roleplaying is required. Getting just the right amount of roleplaying may be the greatest challenge. It generally depends on your playing group how much you want to introduce.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I loved this game the first few times I played it. However, my love quickly faded away, and I now find the game   boring. It's basically the same game every time. There are not enough changes to make me want to keep playing it. (10+ plays)

RATING: 6
GameStorm 2015 Math Trade fodder. One of my earliest post-BGG gaming era purchases. Sort of sad to see it go for that reason. But it never sees the table, and I doubt that it ever would have. Buh-bye.

---

High production value on all the bits, as usual for Days of Wonder. The cooperative aspect is welcome amongst non-gamer friends and family. Everyone will feel like they're being slowly crushed to death, but at least it's at the hands of circumstance rather than another player who may be better than you.

Unless of course there is a traitor in your midst. The traitor is ultimately the redeeming quality of this game. Without it, you're just working together to beat the system at tug-o-war.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The first time I played through we ignored two key rules. We didn't play with the traitor and we didn't notice that the second hero action in a turn is not allowed to be the same as the first. The game was easy. We quickly filled up the white swords and had to grind to fill the table to end the game. It kind of sucked.

I just finished my second and third plays and it was way better. The traitor is awesome, though I think it could still be left out in small games. We did a random draw on all 8 role cards so that there was some chance that the traitor wasn't included, but he still showed up in both games. The biggest change, however, was the second action bit. Without being able to double up on quests, the game is much harder. We lost both games. We were close on the first one, but evil surprised us with a 2 seige engine attack, which filled up the board. Good tension. Good fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is difficult to rate for me. I've only played once and I enjoyed it a lot. I think (as usual) the Days of Wonder components and presentation are fantastic. I also really enjoy the cooperative nature of the game. 

But I played the traitor in my first game (which was great). I dragged my feet and squandered a few things a couple times, then ultimately revealed myself through obvious actions when I thought it would serve no further purpose not to. The thing is...in hindsight, I could see nothing I could do as a player/traitor that would be as disruptive as simply declaring immediately and adding siege engines every turn. There is no actual incentive for the traitor to pretend to be a player, other than the joy of the roleplay. So...while I really enjoy the game, I think in some respects its broken. I'll have to review the articles and see if there is a sensible fix for this.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
To sum up how Shadows Over Camelot makes me feel, I have one word- hoodwinked.  The first couple of plays were golden, and I thought the game might even be great.  The theme was there, there was intrigue, and it was challenging.  Of course, it doesn't hurt that the game looks dynamite and is very accessible.  However, after playing it several times, I started to realize that without the traitor mechanic and the cooperation, it's really just another rummy-derived set collection card game.  There was also a point at which I realized that the game with an incompetent traitor was impossible to lose and a smart traitor is completely unbeatable if he realizes that playing catapults every turn will win the game every time.  The traitor element is much better handled in Saboteur or Cash & Guns.  It's really a shame, because it seems like this should be a great game but it just isn't in my opinion.  I certainly understand the appeal of the game but I think gamers looking for depth and replayability would be best advised to go elsewhere.  I cringe every time I hear someone say "anybody up for Shadows"?  I'm not suprised it's so popular though, given the apparent mantle Days of Wonder has been christened with and the appeal that glorified childrens games have to many of the folks here on the 'geek.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Want to play this more, but it's tough to get five or more people together when something bigger isn't already planned.  Terrific looking game, and the play is tense.  There probably isn't much replayability here, and after a dozen games I don't think that this would come out much.  But I've only played a couple of times, and I'm ready for more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I was surprised to find that the rating for this game actually went down for me after more plays. First off this game really looks great. The bits are all amazing with attractice cards, and great minis. The game itself is fairly straight forward and easy to learn. Quite streamlined, but still a lot going on. The possibility of a traiter also really adds a fun twist. After multiple plays, however, the weeknesses of this game show through. The theme really seems somewhat detached. What I mean by this is that the quests don't really have much to do with each other, and practically any theme (or no theme) could just as easily have been attached. You are essentially trying to make regular playing card hands in order to win. The theme isn't bad in the game, but it isn't as rich as it first appears. The feeling the game gives you is of being pulled in many different directions. The problem is that you pretty much have to go where you have the cards to go, or make due if you are forced to go somewhere. There aren't any real big decisions in the game. Overall, I still enjoy this game, and it still deserves a decent rating. I don't, however, believe that this game is as good as everybody first thought it would be or the hype presented it to be. You'll like it, but my guess is that you probably won't love it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Tough game to rate, since I love most of the individual elements but don't feel they mesh into a partiuclarly astounding game. I may be missing the entire point here, but I think the traitor is this game's weak point. I don't like the idea that either player X will win, or everyone else will win - I prefer either full cooperation or full competition. The possibility that you can die and be taken out of the game is one of my pet peeves - I want everyone to be in the entire game. These aspects wouldn't be too bad by themselves, but the game itself is pretty mean, and some of the event cards are really, really vicious.

That said, when everyone's cooperating, I love the game...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was quite impressed with this game the first couple of times I played it.  After a couple more playings, my ardor has somewhat cooled.  It has some possible downsides: (1) it can take a while to get to your turn and then there's not a whole lot for you to do, (2) once the traitor is revealed, the game can become obvious/slow/tedious for that player, (3) it's possible that the strategy for the loyal knights can be "solved" - in any event, there's a question of whether the game has extensive replayability, since we seem to see all the white cards every time we play.  Having said all that, I still enjoy the game and would be willing to play and it's still on my "buy/obtain" list (though a bit lower than it was).  I'm more aware that a good portion of the enjoyment of the game will come from the players, so it will not succeed in all groups.

RATING: 7

Nice to add to your collection as a birthday gift, but if its your own money there are far better games out there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really need to sleeves this game, black card's edges get easily marked after a few light plays. The Mayday Games purple Standard USA Card Sleeves[MDG-7040] fit the cards and they easily go back into the insert. Expect this on any used game you purchase. The cards are good quality, it is just that running the black color to the edge of the card that is the problem. 

Note: MayDay Games sleeves are cheap to buy, you can within a pack get one or two that are too tight. Two packs will be needed and give you extras. And no, I am not B&M-ing like some, these things can't be easy to manufacture and have all of them to specs given the material and how close they fit cards. I am amazed how well they do. You want sleeves that fit with some slack, poke you when you play, more than double the price, then buy FGG. Very tired of seeing, being told of that long over beat debate.

RATING: 9
So so so long i didn't want to play this game. It looked complicated and not that much fun. Than i got talked into playing it...best decision ever. This game takes hidden roles the way i like it. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I pretty much only play this game when my extended family/brother wants to play it. They love this game and have made me play it for maybe 10 years now, and I think I'm about done playing it forever. Its just really boring for real gamers and too complex for non-gamers . There are simpler and better social deduction games. If you have too many players you always have at least one player start getting bored and stops paying attention, and you constantly have to remind them its their turn, which is super annoying.

I can hardly blame anyone who gets bored, however, because you have such limited actions in this game. Are you out of cards but want to fight the Black Knight? Go to Camelot. That's your turn. Draw cards. That's your next 3-4 turns. Go to the Black Knight. That's another turn. Then lay cards down one at time for 4 turns, assuming you have the right cards. The traitor and loyalty thing is really dumb too. The traitor can't do practically anything out of the ordinary for three quarters of the game or its obvious its them. After that, they can turn the game from a win to a loss in one turn without really any counter play from the loyal knights. Its dumb. 

And don't get me started on the whole "you aren't supposed to tell others what you have in your hand" thing. It turns into people constantly dropping hints about what they have, but making sure that hint is not TOO obvious or it would be against the rules. But the hint was good enough everyone knows what you are talking about. Completely stupid. 

I can see why people love this game. I just really don't. Every time my group wants to play it I suck it up, but inside I'm secretly groaning.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
I don't see how this is a game. You stay on one place taking one card at a time each turn and you spend whole turn to move (since that is all you can do on a turn) and then stay on one place placing one card at a time each turn.

There are some decisions you can make (a little more when betrayer is in the game) but it doesn't change the fact that you are basically helpless. All you do is collect and spend cards. Btw those cards have no mechanics. They are just numbers and you have to match them. And if you want to react to something that is happening on the board, you have to spend at least 3 turns to do it (1. move back home, 2. move to the location where you want to do something, 3. play a card). If so happens to be that you don't have the card you need, only more turns of doing nothing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played this elsewhere a number of times and liked it enough to buy it - and then found that I was never in the mood to pull it out. I think it's a play-time issue - while [i]Shadows[/i] can be fun, it takes long enough that fun-per-unit-time is lower than many other games. (That plus the Grail quest, which annoys me from a design perspective - everything else is "what do you do with the cards you've been dealt", there it's "oh, I got these cards, so I guess I ought to go play them".)

RATING: 7
Production: Quality components. Days of Wonder sets the new standard for how to produce a game.  The artwork is immersive, and the figurines are so much better than would have been token equivalents.

Play: Having only played once, and as the traitor, I do not have an accurate sense of this game. I dislike being in this role, and so my experience has been colored accordingly. Many have expressed a problem with cooperative games that the decision-making can be driven by the most experienced player; my gripe is rather than the game is not intelligently plotting against us, but rather randomly (or by some predictable probability) throwing challenges at us. My one playing of this game didn't suggest to me that it is an exception. (3+1+3) (1 play)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is an interesting traitor game, but it just feels flat to me. It seems like a rummy game rather than a board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
$64.99 from Jogo Canada, mail order from Winnipeg.  I stopped in to their store once when visiting my sister - it was quite a small store.  I heard a few years ago that they are no longer in business.
An excellent cooperative game.  3-7 players.  I'm hooked on King Arthur, and this is the best King Arthur game I own.
I considered buying the Company of Knights expansion, but I can't justify paying $20 for 8 coloured figurines.

RATING: 10
A cooperative game with the possibility of traitor amongst the Knights of the Round.  Relatively easy to learn, tough to master, this game will chew you up and spit you out if you don't work together.  The paranoia of trying to ferret out any possibly traitors creates a great tension, and everyone is engaged the entire game, making sure to catch any potential slips by a guilty party.  The theme here is wonderful, and as always, it looks beautiful on the table.  A delight to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm not real fond of co-operative games. In Pandemic, one person generally controls the game and everybody follows. That aspect can exist in this game, but doesn't have to. Everyone can be working on their own objective, with the help of other players and still feel like you're making your own decisions. Adding a traitor to the mix is a nice aspect as well. It's not difficult to learn and gameplay isn't overly long. Theme is maintained.

RATING: 5
There really just are not enough "interesting decisions per player per minute" (my ultimate way of viewing a game) in Shadows, so its lightness overcomes it. The inventive cooperative-but-with-a-betrayer mechanic was good for its time, though done much deeper and better later on by Battlestar Galactica. In the end, though, this game wants to be played with a lot of people (more like 7 than 3), but that party aspect also makes it harder to like, because a given player has fewer turns in the game, and each turn has just a few things to do -- maybe one interesting decision. So while I admire the originality of the design, and there is some subtlety here, there ultimately isn't enough mental engagement for me to give it more than a 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I love playing Shadows Over Camelot because semi-cooperative gameplay is my favourite. The game is beautiful and the theme is really interesting! My complaint with the game is that the heroes can just ride the coat tails of their past successes to victory without doing much for the last couple rounds or so without being too threatened by the traitor, so it's often anti-climactic barring evil card drama. With more than 4 players, the Merlin's company expansion makes it much more difficult and exciting. Any less than 5 players with the expansion can be extremely difficult for the heroes.

RATING: 7
My kids love to play this game, and I'm never one to say no. Good theme, quality bits and a fun time. Game length is also good for family nights.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Shadows over Camelot has excellent flavor, art, and cooperative gameplay. However, the "single action per turn" mechanic feels limiting sometimes, and the game can drag on, especially if several turns in a row oscillate the game state. I kind of wish there was a "ko" rule, where the board state could not be repeated on the next turn. That said, I really enjoy the way the game throws multiple challenges so that the players have to manage their collective resources, and I feel that it is really balanced in terms of who can do what. I would highly recommend this game to a seasoned veteran of other cooperative games such as Pandemic or Arkham Horror.

Edit: After playing this game once a week for two months as a start to game night (it has rules for people to join/leave as necessary) this game has lost a lot of popularity, because there always seems like something else people would rather play. It is a nice game to have in the collection, but not a must buy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is very fun to play!  S.o.C. is made up of 7 mini-games, or quests, which are really quite simple.  Each player works together, or individually, to build hands (sets) of cards to defeat quests. This, at its very root, would be boring but due to the level of interaction because of the chance of there being a traitor, this game is soooo engaging!  Our first game consisted of LOUD accusations, laughter, and surprises.  We all immediately wanted to play again!  2 games later... and I was so glad I purchased this game.  I can see why this game has held its own for so long in the cooperative genre.  If you've not enjoyed cooperative until now, try this game... it is fun!

RATING: 5
You and your friends will band together to defeat evil!

By making poker hands.

Dishwater-dull gameplay is enlivened by the possibility of a traitor working behind the scenes to screw you all.   Unfortunately, the rest of the game is so repetitive that it's difficult to care until you get down to those last few moments, where one traitorous act could be the difference between a final white sword and a black one, and, and, and...

Oh, Kevin, it wasn't you?  But you were acting so suspicious!

I'm just not willing to play an 80-minute game for 5 minutes of good stuff.

The artwork and the pieces are stunning.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Finally had a chance to play this. Enjoyed it, though it did seemd to have some oddities in the rules and mechanisms...  
The "you may not share precise information about your cards" part seems to be a bit weird for a (semi-)cooperative game. It seems to be the worst possible solution to the issue of needing to provide cover for a possible traitor.
The quests aren't all that interesting mechanically. The "puzzles" are very straight forward. Play a card. turn is over. On the other hand of course it's nice and streamlined but it really made me think about more interesting ways of collecting sets or poker hands (which in return might have given more possible cover to a traitor).
The end game was a bit unthematic and dragged on a bit...  we managed to get to 7 or 8 white swords but then still had to get  the roudn table filled up...  which made us accept the failure of quests just to get up to the full 12 sowrds...  arrghh!  that was weird!  
Despite some shortcomings (seemigly so, on repeated plays perhaps these things would turn out to be non-issues?), i really had a good time playing it and thought it was a worthwhile experience.  
Willing to play again anytime!

RATING: 7
I had a rough time rating this game. I wanted to like it more but there's a couple of problems I had with it. The traitor aspect of it is really essential (which rubs some people in my game group the wrong way) - without the chance of a traitor in the group, there is one overriding strategy that mostly works. Also, the rules were a bit "fiddly". We made several mistakes in our first few games that I only cleared up after reading the FAQs.

That said, my group was fairly lukewarm to it initially and have warmed up to it. I feel the Merlin's Company expansion adds a much needed variety to the base game.

RATING: 6.5
This is the one co-op game we have which doesn't suffer too much from "Hail to the Chief" syndrome. Since everyone's cards are hidden, and since your cards determine which quests you can effectively pursue (and since there can be traitors), each person has more control over their individual roles than something like Forbidden Island.
