RATING: 5
Top notch materials.
Gameplay is a little bit flat: great knights playing poker combination to defeat evil and complete eroic tasks.
Additionally, players have to make (obvious) decision only once every 2/3 turns. The presence of the Traitor is the only thing that prevents one from falling asleep during a game. However, the traitor element negates its value as gateway game.

I like Lord of the Rings better, since it fatures more dynamic and deeper gameplay.

RATING: 8
Excellent cooperative game. It has a nice variety of quests that require players to pay attention in the planning stages and really work together to follow through on those plans. There are really some tense moments, and difficult decisions to make, once the evil power begins to escalate. This seems to have more replay value than its spiritual cousin, Lord of the Rings. Playing "in character" can be quite fun, but after a while it tends to bog the game down a bit. Excellent artwork and bits, in typical Days of Wonder fashion. This one was definitely worth the wait. Recommended!

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm not sure what all the fuss is about.  I thought the game was simply ok.  To be fair I thought the same of LotR when I first played it, but now like it a lot more (especially with 2).  Accusing the traitor before the last turn can be bad, as you give them a pretty brutal power to use over and over.  It still suffers from being almost impossible to find the right balance between being too open with what cards people have (making the game too easy and boring), and playing with no talking at all (making it too hard and boring).  Perhaps there should be a "price" paid for playing a card or trading a card with Arthur as the result of something someone said. I'd play it again if there wasn't something else going on that I wanted to play more, but I can't see myself requesting to play myself.  Gorgeous bits for sure.

RATING: 8
My favorite cooperative that I've played - great theming (down to the "shadows" - impending doom is the dominant vibe with so many ways to lose piling up each turn), and the mechanics forestall any kind of "quarterbacking" phenomenon among the players.  

The traitor is also a great idea, even if it seems like adding insult to injury - even a semi-crafty traitor has a good chance of sinking everybody's chances, especially when the penalties for making false accusations are high.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Shadows over Camelot certainly isn't perfect, but it has lots of atmosphere and is a lot of fun. It also has a real sense of story, which many other games lack. The traitor aspect adds a lot to the game. Somewhat obsolete now due to the release of Battlestar Galactica, which improves upon the basic concept here. However, Shadows plays more quickly and is a more consistent experience than the more erratic BSG. When BSG is good, it's much better than Shadows. But BSG can also be much, much worse than the worst game of Shadows.

RATING: 6

RATING: 7

This beats out Lord of the Rings as it is more thematic, more replayable, and has better components.  I've yet to see the good guys lose, but the games have been close.  I wish I could draw the traitor...just once!  Heh.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Players take on the roles of Knights of the Round Table, and try to navigate Camelot through a series of ongoing trials and tribulations.  Players take turns to first advance evil in some way (hurting Camelot), then doing some good deed to quash evil.  Evil is defeated by completing quests and repelling invasions - richly themed stuff boiled down to playing certain melds of cards on different areas of the game boards, and you really don't get a say there - you look at your hand and it tells you where to go.  Beautiful bits, but really a Lord of the Rings knock-off that is about half as good in terms of game play.  Great as a party/social game, but I'm not sure it was targeted there.  It gets played 3 or 4 times a year, mainly as a beer and pretzels game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great atmosphere created.

RATING: 6

We've all figured out how to beat the board together that any deviation from that path is an instant give away to that player's traitorous intentions. Still, fun and innovative.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The box includes maps, playing cards, player aids, miniatures and few counters of fine quality.  Clear rules and innovative mechanics comprise an intriguing theme and fun interaction between players. The game competes against the players. For every move a player-knight takes there is a counter action from the game mechanics. So, the more players the better and more chances for success. Players are bound to defend the kingdom from Evil. In order to achieve this they have to complete quests like the search for relics, challenge the Black Knight, duel with Lancelot, participate in wars and lift the siege on Camelot. The knights united can easily beat any threat even when faced by bad luck and nasty coincidences or is there a traitor among them! Nice recreational time from Days of Wonder.  

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Okay co-operative game, but it feels a little "samey" the more you play it.  Fantastic looking game, and the traitor certainly helps the replayability somewhat, but I wonder if this game isn't a wee bit over-rated.  It's really just a glorified set-collection card game with a fancy board.   Excitement goes downhill rapidly the more you play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I like this game (loved it at first).  The cooperative part really gets people involved, and there is some good tension that makes the game fun.  The problem is, after you've played it a couple times, it's not any fun without the traitor.  And, it kinda sucks playing with someone new, because you almost dictate their moves. If you don't everyone will lose.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
If you meet at least two of these conditions you MUST try this game at least once in your life:
1. Watched Monty Python and the Holy Grail
2. Enjoy playing co-op games (ex: Pandemic)
3. Interested in Arthurian Legend
4. Like to randomly accuse people of things
5. Enjoy getting into character when you play games

This is a great co-op (with traitor mechanic) that follows the Knights for the Round Table in multiple quests/adventures (ie: Holy Grail, Excalibur, Lancelot, Black Knight, Tournaments, Dragons, Saxon/Pict Wars). Give it a go if it at all seems interesting to you. It has gorgeous artwork and great miniatures to play with as well!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

From my FTL Secret Santa 2012 [username=Radziol]

RATING: 8
The mechanics of this game are very simple once you play through, but in the 3 player game we played, the game proved a good challenge.

I like CO-OP games since they are rare, and allow players who are always out to win to work in a group for a common goal. We did determine quickly exacly which quests we had to win and which we could lose ot still win the game (which changes the game play a bit although still good strategy in my mind) and did not play with a random "traitor" but still, it took a lot of cooperation and planning ahead with each player to ensure victory, the core of any good Co-OP game.

RATING: 9.5
Currenty ranking as my #3 game, Shadows over Camelot is a game unlike any other that I've played thanks to it's traitor mechanic.
Other than that, the game is filled with an inviting theme of Arthurian legend ,great player interaction and a challenging gameplay, one that you will probably loose if you don't work together to complete your quests and find the treacherous traitor that is secretly sabotaging the knights to gain victory for camelot.

Indeed S.o.C is a game that you'd want to bring back to the table again and again for you and your friends and family to enjoy.

RATING: 6.5
Shadows over Camelot has some comparisions with Reiner Knizia's Lord of the Rings co-op game. I am not quite sure which one I like best between the two. 

Beautiful artwork, theme and presentation. Not as fun as I first of thought. Mechanics needs some work. Hand management. More of a card game than a board game in my opinion. The board is just to show where you can go to, do there and what you get for your efforts. Replayability not as high as I would of thought.

**After playing Shadows over Camelot more, I prefer Lord of the Rings than Shadows over Camelot.**

Rating 7 down to a 5.

Update:

Replayed Shadows over Camelot. I enjoyed the game we played. We had lots of fun. Had a better feeling compared to the other games I played. Maybe it's because of the player's I played with.

Rating up from a 5 to a 6.5

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great "cooperative" game, perhaps the best.

An excellent feature is that players are not FORCED to actually cooperate, but if they don't, they will lose. The "traitor" feature is superb and really makes the game special.

The mechanics are fairly smooth except for the awkward way in which players are forced to describe cards without actually saying specifically what card they are talking about. I'm not sure what is gained by forcing a player say "I need strength - but not maximum strength...", or whatever, instead of just saying "I need a 4".

The "Bits" are absolutely first-rate and I also enjoy making all the obligitory Monty Python quotes.

Note: Recently upped rating by a full 2 points  - playing with the right group really helps. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of those great co-op games that we keep coming back to again and again...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
So far I've found nothing to fault in this game. It's design creates a constant tension and you can feel the shadows closing in on Camelot as you work to align the Knights to stop the impending doom and also unmask the traitor. I suspect replay quality will be very high, especially if the traitor is used. The production quality is far and away one of the best I've ever seen in 40+ years of buying games. This game is almost underpriced at $49.95 and it will easily make my "money back guarantee" list.

RATING: 4
UPDATE: Granted, I've never played the expansion, but SoC typifies my issue with Days of Wonder games in general: they look really nice but ultimately have no substance.

A co-op game from Days of Wonder. I liked it quite a bit when it first came out, but each couple of plays made me drop the rating another point. It just doesn't grab me like Lord of the Rings, which I feel has more tension (as well as a theme that works for me more than SoC). In LotR, I feel palpable tension, but in SoC, I feel like I'm just laying down poker hands.

RATING: 6
Sadly, I want to give this game about an 8 or 8.5 but I can't.  The best part of the game is that it accommodates a 1-8 people and you can have a purely co-op game or one with a possible traitor.  There are a few things that hold it back for me the most effective strategy for the traitor is being openly traitorous and laying siege engines every round which is especially detrimental in a game with a low amount of players.  There seems to be a lack or things to do or I just find it to be repetitive.  It's fun but could have been so much more.

RATING: 8
One of the best cooperative games out there, full of flair (although basically abstract, like Knizia's LOTR) and astonishingly quick to play. The traitor role works very well and adds to the excitement, and the cooperative element never gets too "cosy" or boring. The physical quality of the game components is great and the game is beautiful to behold. Could be easily expanded with more characters, quests, etc.. Recommended!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Excellent pieces and a fantatstic theme in a gorgeous package.  But, although the game has a lot of tension and turns are quick, it really does bash you around each and every turn and sometimes your only option is simply to move!  Even without a traitor, this is tough game to win and usually requires player elimination (self-sacrifice) to complete the quests.  Usually I find Camelot falls and the end game is a bit repetitive with half the team fighting the besieging forces.  I think it works best at the 5-6 player level, but does require coordinated player interaction. Some knights are more powerful than others (i.e. essential), but I think the traitor has the easiest task (and is perhaps overpowered).  There is also a far bit of metagaming involved, where some quests you'll try and lose just to ensure 12 swords are obtained.  And maybe co-ops are not for me; it is tough, especially as the beseigers grow and fellow players make unwise plays.  Collectively we all lose (exc: traitor), else, maybe I'm not very good at this game. 

Although the self-sacrifice elimination works thematically in the game, I don't really like it and I find the idea a bit dated (you all still win collectively even if all the knights die but one, doesn't make sense to me) and so I don't believe Shadows would receive its acclaim if launched nowadays.  The traitor was a great original idea the designers came up with though.

I'll revisit this after playing Battestar Galactica and Dead of Winter (where killed players are reincarnated into new survivors) some more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Played twice and both games were highly enjoyable.  I won as the traitor in the first game and lost to the game in the second, so it's not an easy game to beat.  I successfully accused the traitor in the second game about 2/3 through, but post game discussions revolved around whether it's a good idea to out the traitor at all since they can take cards away from players, and even more damaging, place siege engines during their turns.  I read one article that suggests outing (assuming you know who it is) the traitor at the last moment to avoid the two black swords, which seems like a good idea.  What about as the traitor, coming out early on instead of hiding?  Can you do more damage after you're revealed placing sieges, or staying hidden (in order to stay hidden, you have to play pretty darn efficiently pretending to be a loyal player, and this only helps the loyalists)?  Regardless, this is a great game of camaraderie.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A classic design of a mostly-cooperative Euro. The saboteur is a gaming mechanic that is still hot, and it's clear that the originator of the coop traitor nailed it. Kudos also go out to Days of Wonder for an amazing job making this prototype into a stunning production. It's a beautiful game. Even 5 years after its initial printing, the game still has a presentation that would be considered top notch today. 

SoC gets a 6 from me because of the group-dependence of the title. With the right group, this game is a blast, but in contrast, this style of game could be ruined by a different atmosphere. Still, this design demands to be respected.

RATING: 7
[8 plays] This is fabulous and has become my favorite cooperative game.  I think it holds up well to repeated play, and seems to have enough diverse aspects that it isn't likely to feel like the same thing over and over.  And it has a very successful cooperative spirit, with the whole group working together to figure out who should deal with which of the many threats next, and a great thematic sense of impending doom.  Good level of difficulty--it's challenging to win, but not impossible.  It's also a beautiful game.

RATING: 3
Too lengthy for what it is, a rebadged and simplified (!) rummy. The cooperative aspects are a sham (it might as well be solitaire with multiple hands) and the traitor mechanic is weak (be subtle and only affect close games or be bold and be found out immediately). 

I suppose if the paper-thin theme really excites you, you might get some dividends on what you put in, but there are much better co-op games out there (e.g., Battlestar Galactica).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Cooperative game with attractive theme, high production quality, and very accessible for new gamers.  Very high fun factor and tension, especially towards the end!  The cooperative aspect works well, and results in a strong social component.  This game has produced some of my most fun gaming experiences ever. Having a "traitor" makes the game especially interesting, and adds a complete other dimension to the game.  

Some claim it is not ideal for consistent repeated play, except with different groups, but it has to be admitted that it is a great gateway type game and very accessible.  See this review for who will find Shadows Over Camelot appealing: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/168987

Miniatures can be painted to improve it.  I have painted all my minis - here they are still in progress:
[imageid=2926053 inline]

For those looking for a more serious gamers game with cooperative play with a higher replay value and deeper gameplay, Lord of the Rings is arguably a better choice.  

Answer to a specific rules issue about dying [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1697353#1697353]here[/url].  FAQ [url=http://www.daysofwonder.com/shadowsovercamelot/en/content/faq/?]here[/url]

Strategy note: Siege engines are key - don't let them come on the board too quickly, because 12 siege engines is usually what will trigger a loss for the knights.

RATING: 4
If I'd never found BGG and was stuck playing Settlers of Catan and Shadows Over Camelot, I wonder how long I'd last? In any case, SoC is a game like Settlers that was very fun for a while before I knew any better. Once I found better games, I moved on from each of them. In SoC's case, it was, of course, BattleStar Galactica. Playing the traitor in SoC is not nearly as interesting as it should be. You can't do much while concealed without being obvious, so you basically just play along until you decide it's best to reveal and start placing siege engines. Not the most interesting of positions. 

Otherwise, I enjoyed the cooperative aspect of the game as SoC was the most sophisticated coop I had encountered up to that point. BSG improves on the design by leaps and bounds to the point where I'd steer people that way and away from this one. Fun for a brief period, but this one's been obsoleted.

RATING: 6.625
I love, love, love:
- the tension of the push and pull between good and evil
- that the quests are pretty varied in their requirements for success and their bonuses for winning vs penalties for losing each one
- the option of a traitor, but why the heck would King Arthur possibly turn on himself/his kingdom?
- the paintable minis

I dislike:
- the Poker-style mini-games--could've been more creative for sure
- that some of the evil cards are severely punishing

Final verdict: Not a bad game, but it's not for us. Up for trade.

RATING: 5
Awesome theme and interesting game play with each knight bouncing round the board attempting 'quests' which require different card combinations.... unfortunatly the game isn't quite there for me, doesn't inspire me and make be want to play it.

There is a hidden traitor aspect, but not all that much that the traitor can do that will result in either a) them staying hidden or b) affecting the game negatively.

The game appears difficult enough without the addition of this traitor, but perhaps this was simple due to a bad shuffle.

I like that a 'bad' thing happens at the beginning of every turn however once the grail/excalibur are claimed/lost them pretty much everything adds siege engines to the board and the game becomes a complete slog.

I much prefer battlestar galactica to this for a satisfying hidden traitor game

RATING: 7
A gift from my wife on my 30th birthday. Can't wait to play this with my group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
(Language dependent - get a copy in your language). I was surprised at how well this game worked, and how much fun it was. Once you get past the rules reading, which did take a while, the game itself moves quickly. The Progression Of Evil was nicely balanced, the inevitable build-up of enemies at the gate caught me out. I was expecting a much easier ride. Our traitor lead us to a terrible defeat (you treacharous bastard Mike!), and the whole mechanisms of quests, swords, life points, accusations, siege engines all worked very smoothly. Some slight quibble of the Special Powers being a little imbalanced, but the team aspect was good and you were not forced to do as others suggested. I put this co-operative experience much higher than the Knizia LOTR, which to me seemed like a solitaire game played by several. In Shadows Over Camelot, you really have to work as a team, knowing there is a possible viper in your midst. I strongly recommend this game. The cards and rules explainations make the game heavily language dependent, and I'd set a good 3 hours aside for playing, but get this one under your belt, it's another winner from DoW.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played 5+ times. Being that this is a high-profile co-op board game, it is inevitable that it will be compared to the only other game of that type, Reiner Knizia's Lord of the Rings. The first thing I'd compare is complexity. Lord of the Rings has a fair number of little rules to remember, and so does SOC, but Shadows is just a bit easier to get the swing of and is easier to set up. LOTR tends to force the players to work closely together (which I like) while SOC allows players to do pretty much whatever they feel like doing, independant of the other players (which can also be nice) but which renders SOC less sociable and interactive. Don't get me wrong, some co-op is still needed in SOC, but not as much! Both games are good, but I feel I should address the "hype". A lot of people say SOC is much better than LOTR which I can't quite fathom. They are both interesting and unique pieces of game design, each with different strengths, but to say SOC leaves LOTR in the dust is a bit of a disservice to the gaming community. I find them nearly equal in appeal, with LOTR being more of a team game and having greater intensity, but SOC scales to higher numbers well, and is a bit easier to grasp and quicker to setup and play. After 5 playings, I believe that the short-term replayability of SOC is actually quite poor, with virtually no long-term replayability -- it is not as replayable as LOTR if you have the expansions for LOTR, and even base-game to base game, it can't compete with Lord of the Rings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
Not only was this one of the first Euro-type games (meaning not Clue) that I played, but it was the first co-op game I had ever played.  Everyone just told me what to do, and I did it, without really understanding what was going on.  I still liked it a lot.

After a 4 year break, I played it again tonight--ever so much better than I remembered.  In the last few years I have played some really excellent co-op games (Pandemic, Space Alert, Red November, Last Night on Earth, Ghost Stories, or a 5-player Fury of Dracula)and this one ranks right up there.  A really good co-op game--especially with the Traitor and the max number of people. 

On Bruno Faidutti's Best Games List.

Edit: After playing a dozen games, we never cease to have fun, always centered around who is the traitor if any.  It is really an inspiration in the game that perhaps there might not even be one.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[Hand Management, Set Collection, Cooperative, Werewolf Ripoff] [6P:4/3] One play, rating is leaning towards a 4. Maybe a 3. Depends on how bored I get next time around. Days of Wonder strikes with yet another beautifully produced shallow game. This is a card game with a superfluous (albeit beautiful) board. The playing of poker hands has no place in the Arthurian theme and thoroughly invalidates the entire atmosphere and feel of the game. What, too lazy to reconcile the mechanism to the theme? Inexcusable lack of attention to detail in terms of design. At the moment I don't see the replayability problem; I however do see a general weakness in terms of the overall design of the game. Likely will be a 3; Shadows over Camelot has no business being mentioned in the same sentence as Knizia's Lord of the Rings. ***UPDATE: Confirmed. This is a 3. Have found that Shadows over Camelot is even useless as a gateway game because newbies don't know what the heck to do when they get the Traitor card. Pass on this and get Lord of the Rings, it's a vastly superior game.

RATING: 8
Providing an entire different gaming experience, this title is mandatory in any medium size game collection.
There is great fun and sometimes some tension when partners disagree on the right strategy. The traitor factor is quite smart, keeping everyones eyes well open and alert throughout the game (accusations and false accusations are produced in abundance...)
Despite the clever gaming mechanism , the strong theme and the fantastic quality of the components, at the end you felt just having fought the game and not your partners. This element alone discourages more plays, as my gaming friends like to know who's the best at all times.

RATING: 9
Lovagos pandemic. Najó, szerencsére nem, csak ettől féltem egy kicsit. Tisztán coop módban játszva is más, mint a pandemic és ez jó. Gyönyörű a kivitelezés, hangulatos a játék. Nagyon könnyed a játékmenet, ez különösen a túlbonyolított szabály elolvasása után volt meglepő. Nem gondoltam volna, hogy egy 30+ oldalas szabállyal megáldott játékra azt fogom mondani, hogy gyakorlatilag bárki le tud ülni mellé, de ebben az esetben tényleg így van. Külön jó pont a ki és beülési lehetőség, bár nem, tudom hogy fogjuk-e valaha alkalmazni.
Egyelőre csak coop módban próbáltuk. Úgy is szórakoztató volt, de azért érezhető, hogy hamar ki lehet ismerni a játékot, és nehézségi szintek hiányában így valószínűleg nem tud hosszútávú szórakozást nyújtani. Mindenképp ki kell próbálni árulóval is, mert úgy csilloghat csak igazán.

RATING: 7
This is probably one of the most unique games I own. All players are working to defeat the board game itself! It's great with a medium sized group of 4-5. The addition of a traitor is also a lot of fun. There is nothing like making an accusation to find out you just screwed the whole team! Awesome fun, and always a party favorite. If you like the genre of knights and old English tales this is a must.

Is this a game to have in your collection:Maybe
Is this a game children can play:Maybe
Is this a good game for new gamers:Yes

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Shadows over Camelot can offer quite a bit of tension - if you take it as a story-driven experience. Unfortunately, there is little assistance from the game on this as the main mechanism is a fairly dull card collection exercise, so it becomes exceedingly group dependent.
It shares some similarities with the cooperative Lord of the Rings board game but that one runs in a fraction of the time. There is of course no traitor in LotR which is an important (yet optional) part of SoC but then again Battlestar Galactico deals with that in more interesting ways, while the treason in SoC feels very mundane and unexciting. SoC is a somewhat simpler system but still takes a good while to complete which relegates it to a rather small niche in spite of its good looks.

RATING: 9
PROS:
-El traidor da tensión al juego y anula el efecto líder
-Amplio rango de jugadores (3-7), y además permite jugar en modo 100% cooperativo con 2 ó 3 jugadores
-Se puede jugar en solitario
-El arte es genial

CONTRAS:
-Tras jugar unas cuantas partidas, se descubren trayectos a seguir y lugares a los que no compensa ir, lo que provoca repetitividad
-Con el traidor y más de 5 jugadores es extremadamente difícil ganar
-Al no haber edición en español, es necesario tener a mano traducciones de las cartas con texto para los jugadores que no dominen el inglés
-El dorso negro de las cartas negras hace imprescindible enfundarlas para evitar identificarlas a través de pequeños arañazos o marcas

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I still have not made up my mind about this game. My game group went crazy over it when first released. We played it 5 times in 2 days. They wanted to play it more. My hesitancy was whether or not we had finally "solved" it. The first 3 games were blowouts - the Shadows and its treacerous Knight overpowering Arthur's loyal Knights. However, the last two were blowouts with the White Knights blowing out the traitor, 11-1; 9-3. In both cases the Traitor was revealed. Now that we know how to win easily as the Knights, we have to develop a "Traitor" strategy. Perhaps the game will have staying power. I sure hope so. The interaction is fantastically good. Now if only the game will prove to be a tough enough competitor.

Well - it's a year later and it has lost lots of its luster with me. I find it still challenging, but not half as fun. Mainly, I don't like cooperative games. I find it's more of a cooperative puzzle than competition. I love to compete and "win" a game. And when I win, I want it to be against a living, breathing person, not a system. Nevertheless, it's still not a bad game. AND, the ladies in our group have recently fallen in love with it and are playing it 2-3 times a week! They beat it last night with 7 players and NO traitor. I'm still ambivilant toward it. I don't mind playing it, but it's not in my top 10 list. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Awesome game, great mechanics...who's the traitor?  ANYONE?

Wonder about longevity, especially within the same group....we will see after more playings.  Have dropped rating from 9 to 8 after three playings.


EDIT:  Now down to 7.0.  Still like the game, just some of the shine has worn off.

EDIT:  Played this again where I didn't get stuck on the grail quest--MUCH more enjoyable.  I hate the Grail quest!  You feel much more like you're participating in the game when you're helping with lots of different things.  Bumping rating up, I have a newfound liking for the game again.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Shadows over Camelot is a game that entirely depends on the those playing.  it offers a cooperative gaming experience with a rich theme.  There are flaws in Camelot which can be fatal to the design, but most happen with lackluster play leading into too much card information shared between players.  If players are willing to "play" along then Shadows can really be a wonderful gaming experience, and just slightly behing LotR for cooperative play.  The addition of a posible traitor makes all games a little more tense, as suspicious eyes roam the table and false accusations come with heavy cost.  Critics will pan this game for basically being play cards on tasks repeat.  However, the assurance that with each black event draw the ongoing tasks will get harder and some will need attention more than others actually leads to some interesting decisions within the group.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Holy sweet mother, what a compelling, different game we have here!  Unlike other games in my collection, it's collaborative - with a twist.  Has elements of Fury of Dracula in that people work together against a "bad guy", but in this game, you don't know the identity of the traitor.  In fact, you don't know at all if there is a traitor.  The neverending feeling of impending doom makes for a great atmosphere.  I wonder, though, if this game is possible to win.  Only played once - let's see if it ages well!

Starting to wonder what it will take to win at this game.  Last game, the win felt like it was in the bag, but at the last moment, the siege engines overran us. 

Feels like the only way to win is as the traitor!

I'm definitely getting a little tired of this game.  Too many plays too quickly!

The longer I am away from this game, the greater my urge is to play it.

a nice questing like coop(or semi coop with a variant) game based on the classic king Arthur letterature. players are honourable and skilled knight(the famous ones from the legends)with eventually king Arthur himself, who tries to repell all sort of invaders and famous villains and enemies of Camelot avoiding the destruction of the court and the reign. this game features a card sistem that represents the military forces that follows the knights or their own strenghts. a very good game for 3 to 7 players

RATING: 7.5
WOW! Is all I can say.  Fun, exciting, and mildly stressful.  Time flew by.  For me it was the hit of Gencon2006.  Borrowed a copy for a few weeks over Christmas break and it was a good time. I introduced this to my wife, some friends and our kids (no traitor.)  Wife still does not enjoy it as much as others have.  Her primary complaint is "there is too much going on at once."  I think everyone else had a great time and said they wished to play it again.  I let everyone work out their own turn but this game did have moments of collective analysis paralysis.  Lots of interesting (hard) lessons to be learned by adolescents (or anyone for that matter): being prepared, sharing, picking your battles, sacrifice, teamwork and synergy as survival traits.
Update: After a year this game, it is wearing a bit thin.  With seven it is taking forever with experienced players.  Near the end the "bossyness" in some players comes out, and the traitor is always the slowest of all players.  The last few of games have been unrewarding.  Perhaps it is a fun game to learn... but not play... does that make sense? It is now on my wife's refuse to play list; her complaint now is that "it really doesn't feel like a game."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A decent game for certain groups (preferably 6 or 7 players) that are predisposed to enjoy a light, cooperative game.  It doesn't deserve the bashing many give it, because as Bill Parcells (paraphrased) might say, "It is what it is."

RATING: 7.5
Juego semicooperativo -es decir, cooperativo con traidor- que ha sido superado por títulos posteriores, como Galáctica. Sin embargo, le sigo teniendo aprecio y disfruto jugándolo. Quizás sea por la atractiva temática de las leyendas artúricas y por su cuidadísimo aspecto gráfico.

Las mecánicas del juego son sencillas y funcionan perfectamente. Ganar no es demasiado complicado si los jugadores usan la cabeza (hay reglas para endurecer la dificultad). El papel del traidor es importante, pero lo cierto es que en este juego tiene menos margen de maniobra que en otros, por lo que su influencia en el resultado final se verá algo limitada.

RATING: 6
Shadows Over Camelot is a beautifully produced game with an attractive theme. My husband and I love many cooperative games, but we just don't like how this one feels while we are playing it. Because a black card is drawn every turn and can apply to any of six different quests, we feel like we are always in the wrong place and have the wrong white cards. We don't like the feeling  of falling further and further behind with every turn. I am rating the game a 6 because I recognize the good qualities of the design; it's just not for us.

RATING: 4
The first half of my first game approached the margins of "entertaining," but I will actively avoid a second game.  Especially when we could play the masterful Lord of the Rings instead.  There are simply too few meaningful choices, and too little variety in the decisionmaking.  You travel to a quest and then spend several turns mindlessly cranking away, laying down the required cards.  Progress is so sluggish and incremental that players are more likely to feel mild malaise than tense excitement.  The lavish Days of Wonder production is not enough to win my affection.

RATING: 5.5
This is a fun coopertive game in the same mode as LoTR.  However, I never feel like I'm enjoying the game as much as I should be.  One of the frustrating things is to have to spend a turn moving to/from a quest.  When I've already sat through a number of other people's turns, it's frustrating to do so little on my own turn and then have to wait again.  In LoTR communication is encouraged, so I usually feel like I'm a part of anyone's turn, Shadows has a vaguely defined limit on table talk, so I don't feel anywhere near as engaged.
I haven't played with more than 4 players, or with a traitor, so perhaps my rating would increase if/when that happens.

With the group I play with there's a certain formula we use that either works (when there's no traitor) or doesn't (when there is). That's taken some of the fun out of it... still a quality game though.

RATING: 6
I agree with comments saying this is a card game played with a board rather than a board game but that is neither here nor there in my opinion. I love the theme and I love the miniaturess you get in the game. Certainly it's visually stunning. I can see how people are commenting that it lacks replayability and can get repetitive but for me that's probably not an issue as I only play games twice a week and have a vast array available so it's not likely I'll be overplaying any one game at all.

I do like cooperative games and as mentioned I love the theme so this one is a winner with me. It doesn't require huge amounts of thought as your best course of action is usually fairly obvious from the cards in your hand but that suits my usually gaming group who are more into games that are either thematic and visual or fairly simple.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game ticks a lot of boxes for me... It's semi-co-operative, with a traitor mechanism (a la [gameid=9220], only in a much more lavish game). The Arthurian theme is really good, and opens the door to lots of fun with quotes from Monty Python and the Holy Grail. 
The overall mechanism is pretty straightforward card play, using ideas taken from poker and the like, however the black and white cards are an excellent idea, as is the idea of balancing bad and good actions each turn.
There is also the whole metagame of working out who is the traitor, with plenty of table talk encouraged.

Have played this over 20 times now... occasionally with 3 or 4 players and no traitor, but more often with up to 7 players (and 8 sometimes with the Merlin expansion)... and it is an incredible game.


I actually bought the set of painted knights from Days of Wonder before Christmas (2005), hoping to get the game either for Christmas, or purchase it afterwards... Actually got 2 copies for Christmas, though my brother exchanged his one for Railroad Tycoon.

RATING: 2
Really nice components, especially when painted, but : Played twice, and bored to death both times. Use one card from your hand, then turn over an enemy story card. Repeat over and over again. 
We thought the traitor would make the game more interesting, but you are not allowed to act the best ways to win as traitor, because the rules and designers think that would be destrucive game play :) Instead you have to be nice to your opponents and not block the most valuable positions. 
Even worth is the idea to include roleplaying style. You are not to ask for a number 2 card. Instead you ask for a weak army, or a very weak army if you need a number 1 card. Guess what: 3 is a medium army, and 4 and 5 are (very) strong cards :) And the rules tell you to talk like a noble knight.
Age should be 10- (minus not plus) or 12- a great game for little kids, that love playing knights.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This has had replay over years at game gatherings at our house. The "hidden traitor" mechanic makes it a hit with (at least) the early teen crowd. And the challenge of winning makes it replayable over and over.

The most enjoyable aspect of the game seems to be characters and the roles. That may be down to the kind of friends my kids bring over, but it's a definite draw.

The only down side to this is that the girls who come over do feel left out because the only ladies in the game are either evil or very tangential. I'm not arguing for the sort of changes that Peter Jackson made to LotR to be "up to date" with modern audiences --- heaven forbid! But it is a factor in gameplay enjoyment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
The game is beautifully produced, but in essence it is a card game in disguise, as the various boards only serve to provide some info on the quests and placeholders for the cards. Player actions are very simple, and there is a number of decisions on which quests to pursue, which evil to suffer or when to use the Merlin cards. However, the gameplay is too abstract to be engaging, and it never feels very strategic or deep. Most of the time, the players' hands or special powers set the best course of action. It's mildly fun to try to figure out who might be the traitor, but the probability of having one at the table is the only thing that scales with the number of players, causing the difficulty level to vary from game to game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The rules for this game try to solve the usual defect of coop games (experienced players ordering around inexperienced players a puppets) by forcing player to keep their cards secret from one another. In practice, this is a difficult taboo to enforce. Players will still naturally try to communicate the strength of their hands by using vague language ("I'd be good for this quest"), and the inability to accurately express card quality gets compensated by a lot more discussion, using aggravatingly fuzzy terms. ("I just put down a tough card, but not a really tough card. It's not as bad as the last one I put down, but it's still worse than average", etc, etc)

The production standards are high, and it's close enough to being a Euro that you can sell it to non-geeks who would flinch when offered something with dice and armies. I recommend it as a compromise game that suits a number of tastes, though none perfectly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great game. Successful with every group I have played it with. One of the only games where people can jump in and out if needed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was my first big box game. I wasn't sure what a co-operative game would be like but after learning it I just love it. Have played it with 2 to 4 players and each has its own dynamic. I really love this game. The artwork is stunning too. Very clever game.

RATING: 6
Played once. Seemed better in some regards than Lord of the Rings (another grand scale cooperative game) especially because of the possible existence of a traitor. Thematically, certain parts seemed a little strange. Sorry, Camelot is under attack by 11 catapults, but I need to travel far into the woods to fight a single knight, apparently because he is wearing black armor. Even so, for the most part, it was a fun balancing act of how much to commit to the various parts of the game all the while considering who was about to stab you in the back.

The comment above is from 2007. I played again in 2016 and felt that this game has largely been outshined by later released. Battlestar Galactica and Dead of Winter are two that come to mind that are generally stronger than this one.

If you like cooperative games this is the one for you. Can support a lot of players. Great for the board game enthusiast family. The traitor adds quite a bit of flavor to the game too. Make sure to have some experience before you add him. It can be easier than you think to lose. Don't give evil an inch if you can help it. 
Art is beautiful. Theme is fun and is carried out wonderfully through the games mechanics.

RATING: 9
This game can run kind of long for the gameplay involved, but it's still a fun.  The traitor mechanic makes you keep guessing who is good or evil the whole game because you don't know why someone went on that quest or why the keep laying face down cards.  Only game I know of that still plays well (not perfect) if joining the game late or leaving the game early.  Best in larger groups with guaranteed traitor (2 if you're a pro).  Expansion is fun, but not necessary.

RATING: 6
The first time I played this, we played it as a straight co-operative game, with no Traitors.  That was a relief, because we barely survived to win the game!  With potential traitors, we would have wasted too much time second-guessing each other to win.

I think this works well as a challenging co-op game.  But on the whole, I prefer Pandemic.  I don't like it that a player can lose all their life points and thus be out of the game; in Pandemic, everybody lives or dies at the same time, so it's truly co-operative until the end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Played over 40 times.

Played with 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 players.  The game scales really well, not to mention players can enter or leave the game at any time, thus removing the need of running a filler while waiting for late arrivals.

In order to experience this game at its fullest, it is critical one aderes to the rules in that no specific information is provided.  General comments are fine, but no details can be provided.  Thus, "I can fight the Dragon but cannot defeat it" means that a player can play some cards but does not have all the cards required to win that Quest, thus help is needed.  What kind of help? (i.e. which cards?)  That's what can't be told.

The game can be difficult to win without a traitor, and can quickly become impossible to win when there is a traitor in your midst.  You must observe every player's actions in order to see if there is indeed a traitor.

During the "Progression of Evil" phase, the player has to choose between three options, all of which are bad, so picking the one which is least damaging to your cause can be nail biting!

When playing the Knight's action phase, you must try to maximize your EVERY move.  One wasted move can have nasty consequences.

Selflessness goes a long way as it can help another Knight, who in turn may be able to help you.

Since the priority of the different quests varies from game to game, there is a lot of replay value in here!  Each Knight's special ability mixes things up even more.

An awesome game!  Kudos to DoW for another winner!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I never feel like I have interesting decisions to make in this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[Initial Impression: 7]
I really enjoy the collaborative aspect of this game, as does everyone I've played it with (some of whom initially said, "What, no winner - how can that be fun?").  It is especially appealing for occasional gamers and friendly groups. Without a traitor, the game can be quickly "solved" (after 2 or 3 plays) by learning which quests to complete and which to allow to fail.  However, the traitor adds excitement and mystery to the game (especially since different players have different traitorious styles). The highlights of play include the mindgames and traps set by loyal players who are all suspicious of one another, the moment when the traitor is finally revealed and the resulting race to recover from the sabotage.

This cooperative game is a lot of fun.  Everyone is a knight of the Round Table and you work together to complete quests. RATING: 9
11-12-12
I had to lower this one to a 9.  Over time, I've found that this game even with Merlin's Company doesn't hold up against Pandemic with On The Brink.  The traitor mechanic is interesting, but games like Battlestar Galactica handle it more elegantly.  This is still a fantastic co-op game with being easy to teach and play, as well as heavily thematic.  Though as a fellow gamer pointed out, you often don't have a lot of choices on a turn and the strategy becomes pretty obvious.  The games don't tend to flow much differently, so each experience is relatively the same, and if you omit the traitor element, it can be downright easy and rather boring if the cards fall in your favor.

Still, it's the only game I have that can provide the tenseness of a traitor element and play in under 90 minutes.  It does provide an alternative to Pandemic, but I cannot give them both a 10.  This one has to fall, despite still greatly enjoying the game.

RATING: 7
This is a visually attractive game, and is in the rare category of cooperative games.  I like the theme and ease of play.  It encourages a healthy dose of Monty Python quotes and rants! 

The down side is a difficulty to balance witheld information with shared information, and the feeling that the cards sets are just a variation on Rummy.  Also, like many cooperatives, you feel that it is entirely luck driven.  When (If) you are the traitor, you find your actions to be innefective, and your strategy difficult.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The traitor mechanic makes the game. Otherwise, the (other) mechanics (put a card on the board, flip over a card...wait...wait...wait...rinse-and-repeat) are not particularly enthralling. That said, I'm a total sucker for semi-cooperative games.

BSG does a much better job of giving the traitor more interesting things to subversively hinder the team. However, one great thing about Shadows is that there is a lot more motivation for the traitor to stay hidden the whole game, which in my experience leads to more instances of tense late-game situations in which winning or losing actually depends on uncovering the identity of the traitor. BSG, on the other hand, loses some of its luster when all the cylons are revealed.

RATING: 7
(11/08/2008) Retrospective comment: First play at a wedding reception party. First time playing a cooperative game--extremely fascinating and tense. All 7 players were newbies, so one of them didn't know how to play the traitor. So good that we all played it again. I would buy the game for myself, a year later.

(02/11/2012) Comment after owning the game for several years and a few plays.

With really cool bits, superb production values, and accessible game play, Days of Wonder has been consistent with the quality of their games. Shadows Over Camelot has intrigue, tension, and immersion in the theme. Although it has extremely simple rules--there are only two steps, with a limited number of actions in each step, it is easy for the newbie to get bogged down in analysis paralysis. With seven players, there's plenty of tension, but the speed of play drops considerably with new players.  Unfortunately, after ten or so plays, the game's appeal starts to wane, as it is seemingly easy to figure out the game (or perhaps the traitor wasn't doing his job correctly? -- a common problem with new players) for experienced players, and there seems to be too much downtime for such a simple game. But that's just me. I don't mind introducing players to the game, but I'd like a more meaty challenge. Because it is a cooperative game, it is prone to "follow the leader" syndrome, where the experienced player can hijack the game. For the uninitiated, it can be very cool experience trying to defeat the game, or just trying to survive it. But after having owned the game for some time now, I have never been able to re-experience the wonder and excitement of my very first game. As they say, you can never go home. It's a "7".

Update (02/04/2011): Sold! SoC has found a happy home with a family with five children! Looks like they will love this!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
Nice game.  This seems overwhelming at first, but its actually very simple to play.  IMO, its best with 5+ people since each knight has different special skills.  Having access to these opens up strategies and tactics which is important since each player essentially gets one action per turn.  Adding the element of a (potential) traitor really adds an otherwise missing dynamic that makes the game edgy.  In the game are several quests which must, can, or should be completed.  Some are repeatable.  Each knight will choose a quest to go on and rewards are received for their completion.  Some quests can only be performed solo while most allow, if not demand more knights participate.  Knights have cards and skills to help accomplish each quest and this is where each knight's skill can facilitate completion of the quests.  Oh, and all the time, bad things are happening around Camelot so choosing to go on or stay on a quest will make all the difference. The components are really nice and the board and cards are well printed.  I have played several sessions but since each time it usually involves new players, we dont use the traitor card. I'm still waiting for it to hit the table with all who know gameplay.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Plays well between 5 to 7 players. Beautiful game pieces, excellent artwork and rich Arthurian theme. Rarely does a boardgame handle so many players as well as this. It has low downtime between player turns keeping everyone occupied. It builds tension equally for all players starting slow then building to a big finish (win or lose). A definite recommendation for anyone looking for a 5+ players game to add to their library.

Would be a great candidate for a Warhammer 40k / Star Wars  re-theme!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the best coop game for large groups. Really fast turns, and lots of table talk. It`s an old game, but still fun to play. Great experience, one of the very few coop games that can sit up to 8 people (with the expansion). 

An interesting fact about the game is that people can jump in and out. If the group is already playing and someone just arrived, no problem, pick a knight and join the fight or just exit if you have to go, really cool concept.

RATING: 4
After one game, I loved this.  It was my first cooperative game, and I thought it worked really well.  After a few more plays, though, it got boring very quickly.  You don't have many choices about what to do on your turn.  Games with a traitor seemed like they'd be fun, but in practice it was frustrating trying to figure out we were doing so poorly, and if someone was playing badly or actively working against us.  If I'm looking for a cooperative game I'd much rather play Arkham Horror.

RATING: 6.5
Initial rating after 5 plays - 8: A great Co-op game with the possibility of a traitor makes for tense play and accusation flying around. After playing games like Dead of Winter and Battlestar Galactica, Shadows can(at least for me) feel too "basic," but it's simplicity makes it hit the table more often since it doesn't take 20-30 minutes to explain the rules('cough' Arkham Horror! 'cough')

Still a solid game, and one people really enjoy. 

Updated rating "6.5": after continual play this game has fallen from grace for me. 1 action per turn is just not exciting enough for a co-op in this day and age. Yes I understand the game is over a decade old, but it has not aged well in comparison to what else is out there. Still it's a great game to get new players to learn Co-op and hidden traitor mechanism, even if it's in its most basic form

RATING: 6
First played September 13th, 2007.  There are a lot of options, so the explaination takes a while.  (heck we were still going over the rules and looking them up as we were finishing the game)  Two players had played it once before and explained it.  We played this as a 7 player game which was fun, however after an hour, it really started to wear down.  It took about two hours to play.  It was my first coperation game (that I recall) which was interesting in itself.  It seems to play pretty well after you've all played it once.  For what it was, it seemed to have a good balance of strategy and luck.  Arthur turned out to be the traitor which seemed to make it hard on the rest of us.  I'd give this consideration in playing if you know someone who has it.  Based on the length of time it takes and the complexity you may not want to purchase or play on a regular basis.  If you do play, try playing with 4 or 5.  DOn't play with the max unless everyone has played before.

RATING: 5
Wow, I really liked this game in a guilty pleasure sorta way.  I thought all the decisions left up to a player were very meaningful and that the atmosphere was quite tense and uncertain.  Keep in mind my rating is based off of one playing and that I have been warned that the game has a propensity to sour.  Regardless, I'm salivating for another run at those dastardly Picts and that unsavory Black Knight!  Of course I also feel obligated to make the compulsory praise of component quality.  Days of Wonder really does the boardgaming industry a great service with its high standard of quality.

Update:  This game has fallen out of favor with a few more playings, one as the traitor.  I think the decisions you make are only meaningful in an illusionistic superficial way.  There is way too much downtime and the game is far too easy.  To win as the traitor, the loyal knights have to already be so very close to the verge of no return so as to be able to tip the scales enough for defeat.  SoC is 90% flash wrapped around a boardgame with pretty bits.  Flash, unfortunately, always wears off.

RATING: 9
To me, Shadows over Camelot is one of the best cooperative boardgame on my list. Unlike other cooperative games, Shadows over Camelot is not steered by a single player so-called the leader. Because of the existence of a spy, players cannot trust each other. The chain of command ,which is the weakest point in coopertive games, is not working in this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ideal Players: 4-6

Description: Protect Camelot from many dangers while completing noble quests. Cooperate with other players to beat a difficult game.

Pro: Great cooperative gameplay. Difficulty can be changed using the traitor. The mechanics play well with the theme. The motivation expansion adds extra flavor and variation.

Con: Must be played in-character to prevent open sharing of information. Too hard with less than 4.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A fantastic cooperative game, and really the one that sold me on the genre.

Most every other (highly rated) cooperative game fell flat for me in that they just seemed to be glorified solitaire games that didn't really require other players to be present (I'm looking at YOU Pandemic), but this one escaped that trend due to a few key features: hidden information, restricted communication, and the potential for a traitor. Given these elements, the game truly requires good teamwork in order to be able to succeed, and is a blast in doing so. We made a house rule that all communication between knights must be done in one's faux "old english" speech and that makes otherwise potentially mundane discourse absolutely HYSTERICAL. We always have a great time with this game. 

I also like how well-balanced the game is. With some rare exceptions, every game we win feels tense and down to the wire, and each game we lose feels like we were oh-so-close. I love that, and it makes for a very satisfying experience, win or lose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very good game. Terrific components. One of the nicest things is the cooperativeness and the introduction of the traitor.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

I always seem to be the traitor.

RATING: 7.5
Being a huge fan of mythology (especially Arthurian) I knew I had to have this game.  I love it.  I understand the game suffers when overplayed as the best way to win is shown, but as I play this one as a treat for something different, the optimal path hasn't appeared to me yet.

This game is more enjoyable if the Traitor is subtle about it.  If they are just seige-engine, try Lancelot's armor, repeat, etc... then it is not as fun.  If the game is 5 White swords, 5 Blacks swords, a final quest to do and no one knows if there is a traitor or not, then this is a blast!

RATING: 7.3
People's Choice Top 2012 #41
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Cooperative game that may have one traitor character. For me, the most similar to this game is Battlestar Galactica: the game has many fronts that have to be fulfilled in order to win, which makes the game difficult by itself, but with the addition of the traitor, that should await for the perfect moment to fulfill his/her betrayal, the difficulty increases to a higher level.
Positive:
1. Difficult
2. Not as long as Battlestar Galactica
3. The missions that have to be fulfilled are very interesting
Negative:
1. Not always is there a traitor on the game (an in-house rule can solve that)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Traitor is an excellent idea and make this game better (always play with traitor) although it makes very very difficult to win for loyal knights.

RATING: 7
A great co-op game very similiar to LOTR where you are playing against the game however here there is the possibility of a traitor. This adds a great twist and some tension to the game but I am surprised how little impact it actually has. Maybe I need to play more but so far I'm not a big fan of these types.

Update: Played a 2nd game 7 years later. It would seem unmasking the traitor is a mistake, since now he can openly hurt you, and randomly remove one good card each turn ALSO which can really sting, one sword does not seem like a good enough payment for this. I’m not sure how much an undercover traitor can really accomplish anyway, we might be missing something here but it looks like letting them pretend they are good is the way to go?Either way, certainly one of the first good co-ops to really hit the market.

RATING: 3
if i would rate according to the fun factor of my first game, it would deserve a solid 1. (playing the traitor in a 7 player game)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Cooperative game, where players represent knights of the Round Table, solving quests and fighting invaders in an attempt to beat the game system.

Unlike Knizia's LOTR I just don't find SOC to be terribly exciting. With many players, the traitor mechanism provides some excitement, but the downtime is excessive. With few players, downtime is not much of a problem, but now the traitor mechanism doesn't work well.

Balance questions aside, the game is just not very exciting to play, and players are not required to do a lot of decision-making. Personally, I much prefer Knizia's LOTR.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Acquired 2009-06-13
Traded away 2011-09-24
Re-acquired 2012-09-22
Sold 2013-10-17

We played with a full array of players - and no traitor! The traitor mechanic is one that I find appealing, but what I feel is less appealing is how players aren't allowed to directly share their hand... but can pretty much say what it is without calling it. It feels like I'd be trying to describe a small living thing with shortish hair that goes "meow"... what's the point when I can call it a cat?

Anyway, I like the variety of quests, the specialization that players must agree on, and I'm looking forward to playing it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
2013-03-18

Initial Rating: 6.0 (August 2012)

I was not disappointed in the game as I really don’t like any Days of Wonder game out there. 

This game is gorgeous, but as most Days of Wonders game, the gameplay is too shallow for my tastes. The theme is great but, sadly, the mechanics are very boring. You don’t have interesting decisions to make, after you go for a quest you don’t need to think anymore in many turns. 

After a second play I realize this game is no fun for me, I enjoy the first couple of turns and then the game feels samey and boring to me. The only thing remotely fun is the traitor mechanic before he reveals (or is caught) himself as there is finger pointing and shouting (and that doesn’t apply to all games as there can be no traitor). For all these reasons I’m downgrading its rating to a 3.0. I will resist further plays of Shadows over Camelot but I can be convinced if there is no other option :D.

My favorite mechanic is hidden roles, but if I want to play something with it, I would play Battlestar Galactica if I have time or The Resistance if I don´t. For me Shadows over Camelot is a bad game, but (as most Days of Wonders games) can be great to attract new gamers to our beloved hobby.

Current Rating: 3.0

RATING: 4
Overproduced card game.  Only interesting due to the traitor element but that needs to be played right or its just an exercise in group card-hand management (Like LOTR....)/ Happily gave it away to someone who wanted it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the first games to introduce the traitor mechanic and thus, is iconic for that reason alone.  The poker/card playing mechanic is slightly odd as implemented and the opportunities for sabotage by the traitor are fairly obvious and limited by the actual mechanics of the game. Overall is fun, but I believe is held in high regard for its influence on board gaming and not necessarily the game itself.

RATING: 7.5
Played a couple of games now with 4 and 5.  A clever game that I think is best described as "Every turn something bad happens, and you have to stop it through playing cards, unless you are a traitor.  Basically there is a 'death clock' that you don't want to strike midnight."  It's interesting being the traitor although it feels passive in doing things sub-optimally and trying to find an active way to screw things up.  The reveal can be pretty good though on whether someone is the traitor or not.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2013-03-31 - This is a great game. I know some people think BSG took the mechanic and did it better, but the theme here is more universally appealing. It's difficult enough as a cooperative game that sometimes it feels like overkill to include the possibility of a traitor, but that's when the game really shines. There's so much to do on any given turn, that whatever you decide, someone is going to disagree with you and suspect that you're a traitor. The paranoia starts early, and colors every turn. So much fun.

2017-11-06 - I still like this game, but it suffers a bit with a lot of plays. The secret to being the traitor seems to be just play like a good guy and then reveal at the end for the 2 sword penalty. Still a great gateway game, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I am a fan of cooperative games and this one deserves it place in my collection, alongside Pandemic, Lord of the Rings and Defenders of the Realm.  

The distinction here is that one player may be a traitor.  However this is managed very well and does not ruin the game.  Firstly there is a chance that everyone is loyal!  Secondly you actually have to help the knights even if you are a traitor - you simply have to help them as little as possible without being obvious. Thirdly you cannot accuse someone until later in the game so the beginning of the game still has the entire group ostensibly united. It can be a little tricky being the traitor as a new player but otherwise I can't fault it. 

The game's theme is its biggest drawcard.  Who wouldn't want a King Arthur game in their collection?  Second comes the cooperative gameplay. The opportunities for individual heroism on behalf of the round table are bountiful; the opportunities for collective teamwork are just as obvious.  

I have also played the expansion and it seems to be everything you could want from an expansion.  However I just want the base game at this stage.          
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of the meanest games out there. I love/hate it and yet I always find myself drawn to playing it. Like I actually have a chance at winning against it. The only win we have had was not really a win. It's like you have to cheat to win at this game.

RATING: 4
Lots of elements to the game. Easy to play. Seems like [b]stuff gets done too slowly[/b]. Interesting how the traitor element works. Hard to play the traitor and not get caught. Gameplay seems almost too simplistic, reducing the ability for a player to make a great strategic move.

Mostly seems backwards due to the catapult element. You have to spend a whole turn attempting to defeat a catapult. And then you HAVE to do a negative thing (place down a catapult) or waste a Merlyn and your turn. Just seems like too much negativity for this game, not enough progress.

It's still decent for cooperative efforts and questioning other player's agenda.

RATING: 5.5
I'm hot and cold on this game.  Cooperative games isn't my favorite genre by any means and this one, traitor or not, fits solidly in that category.  Every game felt very samey to me; we do our best to find the grail but ultimately fail, we accomplish some smaller missions, but slowly the catapults fill up and we lose.  The traitor can't really do that much damage because they are forced to contribute cards regardless of what they do.  Even if they put 1 cards down on the Black Knight usually we are able to beat him.  I am even less likely to suggest this game now that Police Precinct has come out and implements the traitor aspect so much better than this game does.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the first widely known board games with a traitor element and still one of the best. 

I've played with people who thought that there was too little you could do as a traitor without being blatantly obvious. I disagree with them. The game just requires you to be more subtle when playing the traitor. And even playing along nicely (and just not to the best of your abilites) can do the trick for you as the traitor when the game ends and you can flip the white swords because you managed to make everybody believe that there is no traitor in the game.

RATING: 3
I was really looking forward to this game from the comments and reviews, but when we played it with 7 players it just didn't seem to work very well.  I think it may just have been my expectations going in - I was expecting some sort of RPG-like game where the knights gained better powers and skills as the game progressed.  Instead it seemed fairly helter-skelter in that all the quests were going on at the same time and after we rushed out to win the grail quest the despair cards kept adding catapults (our catapult die rolling was horrid, too - mostly 7s and 8s); we ended up losing after the special black card Morgan caused 4(!) catapults to come out in one turn even though all 9 swords on the table at the time were white.  It's possible I just expected different things and didn't have a strategy going in that made me not enjoy this game as much.  I'd be willing to give it one more shot, but it was definitely not what I was expecting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After a bunch of plays now (many losses :( ) I can safely rate this game.  Forget what you read regarding "solitaire" and "the game plays itself, you just follow along".
If you have fun with it, try just a little to roleplay a bit, and have a good group of friends, this game is truly magnificient.  Difficult, if played strictly by the rules and not too much "chatter".  But winnable with a good group of selfless pals.
One minor detraction is that, if played by veterans, and played selflessly, the game could be "solvable".
Currently 12 plays and a learning game.  Will update to see if it holds up after another 10 plays or so.
Fun as all hell.
Updated 9/05:  Another few plays: Dropped by 1/2 point or so, as some of the shine has worn off.  Still fantastic, but after this many plays has gotten a tad repetative.  Overall still excellent.
Updated 7/06: After a hiatus due to small burn-out on SOC, I played again.  Still quite fun, but must emphasize how important it is to play with the "right" group...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There's never too many co-ops around. The quests are great, and the "Traitor-amongst-the-players" was introduced first time for me by this very game. The only real minus is the fact, that there isn't much to do for the traitor after his cover has been blown. This game had to be done, so that "BSG" achieved that level of awesomeness it did... :D Is quite fast compared to the more slower gameplay of "BSG", so it will propably still get many plays despite the fact, that "BSG" is out. At least I like it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Salieri-like, this game has survived to see itself become extinct. The timers (sorry, quests) are of much less inherent interest than they are in BSG because in BSG, at least there's more than one strategy to raise your food/morale/etc., whereas here, it's move, get cards, move, spend a card, move, get cards, again and again, ad nauseum... 

I wanted to like this, but it's just too slow. You don't get to do enough every round, and not in a Martin Wallace way, more in a holy-shit-I-just-waited-half-an-hour-to-move-one-space way. The choices may occasionally be consequential but they're usually determined via groupthink, as per Pandemic. 

These various problems could've been addressed in an expansion. They could've given you two actions and given you more choices of what to do with each, or allowed you to either move and act or just act. There had to be a way of making it work. Surely DoW has a few people who've played BSG, right? Itself a far-from-perfect game, but one that gives you a great social experience instead of neat mechanics? But sadly, it seems from a cursory reading of the rules that all the expansion does is fiddle with one of the timers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like it, but it got too easy after a while, which limited the replayability of it.  That combined with a personal rule against using loyalty cards if anyone has never played before, means we almost never play with a traitor, and even if we do, we generaly have a problem that all he needs to do to make the game nigh unwinnable is keep placing catapults.  Fun but unbalanced in one direction or another.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Like many people looking at this game, I was hoping that SoC can replace Battlestar Galactica for us, which we've been playing for years now.

The game is simply too short, therefore limiting your options. There's barely enough time for one, perhaps two trips somewhere to fulfil an objective or fight a monster, or you'll spend half of the game battling with siege engines on the board while other heroes fight dragons, how exciting... After which the game is over, leaving you with a feeling that you haven't really contributed or achieved much. 

BSG lets you do something every move, your turn or not. Adding cards to skill checks, passing executive orders, making decisions as the admiral or president or simply arguing with everybody about the best next move. Playing SoC be prepared to sit for 10 minutes waiting for your turn just to remove a couple of siege engines from the board and move on to another player.

A huge disappointment.

[LUP 07-Nov-2006]I quite like it for occasional play, but I don't get the feeling I would want to play it often or own it.  Melissa wanted to own it though ;-)

RATING: 8
I just bought this game a few weeks ago and our group has already played it 5 times. We all really enjoy the game, but we haven't been able to play with more than 5 people. So far, the traitor has been identified in every game and it really reduced his usefulness. If you have a group that is willing to play by the rules and stick to the spirit of the game (e.g. don't disclose cards in hand and play the traitor covertly) then the game is fantastic. 

I really like how this game works to prevent one player from quarterbacking. Each player is able to make his own actions and the other players are just going to have to trust their decisions. 

Can't say enough about this game. It belongs in everyone's collection.

RATING: 9
Keeping
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
- 4-7 player
- Weight: Medium
- Genre: Cooperative + Traitor
- Length: Medium-Long

Have trouble trusting your friends/family? If not, you will after playing this game. Playing with a traitor is likely but you never know who it is and if you want any hope of winning, you'll figure it out. Just to mess with you though, there will occasionally be games without a traitor. This game disguises fairly basic gaming actions (play cards in a set or a run) with a fun medieval theme hunt for the grail, defend against the Picts and Saxons, fight Lancelot, obtain Excalibur, etc). The game can be quite difficult to win, especially with fewer people and even more so with a traitor, but when working together is definitely possible. But who can be trusted?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The Good: My current all time favorite co-op or mostly co-op game. Can also be fun played with the traitor with the right crowd. The components are great. Winning is a BIG challenge, which is good as that gets it more table time.

The Bad: The rules are very long. However, it can be explained in a reasonable time. You have to be VERY careful in explaining the traitor rules, as once the traitor is chosen, he cannot ask questions without revealing himself. A special reference card really is needed for this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
NLD
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Magyarítva

Kooperatív játék a javából, ahol vállvetve küzdötök Camelot megvédéséért. A Pendragon legenda alapvető elemei (Lancelot, Grál, Arthur, kard, Merlin, Morgena stb.) fellelhetők a játékban.

A játékot közepesen nehéz kategóriába sorolnám, nem a hardcore gémerek kooperatív játéka az biztos, inkább családi vagy lazább baráti társaságba ajánlom, ahol azért a szokásos party játékokon kívül többre vágynak és esetleg végre nem egymás ellen küzdenének a győzelemért.

Mindenképp be lehet szippantani ezzel a játékkal embereket a komolyabb társasjátékok világába.

A játék nehezíthető a traitor játékmóddal, ahol 1 vagy 2 játékos is a "közös érdek" ellen fordulhat segítve a gonosz győzelmi esélyeit egészen Camelot pusztulásáig.

Aki hasonló, de erősebb, gémerebb játékot keres, annak a Battlestar Galactica ajánlott (5+ fővel az igazi).

RATING: 8
