=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
All I ever ask of this game is that it doesn't make me play the traitor. I mean, hey, I play it when I want to play a cooperative game. Forcing me to only pretend to cooperate takes the fun out of it for me. But otherwise, whee! One knock is that this can be a hard game to explain - a player pretty much needs to know all the options and all the board areas and the traitor rules and everything before starting, and it is a lot of explaining.

Other knock: This stupid game almost always makes me the traitor. What did I do to deserve that, I wonder. Had to drop my rating because of that, and because I always seem to wind up in a game with at least a couple of players who just take too long on their turns. Turns should be lightning fast, decisions are rarely difficult, but when you have other people who just can't do the thing that they are clearly going to do without first staring at everything for 2 minutes...well, you wind up waiting 5 minutes for your 10-second turn, and that's plain boring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've played twice, and had fun both times.  But I don't need to own this, and can see how it would get stale quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

Sadly, once you work out a good strategy, it isn't as difficult to beat as it first seems.  We won after 3 plays, and the fun goes out of it.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
When Shadows was released, there were very few coop games. Hence the rave reviews it got.

Nowadays, coop games, or coop with traitor games are everywhere and Shadows' flaws are painful.

The traitor is just too damn powerful. There is no way to snuff him out and once he is revealed, he is even more powerful. That's why we stop playing with traitor rule.

But even in full coop mode, the game suffers from several flaws. The worse being that the knights maximise their chance of success by doing very dishonorable things :
- All knights without important items (such as the Graal) should suicide themselves to reduce the number of bad cards per turn.
- Once you have enough white swords, knights should try to fail quest as fast as they can before catapults make them lose the game.

For the perfect "coop game with traitor", check out Battlestar Galactica

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
After a number of viewings and one full play-through, I remain unimpressed.  The theme seems thinner than a cooperative game should warrant (e.g., LotR), and a lot of the choices seem rather limited.  Players can't make many meaningful decisions to help each other, which seems to be the core of a cooperative game.  Since there's a cost to move from quest to quest, they usually just focus on their own activities.  At best, they can coordinate (sort of) the playing of number cards to the same area, and therein lies the problem: it feels like you're just playing number cards rather than fending off invading Saxons.  Even with role-players trying to get into the spirit of things, they couldn't dispel the reality that we needed another 4 card to complete the straight or another 3 to finish the full house.  It just takes too long for too few interesting choices.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3.5
Zero replayability.  I can't understand how this game is getting so much praise and interest!  Last week, my gaming group played it twice in one night.  Those games we played were somewhat fun (I would have rated them perhaps a 6-7) but it will now never come out again.  I believe all 6 who played feel as I do.  It's not really a game at all.  It's an event - one that is done after just 1 or 2 tries.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Shadows over Camelot is a cooperative/semi-cooperative hand management and deduction-based board game for 3-7 players.

Each player represents a knight of the Round Table and they must collaborate to overcome a number of quests - ranging from defeating the Black Knight to the search for the Holy Grail. Completed Quests place white swords on the Round Table; failed Quests add black swords and/or siege engines around Camelot. The knights are trying to build a majority of white swords on the Table before Camelot falls.

On each knights' turn they take a 'heroic action', moving to a new Quest, building their hand or playing cards to advance the forces of good. However, they must also choose one of three evil actions, each of which will bring Camelot closer to defeat.

Moreover, one of the knights may be a Traitor - pretending to be a loyal member of the party but secretly hindering their fellows in subtle ways, biding their time, waiting to strike at the worst possible moment...

RATING: 4
Simple to learn and set up, this game strikes an uneasy balance between cooperation and secrecy between players. The rule to not reveal hand contents feels somewhat forced at times and leads to a bit of frustration. The most entertaining part of the game is the frequent accusations (deserved or not) of disloyalty around the table.

[update] much better social deduction games out there now
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
too little action and too little impact in each of your turns, lots of forced actions, betrayer gets identified if played too boldly or have no impact

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
"I'm not the traitor!  You are too!  No, I'm not, you are!"  It's one of my favorite co-operative group game.  Not knowing who, or if there is a traitor is a fabulous mechanic.  I also believe firmly, after playing numerous times now, that the game system has a hitch or loophole, or at least has a highly solveable optimal strategy.  I'm in the camp that believes in exposing the traitor as early as possible is best...  As the current rules are written, the optimal strategy as I see it, is to distribute grail cards evenly, go after non-solo quests (Grail & Excalibur quests), take black cards after only taking 6 siege engines.  After 6 siege engines, every knight accuses their left neighbor (before any quests/white swords are won) w/o penalty.  This will flush out the traitor every time w/o risk of giving the traitor a trophy or better position to cripple the team.  However, this one optimal strategy can possibly be fixed/curtailed with a slight rules adjustment which would decrease it's primary path to success.  With a rules adjustment (such as 1 black card/siege engine for each incorrect accusations when no white swords are available).  Now, obviously, this is NOT really the way to play this game as it was intended but my mind couldn't help but try to find the chink in the armor.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love the dynamics of this game where it is a cooperative endeavor to beat the game with a strong possibility of having a traitor amidst the group.  However, this game CAN be difficult for some people in that they take things personally which extends into real life beyond the game..:-(  Also, with more than 5 players, I would recommend that one would insure there is a traitor in the midst as I'm becoming convinced its relatively easy to beat with many players and no traitor.  Developing paranoia is a must!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Age and world of Camelot. Although I find the game does capture the feel of the world right, the system looks a bit aged fast.  The game has its moment when people talk and with a right group, the talk can be sun and intense, e.g. accusing the traitor correctly or incorrectly.  The overall game system wants you to balance risks faced by the group constantly.  Each player gets to do an evil phase, in which the evil forces would rise in the various quests. Each quest requires a different card formation to complete (except the Holy Grail). Depending on the number and types of cards in the hand, the players therefore chooses the quest to compete. The basic system is easy to get into for everyone but I don't think there is too many variations for you to deal with.  I agree with some observation that the game might get bored once you find it repetitive, just waiting to see what happens in Camelot and go to deal with the more urgent issues.  In our two games, one was accused incorrectly as traitor while the other one was accused but every one knew he was the traitor.  Still, not much you could do about it but to see the siege engines going to 12 winning the game for the evil.      
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
This game was quite fun the first 2 times we played it. We have played it 4 times total as of today. I can imagine our group playing this game many more times in the future, however I feel the re-play value is fairly low. Will get the Merlin's Company expansion after a few more games and the re-play value diminishes significantly. 
Every time we played we played with 4 players, minus one time we played with 5. We won half of the games, and got close one time. Rule book is easy to understand and our first play through took about 2 hours with 4 people. Every one of our games take approximately 1 hour 15 minutes to 1 hour 30 minutes. I really like the consistent gameplay time cuz it's easy to plan. May rate this game higher after a few more game plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favorite games.  It's cooperative, and it's one of the best coops to teach to people new to board games.  Love the miniatures, love the hand management and different quests, I think it fits the theme well, and the traitor plot really adds a twist to it, especially since you don't know for sure if there will be one.  Sometimes it can be really difficult (or perhaps impossible) to guess who the traitor is.

The only downside to this game is that the basic mechanics of the quests and the game overall are simple enough that, once you've played several times and you're a gamer, it becomes obvious what to do.  So I'm waiting through several other people's long analysis-paralysis turns to do my 5 second turn.  I look forward to getting the expansion someday, but I'm not so sure that will fix this for me.

Nevertheless, it's coop, so having my turn be gloriously deep in strategy isn't the most important thing by far.

This game visually is wonderful, too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Hey - this game is better than I expected. I thought I'd be lowering the score after the first play but the opposite is true. Many people criticize SoC for being a card game in disguise (I believed I would be one of them after having read the rules) but the truth of the matter is that you simply don't see and feel this mechanic while playing. You and your fellow players seem to automatically start role-playing their knights etc. and the atmosphere is brilliant. And boy, is the game hard - especially with a traitor. Even though you have to play cooperatively you really get a sense of accomplishment if you manage to win it (of course we failed the first time around, but we were more or less on the right track and that alone felt good :-D).

RATING: 6
My first real experience with a cooperative game. Solid, although with some odd bits that make it  harder to pick up than i would like. Good fun that will get better with more experience. Not the second coming that it seemed many people once thought it was, but nothing to be sneered at.

UPDATE: After a play of Pandemic, the relative flaws of Shadows are much more apparant. Pandemic is about as deep, I think, but plays much faster and with less reliance on fiddly rules.I won't drop SoC's rating, but further play is really going to have to show me something I didn't see the first time around.

RATING: 6.5
First time playing this, I loved it. The artwork and components are phenomenal.

However the game shines best with the traitor element.
The game runs a bit long if you are more than 5 players and I had lost attention from some non-gamers while playing this at 7 players.

It's best at 4-5 player with traitor or else the game is too straightforward and has some very obvious strategies for the knights to win.

-------------------

Over the time, we find this game is not really interesting. The mechanic is very simple but no themes. Also the action are not very interesting. My gaming group don't enjoy it and are often distracted when we play.

I'm thinking this game is probably good for people who hasnt played many other games.

RATING: 6
This game is pretty abstract feeling, with lots of victories just being a matter of set collection and accounting of numbers, and for the most part no special powers of enemies or things in your face to make you feel like something in particular is after you. I do like how they did the traitor mechanism a lot more than Dead of Winter though, in that it isn't reliant on a personal objective for the traitor to work. Also while the game is abstract, there isn't so much incessant searching, and the game is pretty streamlined.

RATING: 4
Very thematic, but the rules require caveats to prevent the traitor from breaking the game (specifically, the "don't play outright evil").  Even so, loyal-vs-traitor player strategy can be summed up as "Play loyal.  Don't look at your loyalty card; just play loyal."  An unrevealed traitor will nearly always win.  As such, secret loyalties are better done by other games.

RATING: 7
VERY unusual game.. I'm very pleased to see a co-operative game make it into the mainstream - the only other co-op I've got is "Space Future" and .. well, you know what I mean if you've played it.SOC basically has you and your compatriots attempting to complete a series of quests to save camelot, by each taking one beneficial(white) and one harmful(black) action each turn.  The black cards form a randomized timer on the various quests, ticking down to doom.  The rules are simplistic, which is good, because they have to handle combat as well as other types of quests.   This is another game like Arkham Horror that would benefit from a SERIOUS rewrite of the rule books to make plain the rules in a much shorter time - they are straight-forward and consistent, logical once you understand them.  The purpose and handling of the traitor frankly baffled us, however.A game like this has to make a decision between playability/simplicity and faithfulness to its myth, and for me it seemed overly focused on the 2nd (e,g War of the Ring.)  It's a hard balance to strike, however.  Personally, I found it a little too simple for my tastes, but given how many different things it does and how long it takes to play, I don't think they could have done it differently.  The game board, and pieces however, give the impression of richness and one does feel a bit odd when one lands on this colorful board and are told "you just play any white card, 6 times, you're done."  They could perhaps have simplified the number of types of quests for a bit more texture in the ones they kept.Regardless, some minor weaknesses aside, it's very very playable and colorful, doesn't take too long, and was fun, and of course, gold medal simply for the fact of making a mainstream cooperative game that doesn't come out handicapped or silly (re: Space Future)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a really fun game for a group.  With the addition of the traitor card (with 5 or more players) Adds an entirly new aspect of the game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
I have played this twice, great f*cking game! after the first few turns we were really hard pressed to keep ourselves alive and in the game, trying to pick the traitor was an interesting aspect with any bad decision or shifty look came a host of people claiming you were the traitor, none with enough conviction to make a full accusation. I killed my own knight in a mad dash to destory a siege engine at one point, laying down my best fighting card, a two, thus giving myself a 1 in 8 chance of winning, i lost and the traitor placed the last seige engine shortly after... great fun, but hard work. A difficult game is like a difficult woman, it needs plenty of attention and romance before it becomes "willing". fantastic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a beautiful and lovingly produced game that cleverly retells the King Arthur stories in a way that provides plenty of fuel for the imagination. But although it'd not devoid of tactics, each player's turn flies by so quickly, and success is so utterly dependent on the order that black cards are drawn, that it can sometimes feel a bit too much like the game is playing you.

RATING: 6.75
Used to be one of my favorite games, but alas, it has worn-out it's welcome in many ways.  I dropped my rating from a 7.9 to 6.37 as a result.  I find it too hard to explain to new gamers, and becomes a non-fun discussion fest over optimal moves with experienced gamers.  I hope Pandemic with it's shorter playing time can suitably replace what Shadows once was for me.  I still find the Traitor aspect brilliant... there may, or may not be a traitor amoung us... very cool.

UPDATE: over time, I felt this game was a.) too hard to explain to non-gamers, b.) a game that was too easy for push gamers to try and steer the moves of inexperienced players, and c.) not enough of a challenge for experienced players to want to play it anymore.

I gave it away right before the Merlin expansion came out, would love to try it again with the expansion.

RATING: 9
A top-notch game.  Another of those 'rare' games with an integral teamwork element, SoC has alot going for it.  Nice boards and bitz, balanced play (with a few exceptions), and high replayability all help this game stand on its own above and beyond the unique mechanics.  It's a winner.  ^_^
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the first games with a traitor mechanic.  The game requires you to advance evil by playing a black card, placing a catapult or losing a HP.  Then you perform an action to counter the advance of evil.  The actions are very simple with basic card play.  The game mechanics are pretty simple and it is hard not to like this game.  The only difficulty is that it seems optimal for 5 players.  If you have 6 or 7 it is too hard on the traitor and if you have less than five it is very hard on the loyal knights.  One nice aspect is that players can join the game late.  

One of my favorite games and if you can play with 5 it is a great game.

RATING: N/A
90 minute game. 
Min 3 players. Best with 5
These two points (above) suggest that the game won't get much play.

Mixed reviews as a family cooperative game. Although they do seem to be overwhelmingly positive: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/97023/shadows-over-camelot-revisited-why-when-and-how

Some comparisons to Battlestar Galactica.
Some have said the game is boring. But this is typically a seasoned game who wants something meatier.

Videos suggest that this might be fun BUT it sure seems complicated.
Pandemic and Forbidden Island may be a lighter/easier way to go in terms of cooperative play.

This review confuses everything: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/308846/will-my-friends-want-to-play-soc
Easy to learn (good), 2 hours to play (bad), fun (mixed feelings), etc.

This review seems to seal the deal (i.e., get it and it will be enjoyed):http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/119271/whats-all-this-then

This review also seems to hit a positive note (esp from a family's perspective): http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/533749/family-review-shadows-over-camelot-a-noble-quest

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[Played more than 100 times]

I've played it (with any number of players; included solo with an house rule) several times and I've enjoyed all of them. Besides, it has been extremely well-received by my friends (five of them have bought their copy!).

It's unique because it is: 
1) cooperative;
2) simple enough to be liked by non-gamers, but interesting enough to be liked by gamers as well;
3) for 3 to 7 players (scales well and may be played with 2 or solo with a simple variant);
4) "open" (you may join or leave the table at any time).

Besides, I like:
1) the "Traitor" mechanic (it adds a very subtle psychological aspect and more tension when playing; it also helps balancing the game since it is more likely with more players);
2) the non-linearity granting much more variety and possible strategical approaches than Knizia's LotR;
3) the randomness used to give variety, but still leaving several choices to the players;
4) the balanced gameplay and the possibility to adjust the difficulty level as desired (e.g. to make it harder play as "squires", start with less life points and/or cards, put the "Mists of Avalon" in play during setup,... to make it easier play without Loyalty cards, start with more life points and/or cards,... );
5) the setting (Knights of the Round Table);
6) the great bits and artwork;
7) the good replay value (granted mostly by: the traitor, the variety due to cards, the possibility to raise the difficulty as explained above).

Average game lenght for us: 90 minutes.

Overall impression: it's an original, interesting and well realized game.

RATING: N/A
In most games, players compete against each other to achieve victory. Shadows over Camelot proposes a journey of a very different kind, where you and your fellow players, as Knights of the Round Table, will collaborate to jointly defeat... the game!
At first glance, this task seems simple enough. After all, shouldn’t a band of young and noble Knights - fleet of foot and sound of mind - easily defeat a game that plays itself? Alas your quest is further complicated by the ever-present possibility of a Traitor in your midst, biding his time, waiting to strike at the worst possible moment...
But enough words... Don your cloak, climb astride your warhorse and gallop into the Shadows to join us in Camelot!

RATING: 5
When I first played this game, I immediately loved it.  This is probably because it was the first coop strategy game I played.  After several playings, I'm less enthused.  The play gets stale, as there are few options in any given turn.  This is particularly true during quests, due to the large penalties for leaving early.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Jeux Organisé
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The jury is out on this one. So far just the one game, but your options seem pretty dictated once the game gets under way and the evil cards start to fall. The traitor mechanism is nice - it adds some fun opportunities to interact and taunt the others. this rating will either end up an 8 or a 6.

Update 2006

Gave this to my sister for Christmas and it turned out to be an instant hit! We played 5 games over the New Years weekend and had a blast every time. The game is difficult no matter how many play and each victory (and loss) came down to a final few player turns that could have gone either way.

Well done Days of Wonder!

Update 04/14/2007

Time to re-evaluate this one. I find myself not wanting to play this much anymore. It's like the game has been "solved" or something. There is a set pattern to completing the quests and unless you have a really good traitor, the end game will ultimately be determined by the Evil cards that come in to play. If you get a few nasty ones in a row when the Knights are weak... game over. I'm dropping this to a 7.5 for the time being.

Update 03/20/2009

Played this one a couple times after a long hiatus. I had a lot of fun but I'm still dropping the rating down a half a point as I found myself not as drawn into the game as I've been in the past. The game feels a bit scripted at times - the Pict/Saxon quests are rarely done to by the knights, the Black Knight quest even less. It's just so important to finish the Grail and Excalibur quests as quickly as possible (although there is something to be said for keeping the Excalibur quest at a "status quo" don't get additional seige engines).

RATING: 1.1
I made the mistake following the advice of the rulebook and to play the first game without traitor. It was a boring game, because between 6 players we achieve 7 swords and, like it was obvious, we decide to combat the catapults and to hope the black swords arrive to finish the game.  
So boring it was that now I will make an effort to convince to the other ones that with traitor it is better.
I'll try to get a new chance and after that i'll change my vote. 
UPDATED: reading the rules clarifications in many threads I think it would be possible to have a better approach to this game. Scale from 1 to 2.
UPDATE: After another play with differents player and including the traitor, the thing was better: more fun and difficult (traitor win with 12 siege engines). So, going up to 4.
UPDATE: with other difficult game of 4, I reach the conclusion that ithere is not fun when each one is devoted to a futile activity: to put cards in an even double or in a line of Grail. Several rounds making the same thing to anybody has a good time, more when the Evil advances relentless.  
In synthesis, what I see for the time being is: or it is very easy and they no longer give desires of playing it again, or it is very difficult that neither they give desires of winning it in another opportunity, because when not being an individual challenge it doesn't exist the element and personal pride to achieve it, being reduced to a fruitless and boring collective effort.
4 to 3.
I'm thinking that i paid too much for this items ($55 to Chile) for the so few games that I will probably play.
I would prefer to like it to justify the investment and to surprise my friends with a game that has such a pretty appearance (my initial bias was so positive that I translated to Spanish all the Specials Black and White cards and the Special Power of the knights and I put them in BGG).
FINAL UPDATE: the last game with 5 player 1 traitor include. Boring. From 3 to 1.
The worst investment i have done.
Negative aspects: a lot of factor luck, boring repeated actions; few alternatives for the player, slowness  
Positive aspect: new experience, for not repeating.
Before our last game i played for the first time Saboteur: this was for all of us a great discover, with a lot of fun. Very easy to learn and to play. Fast. Discover the traitors or saboteurs was much more amusing that the same thing in Soc.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
SOC is a rich, gorgeous game with an absolutely brutal pace: Things look okay for the first couple of turns ("Twelve siege engines? We'll never get there...") but get ugly quick -- in a good way.

With multiple quests demanding attention, the prospect of a traitor in your midst, and a constant war between using/saving life points and gaining/using cards, there's always more you want to do on any given turn.

Having played this with the traitor, I'd love to try it as a pure co-op, Pandemic/LotR-style.

RATING: 8.5
Fun game! Everyone I played with really enjoyed it...maybe more than me? I had really high expectations, so maybe that played into it, but it didn't quite knock my socks off the first play. I think part of that might be due to the fact that I played the traitor, and I wasn't sure how to play it very well. I lost big time. Bottom line, if you have intelligent gamers playing this game, it's really hard to play the lone traitor (particularly if the player count is 6 or more). 

That said, what I did like was:

-Components: gorgeous and solid boards and bits
-Theme: Can't go wrong with King Arthur and the round table
-Variable player powers: These could have been more impactful on gameplay, but they were still interesting.
-Scalability: I could see this playing well at any count from 4 to 7. Not many games with this much meat can play well with more than 5.
-Accessibility: In the same league as Pandemic--a true gateway, considering how you largely are just playing poker hands.

So I definitely liked a whole lot more than I disliked. The group had a great time, and it's certainly unique. I give it an 8.5 for now. I'm hopeful this will go up with future plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Three brave knights (5, 8, and 38 years) set out to save Camelot.  I decided our first game, and possibly all games, will be co-op, i.e. no traitor to try and get the boys working together.  The boys quickly took to the rules with only minimal prompting about the turn order and actions.  The next game will go even better.  Any special card (white or black) was put out on the table for all to read which overcame the 5 year old reading issues.  Younger kids will not have any problem with the game and it was an enjoyable experience for all.  I already hear requests to break this out again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In Shadows Over Camelot players take on the role of King Arthur's knights of the round table.  The game is co-operative, though there is the possibility of a traitor within the loyal knights' midst.  On a players turn they choose to go out to help accomplish one of a variety of missions, whether it may be going off to fight invaders, or questing after some object of import.  They also have to do something that will negatively impact the group.

The game uses poker hands to accomplish missions, which isn't really thematic.  Also, most missions have a real tug of war feel, as you do something to get closer to succeeding in the mission, but then something bad happens to take the mission's success further out of sight.

The idea that there may be, but not necessarily be, a traitor adds a nice feeling of paranoia to the proceedings.  Though not short, this isn't overly long for a big game either.  For that reason this is my game of choice for a co-op with hidden traitor.  While not as thematic as Battlestar Galactica, the fact that it is 3-5 hours shorter is a huge plus in my books!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The groups enjoy this game alot. Mainly the accusations of traitor.

A few observations:
1. Replayability Issue? This game is getting pretty old.
2. Putting Siege is like the suckiest Progression of Evil.
3. The game is like a timer of inevitable defeat unless the knights can complete enough quests prior to that end. Variant of Knights do not win if final quest fails is good.
4. Seems like traitor always go to Excalibur to burn good cards.
5. Holy Grail quest is suckiest (read: most boring) if attempted alone.

Update: Sold.

RATING: 8
Enjoyed the co-operative nature of this game and the game play.  A nice balance of play options per turn which gave rise to many dilemmas.  Should we focus on the Holy Grail or take on the Saxon Army?  And what about that Black Knight? A nice one for seasoned board gamers.
Update: Enjoyed this game even more as I got to play the traitor last time.  I didn't get caught until they thought they had won; then I snatched victory from them at the final hour... bwahahaha.
Update: I've now played this about 6-7 times and still really enjoy it.  Whether it's playing with different people maintains the interest, or just the nature of the way the cards come out I'm not sure.  And as long as it stays fun, I don't care :)

RATING: 8
Fun and easy going, yet challenging co-op experience with a traitor element.

The goal is to gather poker hands around the board to stop evil things from happening, while gathering white swords around the round table.

Also the point is to find the traitor ASAP, before he/she can ruin everything :)

RATING: 6
We misplayed our first two games; we misread the rules for the quest action on the holy grail making the game a touch too easy.  The past four games have been much tougher with the proper grail rules and using the squire / 3 life point variant.

Six games in and I am already starting to feel burnout; the novelty seems to be wearing thin.  I love the components and I like the fact players can enter and exit at will, however, I have avoided playing the game during the past two game  sessions.  I will enjoy playing it a few times per year.  But on the other hand, I can usually say that about most of the games I own.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Shadows is great fun for various sizes of gaming groups, and one of the few popular cooperative games on the market.  As always, Days of Wonder does a fantastic job with the game design, which is a huge boost in a medieval fantasy game.  The gameplay remains challenging and fun, although it can suffer from the more-experienced players doing too much to guide others, rather than letting them play as they see fit.  It definitely works better when the players have similar experience levels.  It's rarely easy and the difficulty scales extremely well with various numbers of players, which greatly adds to the level of entertainment.  The fact that great fun is usually had and that it accommodates a much larger number of people than most games keeps Shadows on my list of favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I have played the game twice now.  I enjoyed it much more the second time. Still not a game I want to play often enough to rate higher.  Not much decision making in the game at all. No matter what, you must be in the mood to play this story driven, cooperative game.  If you are in the mood for a competitive game in the traditional sense, stay away!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played this with my regular crowd and we all loved it.  Tight, tense, and exciting till the very end.  In our crowd, we all kibbitz, give advice and rag each other throughout every game we play, so this one is perfect for us.  It might get old after a ton of play as strategies become more obvious, but we're enjoying the trip so far.  Tremendous production values make for great eye candy.  Quick turns keep the action flowing around the table.  It's a little squirrely trying to explain the rules, but just don't try to explain absolutely everything right away, as most of it will become apparent through play.  Exceptionally brilliant co-op game for the right crowd.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: Knights of the round table co-op game. Jump from rummy mission to rummy mission collecting good points before the game sneaks up and ends.

Played as: 4 player (w/ trader)

Pros: Variable player powers add the right amount of spice to otherwise simple mechanics. A lot of good stuff going on around the board to make players sweat. The option of a traitor adds something worth playing for when the board starts to offer less challenge.

Cons: Theme felt a little pasted on and even though there were plenty missions, didn't offer enough interesting variety from one to the next to match it's 2 hour play length.

Other: My one play was with a traitor and I think I would have preferred to just focus on beating the board off the get go. This might have affected my initial impression and the rating I gave it. I can see the traitor being a big plus with some more experience just playing the board. I'll certainly play again given the option.

Best Use: A nice medium weight / length co-op game.

RATING: 5
Somehow this game reminded me a lot of playing bonhanza - without the trading. Your actions in the game are pretty much limited to whatever white actions card you draw, and of course these are drawn at random. As such it feels like the game is playing you rather than the other way around. The only meaningful decisions are taken in the black action phase, and there is not enough in there to keep me coming back (maybe if the game was 60 mins that would be ok). My other main concern with the game is game balance. After playing 4 times (with two traitors), it seems that winning without the traitor is hard enough, and impossible to win when a traitor is there. 

Maybe I'm just not a cooperative-type person :)

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Such a unique game - plays equally well with 4 players as it does 7, though turns can get a little long with a full 7, especially if one of them has a hard time tracking whose turn is coming up, etc.

Turns should be VERY quick, often less than 20 seconds.  Each hero has a nice special mechanic which is valuable.  This is on the easier side of co-op games, but if you get a good traitor in your group - it can be really well done and just as you think you're coasting to victory, in a surprising turn or two, it's over and you're left in shock.  Very fun and unique cop-op.

The miniatures are great quality and were fun to paint.  We find the board layout a bit awkward - not sure on solution, but so many separate boards just feels odd, but it makes sense why it's that way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Solid game, great bits, easy to teach.  I love that you have to do something "evil" each turn, it creates a good amount of tension.  The traitor mechanism is also great, adding to the tension.  Not enough choices to make this a great game but otherwise well-designed.

RATING: 8

The only thing holding it back from a 10 for me it's the fact that the mechanisms mimicking poker can feel sort of out of place. I'd rather try to do something different to represent a duel with the black knight than playing 2 pairs... Only that, and even in that regard I'm being picky, because once you're playing, you won't feel it that weird.

Excellent game.

RATING: 8.5
[played 10+]

The best cooperative game I played.
Usualy I'm not very fond of cooperative games, because they tends to be boring, but this is not the case in SoC. The game plays well aginst the players, who are always close to be overwhelmed by evil forces and have to choose carefully wich fiend fight.
There's a thing I like much in this game I never found in other boardgames: players do (if they want, of course) heroycs deeds - they sacrifice itselves, they risk, they fight against theri odds - and winning being "heroics" it's a fine feeling.
Traitor add some flavour and suspect to an already good game.
Winning as "good" is not easy when you play in 4-5 players. IMHO best played in 6-7

RATING: 4
Great theme, but one of the most convoluted games of any title in my collection.  Especially for this particular publisher, I was mystified as to why it appeared to take a degree in Advanced Physics to understand what to do turn to turn!  And then when you finally figured out how to do something, forget about actually trying to win the game.  You need to have the coordinated effort of the Navy SEALs going into combat to even have a shot at victory.  With so many other co-ops around (and my gaming groups' relative ambivalence toward this genre in the first place) this was the perfect candidate for selling.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A rather challenging but nonetheless entertaining game which requires dedicated teamwork in order to achieve a victory. It's a bit like multi-tasking since you have around seven quests going on at once and if you're only playing a three-player game, then it's a little difficult to catch up on all of them - as a matter of fact, it's impossible. This is one of the factors that makes this game interesting: you have to make big decision which will have a big impact on the outcome of your game. You have to choose which quests to abandon and consider lost, since you can never win all of them. As you play this game you seek to complete the most profitable quests for which you have the corresponding cards, abilities or whatever. However, it is quite challenging and you will likely lose a considerable number of your games. Still, this makes the game even more intriguing, since you then try to look at what you've done wrong in order to improve for your next game, so as to increase your chances of victory. Shadows over Camelot is a game which really encourages teamwork and makes you appreciate it a lot. The replaybility of it is not very low as your choices depend on the cards you receive and on the various events that take place every turn as "evil progresses". Besides that, there is always the ever lingering possibility of a traitor amongst you who makes the game at least three times harder!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I don't think I could play this without six or more players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love that this game! Players play co-operatively against the game itself and the inclusion on a traitor in the midst is really what sky-rockets this game from a good game into a great game! Make no mistake; this is not a simple game. Also, this game is HARD! We played and got our asses kicked even without the traitor but going up against insurmountable odds and winning by the skin of your teeth makes these types of games fun and exhilarating. Artwork and pieces are gorgeous too! The only real downside is the complexity of this game. Even though the rules are well written, it’s still a little hard to explain to new players. Also, it's at long game that will require about a 2 hour commitment. Otherwise, it’s highly recommended, especially for groups who enjoy a little back-stabbing and a good challenge.

RATING: 10
Shadows Over Camelot with the Merlin’s Company expansion. After explaining to your non-geek friends what a “hit point” is, the rest of the rules explanation go relatively painlessly. Old-school D&D players will take to it like a pig in mud.  The cooperative nature of the game is a nice change of pace for the night, but the challenge remains intense with the possibility of a Traitor. One of our favorite parts of this game is the possibility that there may be a traitor in our midst. One of everyone ELSE’S favorite parts of the game seems to be accusing ME of being said traitor. Shadows frequently lasts only about 90-120 minutes, but can go over 3 hours.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A nice co-op with a "traitor" element.  Fun to get into with the right group, but with the wrong group, it could be less-than-pleasurable.  Mostly due to some wonky rules regarding the traitor and table-talk that you just have to accept in order for the game to really shine.  Also, the rules take a lot of time to explain, but once the group knows what they're doing, gameplay can be nice and quick.  So, not a perfect game by any means, has some flaws, but in the right context, it can be a good time.

And to those who say Battlestar Galactica replaces SoC, I will say this: it may indeed be a superior game in depth, strategy, fun, and virtually every other way, but any game that takes between 2-4 (or more) hours will never get asked to be played again in any of my gaming circles.  We can knock shadows out in 1-2 hours.  So there you have it.  Maybe I'm settling for the lesser game, but at least I will get to play a game.

RATING: 7
I love the concept of a cooperative game, but didn't much get into the Lord of the Rings coop game. This coop seemed really  hard the few times we have played it, possibly because we desperately wanted a traitor to be present and accounted for.   Also, one complaint that possibly might be cleared up with more plays: it seems that as long as the traitor is "pretending" to be good, they can't be adding catapults on each turn and hurting your progress.  So, even if you know who the traitor is on the first turn-- is it necessarily good to expose them?  You almost cripple their powers by keeping them on your side for a while, which somewhat hurts the theme of a traitor.

RATING: 6
At first, the rules seemed too dense and confusing. However, once we started playing, within a few turns everything was quite clear, and then we discovered just how intense the game could be.  This game lulls you into a sense that you are in control, and before you realize you're losing to the forces of evil!  As a knight you struggle to beat back hordes of Saxons, Picts and the Black Knight, while trying to capture the Holy Grail and Excalibur.

A wonderful game with a ton of great story flavor. The game play is easy once learned and in the end provides a rich, and very dramatic flow with a totally unknown ending.  Very much fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Shadows Over Camelot is probably my favourite of the hidden traitor coop games.

Players must all work together to card manage a variety of problems the Round Table has to face before the game is up.

Not being able to give exact information on your hands makes trust and negotiation important. The traitor(s) can take advantage of the game's features to ruin chances of victory and encourage distrust.

I imagine with the wrong group this would not work well, but with the right group it can have more diplomacy, heroics, mistrust and strife then an episode of Game of Thrones!

The expansion is almost essential.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I think this game is perfect with 7 people, as a matter of fact, whenever I have 6 friends over the first thing that passes through my mind is "I should get the Shadows over Camelot".
The game however has some flaws that makes for the 9 instead of 10, for instance:
- After a couple of plays you'll always know if there is a traitor in the group after 10-20 min of game. This bust the fun of COULD be a traitor, and either grants you that in fact there is a traitor or that the rest of the game will be annoyingly easy (and you can't even say let's end the game because there is no traitor, because there could be a traitor that does not know how to play).
- There is only one traitor and it has the same power independent of the number of players, this makes the game EXTRA hard with fewer players, but also ruins the fun because it's easier to detect the traitor. With 7 players the game is quite balanced, however the traitor doesn't have much power and depends on luck to win the game, but this is balanced because most likely you'll not figure out who's the traitor until the very end.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Shadows over Camelot is responsible for the renewal of my interest in modern board games beyond MTG and the occasional game of Citadels; and will certainly remain a milestone in my gaming group, thanks to its ludicrous production values and compelling theme. It has, however, several flaws that I can't honestly overlook:

- The difficulty relies quite heavily on the player count, which wouldn't be an issue if SoC was a purely cooperative game. We go from 3 players, which is probably unwinnable for the good guys if there is a traitor, to 7 players, which is almost unlosable for veteran good guys regardless of the presence of a traitor.
- The official communication policy is messy. The reason why the rulebook tries to set one is that giving away the contents of player's hands would make the traitor's job (hindering the game plan under cover) impossible, but having no idea about their contents would make team coordination impossible. You're left with this bastard system where you're pseudo-roleplaying sentences that are really convoluted, thus you can't sensibly describe more than a couple pieces of information every other turn without entering downtime town. Meta-gaming social etiquette as a gameplay restriction seems like poor design.
- The amount of rules to be learnt is disproportionate relatively to the simplicity of a game turn. I mostly blame quests there, which are basically "tug of war", "biggest total after reveal wins" and "race to make a flush" but take a lot more explaining.
- Some parts of the rulebook are poorly laid out. Every time I want another info than the full ruling of a special card, I have to pause the game a bit.
- The rewards and penalties associated with a correct accusation, an incorrect accusation and the traitor staying hidden the whole game aren't exactly intuitive and it's hard to ask for them without being accused of felony.
- The traitor has no strategic reason to bluff cooperation at all. Holding a couple special cards from the recycling discard and being sometimes slightly less efficient than the other players, in the hope you're trusted one critical turn with something important, is not as powerful as being openly damaging from the very beginning by losing quests and blocking spaces on purpose. Then if we compare the 4 swords swing gained from being undetected the whole game (at the price of granting several white swords before that point by playing loyal) to openly blocking spaces and choosing the worse outcomes every time at the mere cost of 1 sword when you get accused, the undisguised way will on average generate more black swords (which is not even close below 6 players) or simply openly threaten a loss to catapults from the get-go. The *actual* incentive for cooperation is that a revealed traitor is boring to play. Again, the game working on a tacit meta-game consideration seems like poor design.
- Discarding cards to regain bravery as an action is incredibly clunky, in the sense this bravery will likely be respent for the action just spent anyway. I suppose it's a hack around grail cards bloating your hand in the endgame, but having this mechanic and accusation as basic actions while you seldom ever use them in practice hardly helps with teaching the rules.
- Games of SoC are relatively same-y, because the same threats always hit the same locations, just in a slightly different order that doesn't change the process of dealing with them in any way.
- Overall, the density of interesting decisions is quite low; your hand of cards more or less dictates the quests you're proficient at. The relative obviousness of player behaviour was possibly designed with the intent of making players able to detect potential traitors without getting a headache in the process. And it's possible to be involved in other players' decisions regardless of checking whether they look loyal, but you can easily witness that anyone's turn often comes down to "draw a black card, do my thing, pass".

In conclusion the game mostly works and I will still play it with my crowd, but more out of habit than excitement. Oh, yes, a word on the expansion, which suceeds at making the game harder (for the good guys) without making it more fun in the process. The base game already features simple variants if you desire such a thing. Skip.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
When thinking of a co-op game, most people turn to Pandemic. I like Shadows much more. While it can have a traitor, the game plays as a co-op game. It's built well enough to allow players to drop-in and drop-out as needed so it works great when one person is running late, or leaving early for game night. I love the theme and the game plays well into it. And it's TOUGH. Much more so than Pandemic. This might be less exciting for some, but I love it. If there is a better co-op game out there, I haven't played it.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Since I got my start in role-playing games, I really enjoy the cooperative aspect of this game.  It definitely has that adventuring feel to it, and the theme comes through very stronly.  I also think the mechanics do a very good job of scaling across the player range, and allow players to join and leave as they choose.  I also like that the game is hard for the players to win; it's a real challenge, and victory feels rewarding because of it.

I am concerned that the traitor is too powerful.  It seems that there is no real incentive for the traitor to hide himself, as constantly placing siege engines should be more than enough to overwhelm the good knights.  Add to this the fact that the traitor is more powerful when he is revealed, and it seems like the traitor should be played in an obvious way.  The game is still fun and a good experience, but the strategic level may not be there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I love cooperative games, and this game is no exception. Even if this game has the theme slightly pasted on, I loved the tension, the cooperative factor and the beautiful components.

RATING: 8
Great co-op game with a great theme, artwork, components, and miniatures. If you love the mythology of King Arthur, you'll probably enjoy this game. It's fun working together as Knights of the Round Table, attempting the various quests, keeping the Picts and Saxons at bay, and preventing siege engines from destroying Camelot. I would love to play with a traitor, but the game is hard and long enough without one that we usually keep that mechanic out.

RATING: 8
If it was just a straight cooperative game the game might rate a six or seven, it would be good but not brilliant.  The traitor makes the game; the fact that figuring out which player is the wrong one adds a challenging element that makes each play intriguing.  And the fact that the game can be played fairly quickly makes it even more friendly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Cooperative game themed in the period of King Arthur. Everyone plays a Knight going on different quests, such as the Holy Grail or finding Excaliber; quests are resolved by playing certain combinations of cards. During their turn, a player must do an evil action (draw black card, lose a life, add seige engine) and do a good action. Game is lost if there are more black swords than white on the Round table, there are 12 seige engines or all Knights are lost. The marvelous twist in this game is that someone can potentially be the traitor, and they win if the loyal knights lose. Without the traitor, the game is an okay system cooperation game (7 out of 10), but with the presence of a traitor (8 out of 10) the game is tense and exciting as everyone is looking around suspiciously. It's a fun game, but with 3 players, it is too easy for the traitor, and if there are 7 players, it is too hard for the traitor, so there needs to be some balancing variants, some of which are suggested in the rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fairly fun co-op game. One to play with the family really.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'd like to try this out. I'd get it if

1. It didn't need 3 players to be fully implemented since I can only rely on 2 regularly.
2. It didn't compete with other semi-coop games of which I have several
3. I didn't already have so many hidden traitor games.

It looks like an amazing game and I'd like to get it but with chaos in the old world on the way, there's only so many games that require 3 players that I can get.

-------------
UPDATE: Cou'dnlt help myself. Bought this along with Merlins company and company of knights. Looks amazing. Can't wait to play.

UPDATE: I love this game. Played it solo, played it two player full coop. Played it four player with 25% chance of no traitor and also played it 4 player with 1 traitor for sure. It shines in all these ways especially this last. Its a strategic game that has the suspicion and bluffing element but its light enough that new players can jump into it fairly easily. There are definite strategies that should be taken; some people have said it's "solved". I wouldn't go that far, but the theme, components, flavor and bluffing/suspicion element make all of that come alive. This beats battlestar for my collection.

None of this changes the fact that the game is a blast to play.  The forces of good and evil both make progress on every turn, which makes SOC immensely superior to the Lord of the Rings co-op game with its damnable stack of good and bad tiles.

RATING: 6

RATING: 8
Fun to play many times, but with less than 5 the traitor does not work well in our experience. Once you play a few games it becomes easy to win without a traitor. If there is a traitor with less than 5 then you have almost no chance of winning (unless you are the traitor). I also do not like that catapults come out after completing the grail and excalibur quests. I realize this makes the game more balanced, but catapults are so hard to destroy it is as if it would be silly to beat those two quests. 

Despite the flaws this is one of our favorite and most played games, the game play is engaging and devising a strategy is fun. Also the artwork and theme are really cool. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The game definitely works, and it is certainly accessible to non-gamers.  That said, when I'm picking games to bring to an outing I keep passing this one up after only three plays.---update---Degraded to a 5.  This is a cardgame posing as a boardgame.  Not a very compelling cardgame at that.  The traitor idea is neat, but I'd rather play werewolf.  The fighting back evil forces that come from the deck is neat, but I'd rather play Knizia's Lord of the Rings.  Figuring out how to cooperate in the best possible fashion is neat, but again I'd rather play Knizia's Lord of the Rings.  The components are beautiful, as we've come to expect from DoW, but this one is all sizzle and no steak.  The options on your turn are way too restrictive, which makes the game artificially tight.

---update---
down to a 3.  There is a fine basic system but there just isn't enough here to make me want to play this again.

RATING: 8.5
The game is not as predictable as reviews lead on if played with 5 or 6 players: 7 makes it too easy for the knights w/o squire rules, 4 or 3 makes it too easy for the traitor.  I'm a BIG fan and after countless plays, this game's strategy still seems fluid enough not to drag play, although I still haven't seen a knight attempt the Black Knight.

Also, like Settlers, Shadows is a great gateway game.  Maybe it's the acronym.

The problem?  BSG exists.  And for a gamer posse, it's simply a better 5-6 player "traitor" game.  It has completely replaced Shadows as the coop-minus game of choice in our group.  But it's perfect for younger audiences like my nephews, and it's a great intro to coop-minus-one games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Has the most common broken game mechanic out there -- limited communication. You can't say what the number is, but you can talk about it vaguely. Anybody who isn't an idiot can figure out exactly what you are saying and the only way to fix it is to never communicate which makes the game too hard. We were playing with expansion cards and the game was over shortly after we got our first white sword. It turns out there is a card that draws two siege engines. I guess it was funny that we all thought everyone was the traitor even though there was no traitor.  If a group is looking for a game that is basically the opposite of fun (where everyone loses badly and quickly while yelling at eachother) this is a great game. Despite this, I'd play it again -- its very fast and entertaining in a Walking Dead / everyone you love will die sort of way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
This a good cooperative game with a twist. If you play with the traitor, you can never be sure when you're going to be stabbed. It seems like it's best to concentrate on one or two goals at a time, since spreading yourself too thin accomplishes nothing. There seems to be a fairly standard way to beat this, so it might get dull after too many plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.45
The components are top notch, Days of wonder style. Thick cardboard, nice illustrations, miniatures... the best of the best.

The traitor/loyalty idea has been adopted by many later games, some of them very recent and popular (Dead of Winter and Battlestar Galactica), and I cannot say it's been improved a lot since then. In SoC though, the traitor must do his best not to be discovered, because his ability to influence the game will be much more limited (and boring) when operating from the open. But I cannot say this is a flaw of the game, it just forces the traitor not to try his luck too much.

Time has been kind with this title. It still plays nice and it's a good option for a cooperative,maybe not as good as others, but it's much shorter. 

Like most others in its genre, it's not really scalable (5-7 players) and time between turns feels a bit long. Also, its mechanisms are a bit too easy to master and I'm afraid it's not going to be very replayable for veteran gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Every time I play this game it is usually with a new group of people, so for ease of teaching I have not yet had a chance to play with the traitor rules.  Still, it's a good game to play for the people who like their gameplay cooperative and not ridiculously hard like Ghost Stories.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
For trade: like new.  Played twice.

Super high quality components (typical Days of Wonder style), lost in an abstract masquerading as a thematic game.

Admittedly, I have only played this game twice, and both times without the traitor.  However, understanding how the mechanics work, it seems highly unlikely a traitor could go undiscovered for very long (assuming they actually do anything to thwart the rest of the players.)

Frankly, the game is hard enough to beat without the traitor.

A very similarly styled game: Battlestar Gallactica.

Whereas BG has a spot-on theme, great mechanics, and a superb implementation of the traitor mechanic, SoC has a pasted-on theme and mostly weak mechanics.

RATING: 6
The collaborative element is a winner. Perfectly playable with two (take two or three knights each, natch), and easy enough - despite the imposing appearance - to teach granny. Gorgeous, gorgeous art work in all elements of the game. Those complaining about the general shallowness need to lighten up and bring a bit more RPG to the cause, as hinted at by the manual! 

Upgraded again after it proved to have more legs than Pandemic. Probably the only co-op I really need to own.

RATING: 10
Amazing mechanics. Plays relatively fast and has great flow. Cathala is a genius when it comes to taking preexisting archetypes and re-imagining them in an important and fresh way. The card play keeps the game simple to play and teach, but the theme doesn't necessarily suffer from that. As a team you feel like you are running around the board putting out as many fires as possible, all the while knowing that someone might be sabotaging all the hard work.

Do I feel like King Arthur? Probably not. 

Do I feel the tension, the camaraderie, and the inevitable  triumph/defeat of our team? Absolutely.

RATING: 7.9
This is Awesome! I haven't played a cooperative game yet I didn't like! You know I never have gotten into the Camelot/Medieval type theme...ever! But this game has done just that and more! This game is great for 2-players, but only gets better with more! When you get a good game going and the traitor aspect of the game comes into play...that's when this game really shines! It took us awhile to get to a really good game like that...I think that was due to us teaching the game to new groups of people! You are a knight at the round table or even King Arthur himself! You must go on quests to help retrieve Excalibur, the Holy Grail, special armor, defeat the Saxons or Picts, etc. all before time runs out. Every battle won means a white sword on the round table, every battle lost means a black sword...booo...unless you are the traitor that is! 

So far this game seems to take the same pattern of event play (i.e. Excalibur, then grail, then whatever other quest until you win...or lose)! I hope this isn't true...will play more and see!

RATING: 7.75
I think this was my first co-op + hidden traiter game. I like Battlestar Galactica a lot lot more than this, although it is a lovely game. The major difference between this and BSG is that calling out the traitor is a gameplay option with real consequences: if you're wrong, you get screwed. The strength and weakness of the BSG system is that you have to out yourself as a traitor, and everyone else can just make assertions. (Obviously that changed with the introduction of executions in BSG.) Aaaanyway, Shadows is pretty nice. Dunno when I'd ever choose it over it's prettier younger sister though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.8
[youtube=B4n5WfqQLNY]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game is just awesome, it is seldom a weekend at which this game doesn't come on the table. This game is mainly a psychological defiance. You don't know whether there is or not a traitor in the game, and this uncertainty is what makes this game what it is. In fact, the traitor (if in game) can't do that much more harm then any other player could, what is important to the traitor is doing certain actions at the most critical times. But the simple fact of uncertainty makes all players somehow play in a very enclosed way, always analysing each other trying to detect the traitor among them. And if one of the players should make a wrong move accidentally, it immediately triggers the "side look" syndrome on other players. He may not be the traitor, but one wrong move was enough... so, despite being a cooperative game.. it's not as linear as that.. you need to try it to get it. So... please do when you get the chance.

[b]Strong theme[/b]
[b]Co-op game[/b]

RATING: 6

RATING: 10
One of my favourite games ever! Its hard and with a Traitor element especially if that Traitor knows how to play and waits for the right moment to mess things up for everyone else it will be a blast.

One of the best artworks I have seen ever in a game along with Archipelago and Cyclades. The Arthurian theme is one of the best themes for me since I grew up playing Stronghold and Stronghold Legends and it captures it beautifully. 

Elements are cool everyone against the game which is really hard and harsh to the players but here is the fun part the game is co-op and all the knights are trying  their best to win the game or do they? But one of theme is secretly a traitor who works for Mordred and his dark forces. And no one knows who the traitor is and this adds so much mistrust between the players and soo much fun and replay value since you never know if there is a traitor or there is no traitor at all.

10/10 A must have for any game group out there!

RATING: 7
Un gioco divertente e molto ben fatto: ha i punti forti di Arkham Horror (il gioco in cooperativa) senza i difetti (una certa pesantezza delle regole) e con una ciliegina (l'infame che rema contro). C'è sempre il dubbio che chi compie una scelta sbagliata non lo faccia per distrazione, ma perché è la mela marcia. Si è sempre frenati dall'aiutare i compagni, temendo di avvantaggiare il traditore. E si dubita di ogni mossa altrui. Il gioco permette alla mela marcia di fare danni passando da eroe. Eccezionali gli ultimi turni, quando le azioni di tutti i cavalieri vengono passate al setaccio, in un crescendo di paranoia. Se si fa finta di non di sentire l'odore di astratto salire da sotto le illustrazioni medievali, e si ha la compagnia giusta è un gran gioco. Come genere cooperativo c'è di meglio in giro, ma rimane comunque un bel gioco.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is one of my favorite games. It is usually quite fun, but a bad group of players can make the game really difficult. People who do sub-optimal plays and refuse to listen to the group can cause misdirected suspision and cause incorrect accusations of trechery. If players are not good at working as a team, then they shouldn't play this one. No one will have any fun. On the flip side, this game can be really easy with strong players and no traitor. This game also has a good deal or shiny pieces and great art.

RATING: 6
I'm not a huge fan of cooperative games, and like most of the genre, this one is way too hard, even without someone trying to sabotage your efforts.  Even completing quests is often negative, because then cards related to that quest that are drawn become even more deadly.  The prohibition on sharing information about cards is really hard to enforce, as people gave clues that essentially gave it away.  The components in the game are absolutely fantastic, I'd be hard-pressed to think of a game that is more visually appealing.

Sold on eBay 7/29/16 for $32 incl $13.50 shipping.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favorite games with easy rules and very approachable, particularly as traitor mechanic is optional (although game will not reach full potential without it). Beautiful game with excellent components. Different abilities allow players to contribute in different ways. Recommend playing without traitor until group is familiar with rules and mechanics otherwise, an inexperienced player may be confused for a traitor and affect overall enjoyment. Good theme, but not applied too heavily. Quests are solved essentially by playing sets of cards, so easy to understand, but may be thematically disappointing to some for its abstract mechanic. No walk in the park, but probably easier to win than Pandemic (and the traitor will win if the players lose, so there's always that.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Love the coop with a hidden traitor mechanic

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Fun Factor: 8
Components: 10
Theme: 10
Mechanics: 7 (Mechanics are almost TOO simplistic)
Theme + Mechanics: 8
Replay Value: 8
Scaling/Players: 9

Possibly THE best cooperative game to play with children.  Teaches teamwork, strategy, goalsetting and even has a traitor element to help with deduction and motivation.  It is not surprising I find this to be one of the best family games out there.  Only (mild) weakness to this game is a lack of depth for those of us that need our brain burner meds on an IV drip.  With kids, it is just the right amount.  And if you are that bored, just deal yourself the traitor card ;P

First time we played, King Arthur was the traitor- which was hilarious.

RATING: 8
(10+ plays)  

Who can play?  Strategy game for 3-7 players.

A great cooperative game that is easy to learn and quick to play.  Anyone could like this game, as long as you have someone to teach it to you.  After a few more plays of this game, I still really like it, but it's harder than expected to get new people to like it.  There's something about the reading of the cards and the lack of action that just doesn't hold the attention.  The traitor is the "hook" that makes the game work.  Still, it can be a little predictable sometimes.  I think the game could use one more good "hook".  I hear there's an expansion in the works . . .

RATING: 8
A great game with 4+ Players and a good co-operative mechanic that builds real tension. You realise quickly that every action counts.

Can be played solo but this eliminates the traitor which kind of helps with the tension.

Plays in about an hour and not for dummies so you probably want Adults playing. I like the Camelot theme and the artwork and production quality of the components inspired me to paint them.

A great game for great company.

RATING: 7.5
Tense, difficult co-op game that has the thrills of BSG but at only 90 minutes. Sure the card poker mechanic isn't as thematic as cylons and attacking starships, but Camelot is easier to grasp and has gorgeous artwork and components. 

Plus it's short length means it will get to the table more often. So it scratches that traitor-cooperative game itch and is generally more satisfying than The Resistance, Saboteur, Werewolf. So certainly a game worth trying. Have to try Dark Moon and see how it compares to this and it also offers that much-wanted BSG fun under 2hrs.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nice and very simple coop. The traitor mechanic feels nice, but I think this works better in games like "Battlestar Galactica". The role of the traitor after the mid game can be very limited. A good thing about this game is that it will easily fit 8 players, without them dying of boredom between turns, since the mechanics of each turn are so simple.

RATING: 7
An unusual card-driven cooperative boardgame.  Best with five or more players; and I'd reccommend not using the traitor for the first few games.  On the one hand, there are some mechanics that still concern me, such as the preponderance of seige engines after you snag Excalibur.  And it's crucial that the group observe the communication rules, otherwise the game is far too easy.  But I gotta admit, the enthusiam my family shows for this game is undeniable.

Good fun if everyone is on the same page. It can be quite difficult, but as long as everyone "Get's into it" it's a lot of fun. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
With less players, you have fewer starting resources and less flexibility. This makes the game a lot harder with fewer players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Beautiful cooperative game. High production quality. Needs a high number of people to play, or it will be very hard or unfun; it does have some balance issues. Playing Shadows over Camelot is a fun, and (with the traitor) often tense experience, but I feel it lacks depth and replayability and feels mechanical without offering interesting choices. It also often takes too long, and the game can drag when you reach the endgame.

Shadows over Camelot is probably a good game for a large group, with non-gamers, who might be engaged enough with all the social interaction going on, and aren't as bothered by the lack of choices and variety. But, the rules can be quite overwhelming on your first play, so I don't think it will be succesful as a gateway game. You might as well play werewolf.

The traitor is a brilliant idea, that could have been implemented a lot better. And it's the game's only highlight (ok, I enjoy the fact that it's non-linear too). The games of Shadows I played were fun, but when I'm in the mood for a coop game (not that often), I can't see myself picking Shadows over games with a more immersive feeling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Several plays in and you can definitely see the bones of Knizia's Lord of the Rings co-op game underneath all the chrome/armour. I appreciate that the traitor element really provides the social fun which LOTR lacks, but SoC has some chinks when I compare both designs. The most noticeably thing is how textual in rules explanation and execution in Camelot, whereas Knizia has stripped his design almost bare, which I'm all for, for pace sake. Already after the first game, knights were already discussing some short term strategy, where as the hobbit's life involves more long term planning and thought; and with LOTR you can finish the game once someone is eliminated. Played mostly 4 player sessions which feels about right, 5 players would be a stretch turn based wise I think though I would like to try 3 player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
-

This is an entertaining cooperative game with the twist that one of the Knights could be a traitor. This feature makes the game much more interesting, adds tension by making the players suspicious of one another and keeping them guessing whether there is a traitor and if yes, who?

I'm not particularly fond of cooperative games, so I'm being very generous with a 5. I'm yet to play Lord of the Rings.
05/25/06 Update: Rating reduced from 7 to 5. Probably won't play this again.

RATING: 7
Cooperative game with a possible traitor in the midst! Players take on the role of knights at the round table and aim to keep Camelot secure from the Pict and Saxon attacks while embarking on quests to defeat the Black Knight, capture Lancelot's armour, The Holy Grail, and Excalibur, all of which endow the knights with special powers. 

Like other Days of Wonder productions, Shadows over Camelot has a high production value with a brilliant game board and detailed miniatures.

RATING: N/A

We got him.

That was a great session.

Tentative rating: 10/10

The traitor's options are too limited and so are the knights, in my opinion. Also, the game is too easy to win (Yes, I would like to try the expansion).

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is awesome. I love cooperative games, and this one is cooperative -- but with a traitor twist. It's always fun to see how people react to being the traitor, and it's fun to play because there is so much happening on the board and so many different fronts that need to be managed that it's easy to sabotage. On the other hand, when you aren't a traitor, it's still fun because things always feel as if they are on the brink of spinning out of control, and it takes a lot of group planning to figure out how to best approach the problem -- especially since you can't directly talk about what you're going to do. Love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
