RATING: N/A
8 Players, co-op with 2 traitors
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very interesting dynamic in that this is a cooperative boardgame.  Lots of player interaction but in a way that is very tense for everyone involved... especially if you have a lot of type "A" personalities.  The theme is evoked primarily through magnificent art and player interaction more so than game mechanics.  In other words, most of the time, you ARE taken in with the theme... but the immersion is about 85% complete.  Sometimes there is a nagging realization that crops up where you are cognizant you are playing what is essentially a card game.  

But liked I said, the game has much tension (which is very surprising for a cooperative game) and most of the time you are well immersed in the theme.  The components are outstanding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Best game of 2005.

People say that they get tired of the game - well, it hasn't happened to me yet, and I can't see it happening either.  What you have is a neat co-operative "beat the system" game, and I can see how you could get tired of that.  But there's also a "Werewolf" type game running in parallel.  Even if you have a foolproof way to beat the game system (unlikely, due to the random card distribution in the decks), you still have to deal with the Werewolf - sorry, Traitor.

AND it's a really top-notch production.  The only citicism is the plastic box insert isn't perfect.  And since getting the oainted knights, I don;t have anywhere to store my Quest artifacts. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've played this game over 50 times and have NOT ONCE played with the traitor. I love the idea of a traitor mechanism, and this was one of the first games to offer that feature. However, it is kind of flawed in its execution. The traitor seems to be more powerful if revealed and so it makes little sense to even try to hide the fact. WITHOUT the traitor the game can be hard enough and is easily modified with various starting health, optional "squire" phase, etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very good material, good cooperative experience
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A role playing game, without the creative freedom, in card form - with a board attached, so as to get a boardgame classification. Plenty of eye-candy to attract the bowerbirds of boardgame collectors.

Bowerbird:
1. any of various birds of the Australian region whose males build ornamented structures resembling bowers in order to attract females.
2. informal; chiefly Australian; a collector of unconsidered trifles.

Loving fantasy and medieval art, architecture, etc., I am a clear sucker for such themed games; however, the eye-candy in this game was not enough to make me wish to possess my own copy, let alone play it more than once or so per year once I actually got to sit down and play it.

The game can be fun, but it just takes too long. About 30 minutes of fun, 30 minutes of thinking, after which it starts to get tedious. Downtime can be a drag.

Perhaps my rating will go up when I play the game a few more times; then again, there is a possibility that the rating could go down each time I play it. I both like and dislike the game... a few more goes will decide the tilt of the scales.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Beautiful looking and really good. Though the gameplay itself isn't really that thematic, the artwork and tabletalk makes up for it. Insanely difficult, though. Or maby we're just horrible players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very interesting game. The quality of the components is through the roof. Unfortunately, the gameplay suffers from balance problems, and too-limiting of options. There just aren't enough choices to make. LotR is a much stronger game from that standpoint. I think SoC's biggest flaw is that the Traitor has little ability to actually affect the outcome. It's so obvious if they are doing any unheroic actions, that even the Excalibur quest is suspicious.

Update: After a completely different play, the game impressed me with the menace the engine can provide, even with 7 players. It beat us with sub-optimal play even without much Traitor influence. It showed me that you have to be efficient to easily beat the game.
Raised score an entire point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I absolutely love this game but my gaming group...not so much. What really drew me into the game was the theme. I really enjoy playing as one of the knights of the round table.

On the other hand, a few of my friends felt that they didn't have enough flexibility in the kind of actions they could make each turn. They actually ended up having their knight sit in the same spot and keep playing the same cards every turn; not a very satisfying experience for them.

To this day, I have not been able to see how this game plays with traitors because most groups I played with had trouble beating the game without traitors. I think that having that additional level of gameplay would break up the tedium of "I sit on the grail quest and keep playing grail cards every turn because we keep drawing evil grail cards".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I very nice game. I always love the Arthurian theme.

I could have won as the traitor, but forgot all of the choices you can take to start your turn. Its always hard for me to be the "odd" role when learning a game for the first time.

RATING: 7
Nice cooperative game with a little twist (traitor) that makes a huge difference. The potential traitor stirrs up the gameplay quite a bit and at least in our gaming groupe there are constant discussions who the traitor might be. Apart from that gameplay is basicaly card management. But it's tense to discuss the strategy and it is not so easy to win this game. But there are some people who find the gameplay totally boring since your actions are quite limited when you are at a quest: you simply lay a card down. I believe it is only interesting if you care about every move your comrades are doing and if you take part in the discussion what would be the best move next. If you don't care what's going on with the rest of the gang, it's boring.

3-7 Players. Coop. All Vs. 1/Coop. All (Variable) 90' Fantasia medieval a Camelot, companyerisme, deducció, joc en grup, quests... Són algunes mostres de tot el que ofereix aquest joc.

Sota el majestuós cel blau, ferm en la terra jo estic.
En la boira a l'entorn, una bèstia està rugint dins meu.
Trèmol, la crin en flames, talla l'aire el cavall blanc.
Novament, a dintre meu l'animal rugeix. 
Coratge dona'm senyor, deixa'm cridar fort.
Llibertat i raó, amor, fraternitat, amb gran fervor i afany, ho aconseguiré.

El Rei Artur.

RATING: 5
My enjoyment of the game is slowly declining. The first couple times you play, you are amazed with so many factors.

It's a cooperative game, it fits a lot of players, it has RPG elements, quests and rewards. The art is great and there's just a lot going on.

As you play it a lot however, the game becomes fairly mechanic. The traitor mechanic is the only redeeming part at this point.

Explaining this game to new players is a headache. The overall game is fairly simple: do a bad and a good action on your turn, 12+ swords with white a majority wins the game.

There's just too many side rules like, "if you leave a solo quest, the white cards disappear.", or "cards in the game must be discarded face down.". etc.

SoC is mechanically bland, drags on too long and gives players very little true decision making. Traded away our copy to prevent in-fighting amongst the group and frustrating game nights.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've always wondered at the expression that a game "takes too long for what it is". I mean, it is what it is, how can it possibly take too long?

Then I played Shadows over Camelot and came to understand. Played with a decent number of players this is two hours plus of assembling poker hands with the odd dice roll thrown in. It's great for about the first hour and bit, and then it starts feeling, well, too long for what it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is a nicely themed semi co-operative game with a lot of interesting stuff and a fun, tense endgame. But the problem is how it actually plays for the rest of the game.

It can easily last for 2+ hours. During that time you might find yourself just sitting in one location on the map discarding a card each turn. That can literally be almost everything you do, apart from discussion with players.

Other parts of the game are better, such as helping other players make decisions (albeit based on scant information) or trying to discern which players are traitors (ones with a secret goal to saboutage the others).

The game has fun moments and some surprises. There are plenty of interesting cards that make magical, heroic or awful things happen. It satisfyingly raises the tension towards the end of the game, when players invariably find themselves on the brink of disaster because of all the evil enemies emerging from the board.

I'm not happy with the co-operation system. It involves an essential - but VERY awkward - ruling that permits you to only *broadly* describe what you have in your hand of cards (which is hidden). It is very difficult to apply that rule consistently and it is very open to individual interpretation. Many players will try to hint heavily about what cards they have in order to help the group win. In our group certain supposedly vague phrases inadvertantly became code (i.e. "I can continue on this quest for A BIT longer" or "MUCH longer" or "I will have to stop VERY SOON" etc). That can get frustrating for a traitor player, whose chances of winning plummet if players share too much detail.

Other games have done a similar thing better. Even the arduous Battlestar Galactica is better, if you can stomach the way its deduction process involves a lot of memorising what colour cards people have played etc. Dead of Winter, though not a favourite of mine, is probably better.

Oddly, I still seem to have this game in my collection after many years. I think that's because it does one particular thing very well. It provides a slightly chaotic 'romp' through arthurian dilemmas, which is a very appealing thing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Love the game.  Must have a group who is willing to play "in the spirit" of the game; if naturally Chivalrous, that's all the better!   Very easy to incorporate some optional rules to spice it up... with 4-player, we give each person randomly 2 cards (I have the 8th Knight) and let him pick which one to play.   Some of the variant quests people have added are unique and fun too.   We particularly like the HUNT FOR THE QUESTING BEAST, and have special rules making it Easier to work on that quest when there are LESS players in the game (less players = tougher for Knights to win).

RATING: 4

But there is a disconnect between the mechanics of the game and what it is you're supposed to be doing.  What does collecting four sets of 3 cards have to do with slaying a dragon?  Lord of the Rings outshines this game in the sense that the gameplay mechanics are intimately tied to the theme.  A nice attempt, but ultimately I think this game is too abstract to have real lasting power.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.45
Shadows over Camelot is amongst the very first co-operative games. Each player controls one of the Knights of the round tables, and must undertake various tests (which essentially consist of trying to assemble poker hands) while various timer mechanisms tick away to the final victory of the dark forces.
Yes, Pandemic is more elegant, and Battlestar Galactica does much the same thing but with knobs on. Despite that Shadows is a genuinely clever and involving game.

RATING: 8.5

(07/07/2008) - [8.5] - After playing two games of this today I am hooked. Anyone who thinks this game is only about making poker hands is sorely mistaken. SOLD - (04/11/2017) - Shadows Over Camelot has been sold. It was a great game many years ago, but has since been surpassed by other traitor-mechanic titles.

RATING: 6.5
This had a higher rating, but with the introduction of so many more cooperative and hidden role games to the hobby, it has fallen a notch. Production values are incredible, theme is amazing, but setup, explanation of the different quests, and the chance of a new player getting the traitor and not knowing what to do makes this difficult to bring to the table. I will say the high player count and the fact that people can join mid-game do make this unique and will keep it in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
What I most enjoy about this is the ambiguity I can create in my behavior and gameplay. I spent the last session, where I was loyal, behaving erratically; this was in order to lay the groundwork for future rounds as the traitor. If they were so sure I was the traitor and they were proven wrong, will they be so quick to accuse me in the future?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
(+) The game can host many players and still keep everyone involved for the entire game time
(+) Beautiful artwork, very appealing game and theme
(+) Accessible game: you can play this with your family, your colleages, ... Also occasional players will be interested in this game
(+) The traitor mechanic is very well done, and it's this mechanic which makes the game truly shine
(+) Very high 'fun'-level in a game which still offers some strategic thinking and planning

(-) At the end, it boils down to drawing white and black cards. With luck, the order in which they are drawn raises the chances of the party of Camelot, otherwise they will have a hard to impossible time to defeat evil, no matter what the actions of the traiter might be
(-) With multiple players, the effect of the traitor gets 'dilluted'. Multiple traitors are required in such cases, but this will inevitably result in low chances of success to the party of Camelot, as single player quests do not scale well with the player count and defeating multiple traitors is quite an impossible task :)
(-) After multiple plays, my guess is it would become very hard for a vicious traitor to remain in the shadows. Still, this is a problem we haven't encountered yet, as loyal players often also tend to play a little... strange - always resulting in joyfully misty distrust and deceit


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I hear that this game can lose some of its appeal after many playings, but having played about 5 or 6 times, I haven't gotten there yet. It's still a blast, and one of the best-looking games I own.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Pretty fun cooperative game with a traitor twist. It can get really metagame-y at times, and the ease in which alpha-gaming can take over the game can be a damper to the fun.

Rules (especially those pertaining to hiding information) can be relaxed a bit for a more casual, introductory experience; however, having a traitor negates this back into a tense experience.

Definitely will play; however, would be more prudent in which kind of group this is brought out to.

RATING: 6
It's unclear to me that it's really all that fun to play the Traitor (which always seems to happen to me).  On the one hand, playing sub-optimally while trying to appear to be playing optimally is not easy to do, and if you're doing that, you're probably not playing badly enough to actually hurt the Knights' chances much.  If, on the other hand, you play badly enough and are suspected, it isn't in the Knights' interest to accuse you until the last possible instant, since unmasking the Traitor bestows considerable power upon him.

Add this to the list of cooperative games that still haven't achieved what I think cooperative games are capable of.

RATING: 5
I tried it a second time, and it's ok. What I dislike is that the game takes too long to play. Quests take too long to complete, and I find that the game itself lacks a certain "spark" that makes it fun.

The special abilities of the knights are not all created equal -- it would have been nice if the specials were usable every turn, as opposed to triggering on (relatively rare) events.

There are better co-op games out there now. This is not worth a purchase.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm never usually a fan of cooperative games. Whenever I play them, I feel like I'm on cruise control or autopilot. Other people are making all the decisions for me, since they're more experienced in the game, or they just have a control fetish.
Nevertheless, I get the appeal behind cooperative games. So many frustrating Monopoly arguments from my childhood is living proof that sometimes conflict in games doesn't add to the experience, it destroys it.
Shadows over Camelot however doesn't feel like most cooperative games. You are your own person, I feel like, moving your dude around different quests while trying to help out your fellow Knights of the Round Table to stem the tide of evil.
It has quite a few good systems, and it doesn't just pan down to trading with your partners in order to finish all the tasks. Each person at the table will assume a specific role, no matter what, and each will contribute to finishing the game. Most likely in death, but whatever. Its still a fun game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is one of those games that's relatively easy to explain, but takes a while to really "click".  Still everyone I've introduced it to has enjoyed it.  And I personally enjoy teaching it to those who have never played it.  It will always have a spot in my game closet.

RATING: 9
This game is great with large groups (5+ players) and gets better each time you play with the same people.  The bluffing element to the game really starts to shine when you’ve had experience playing with everyone at the table.

This game is fun for new players as well – the rules are easy to learn, and new players can sometimes be the most successful traitors.  (Your fellow knights will be asking themselves “Is he inexperienced or the traitor?”.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love Days of Wonder games.  This one is a lot of fun even though we have figured out how to beat it practically every time, even when there is a traitor.  I suppose my gaming group should play with the optional "squire" rules to make it a bit tougher, but then we might all lose (except for the traitor).  

I don't have to think back too far when I played this for the first few times, when we lost horribly every game.  We played it several times over several weeks until we finally beat it.  We finally won for the first time when my little brother made some huge mistakes as the traitor by telling us he was the traitor.  He thought he had the card that revealed the traitor to the rest of the players detriment, but he was confused and had a different card (don't remember which anymore).  Anyway, because he let us know he was the traitor, and he didn't have the right card to reveal himself, we voted against him that very next turn and got a white sword.  We all teased him and told him that we couldn't have won without his help.  He got soooo mad.  It was hilarious.  OF course we had fun at his expense, but isn't that the point of overcoming the traitor?

RATING: 8
This has ended up being eclipsed at its own game by Battlestar Galactica, but this is a better game for people who want a more straight cooperative experience, with a little bit of uncertainty thrown in with the traitor. Good family game, and lower complexity than BSG, but it lacks the depth of its younger brother.

*edit* After many years of never wanting to play this again, I recently landed another copy in a trade and was surprised to discover that after all these years, Shadows Over Camelot still holds up pretty well. There is a dearth of family-style traitor games, but Shadows Over Camelot fills that spot quite well. There's enough narrative detail to enjoy it, but the gameplay from turn to turn is very simple and straightforward. Battlestar Galactica is still the better, more engaging game, but as BSG's less relevant license and situational greatness become liabilities, Shadows Over Camelot shows its quality all the more.

RATING: 7
Tamás 

A játékban a kerekasztal lovagjainak bőrébe bújva kell felvenni a harcot Camelot sötét erőivel. Ebből eredően a játék kooperatív. Pontosan csak részben mert nem minden lovag lojális az igaz ügyhöz. 
A játékot 7 lovag tudja játszani (köztük Artúr király). Minden lovagnak van speciális képessége mely egyedibbé teszi a játékosok körét. Igaz kisebb létszámnál is élvezhető de 7 játékosnál igazán izgalmas. 
Minden játékos körében van egy rossz és egy jó fázis. Előny (vagy az árulást tekintve hátrány), hogy lehet választani a rossz fázisban 3, a jó fázisban 4 lehetőség közül. 
Egy szerencsétlen setup-ból pár kör alatt el lehet bukni a játékot de normál esetben az árulónak nincsen könnyű dolga. Igaz ha a többi játékos nem keresi akkor a felfedetlensége előnyt jelent neki a játék végén.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Shadows Over Camelot is a semi-cooperative game where the players are knights of the Round Table; there is a chance that one of the players is a traitor, working against the Round Table, but it is by no means guaranteed.  Each turn the players may take 1 free action or may sacrifice a life point and take 2 actions, but they must always draw a card from the black deck which represents the opposition's actions.  The knights must complete quests thereby winning white swords, but if any quests are lost they gain black swords.  At the end of the game if there are more white than black swords the loyal knights win, otherwise the traitor and/or the game wins.

Since the role of the opposition is played out via a deck of cards the players must coordinate their actions in order to win the game.  Many quests will ebb and flow, and this will add great tension to the decisions.  A wasted decision can spell disaster.  On their turns the players must choose to move to a quest, or play a card from their hand on their current quest location, but if they cannot play a card on their current quest they must move.  Players must think ahead as moving can be a tiresome waste.  Players may also accuse someone of being the traitor, but they are penalized if they get it wrong, however if there is a traitor and he is undiscovered he may convert 2 white swords to black and thus tip the scales.

This is a great cooperative game that has seen many a knight die, a few traitors win, and required active participation by all players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
With all the rules, very hard to teach to casual gamers.  Experienced gamers don't feel that there is enough to the game for the length.

RATING: 4
Seems rather similar to Lord of the Rings in many respects. The fun you have is entirely dependent on what the players bring to the table, which is true of any game I suppose, but this one really relies on a fun group. That doesn't necessarily make it a very good game in my eyes. Another concern I have with this game is the re-playability in terms of variation in the game and in terms of how experienced players will approach the method of playing once they've developed a winning strategy. Finally, the theme doesn't really excite me (I consider the whole theme of King Arthur to be a giant yawn), and therefore the game is running an uphill battle to excite me in the first place.

RATING: 9

Appeals to both gamers and non-gamers alike as players take the role of a Knight of Round Table, trying to complete quests with their compansions befor Camelot falls into darkness.  The twist?  A traitor may be amongst you.  This game uses card management, knowing when and where to play the rare, but powerful cards, and when to hope your weaker cards will succeed.  Absolutely beautiful board and pieces.

RATING: 6.6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife and I generally do not enjoy straight-forward, traditional cooperative board games. For one, the "alpha gamer" problem can be very annoying; hey, it's my turn, so don't tell me what to do. Also, we usually don't feel very satisfied by either winning or losing: if we win, then we all win together which just isn't as interesting (probably because we are selfish).

But I knew Shadows Over Camelot would be different. However, the main question was "would it be different enough for us to like it?" Answer: yes! It is really great.

We played our 5 times over the course of 3 days, teaching new people in 3 of those 5 games. The actions are simple and generally go pretty fast. The quests are abstract, but the graphic design makes them feel unique and interesting, some being solo and some needing multiple people to be successful.

Yet really it's the traitor that matters. This is so great. Who is the traitor? Do we even have one? Everyone has to make shady moves at some point in the game, so it works really well for the traitor to hide in the shadows.

After a couple of plays, I asked my wife if this seemed more like Pandemic (which we don't really like) or more like The Resistance (which we have really enjoyed a lot in the past). We decided it feels more like a hidden identity/bluffing social game than a normal co-op game. And that makes us happy to have it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Elso nagy kedvencek egyike. Itt szerettem a kooperativ jatekmodot es kezdtem el keresgelni az ilyen tipusu jatekokat. Nagyon ajanlott az arulo karakter megletenek a lehetoseget is jatszani mert egy ujabb izgalmas faktort hoz a jatekba. A hos lovagok probalnak kuzdeni a camelot-ot fenyegeto veszely ellen es nagyon sok mulik azon, hogy mennyire tud egyutt mukodni a tarsasag, mennyire tudjak a jatekosok ez egojuk fele helyezni a csapat erdekeit. Relative egyszeru szabalyrendszer es vegig izgalmas jatekmenet. Szeretem nagyon.

Weakness of the game is gamers get bored with not being traitor, and non-gamers can get intimidated by being traitor on their first play. Also not a fun game if people don't get into the theme. Depends a lot on who you play with, and combined with the large player complement, it's hard to get a good group to play this.

RATING: 1.5
Nothing really wrong with the game, but nothing really right with it either. For what is basically a very simple game, there is just too much rules - too much stuff that adds nothing to dynamics of the game. Game flow is too static - this is mostly a co-op and you're having 3 decisions per game, you're just doing one thing over and over again. The traitor element doesn't seem as strong as in BSG for instance, focus here is not so much on what traitor does, but how to discover one (or two). It's a game where good parts (interaction) are buried and hidden under many layers of relatively bland mechanics. Not as overbloated as BSG, but not 1/4 as intriguing either.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
For those who enjoy a good co-op, Shadows over Camelot is a near perfect marriage of the abstract onslaught of Ghost Stories and the deeply thematic "don't know who to trust" zombie apocalyptic Dead of Winter. I know SoC helped pioneer the way for the latter two, but that doesn't mean it's lost any of its luster as board games continue to evolve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Cute. But not much to the mechanics. My group likes it, and people can join or leave in the middle of the game seamlessly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is extremely easy to pick up.  The rules are simple and easily explained, although there are a lot of them.  Gameplay is pretty straight forward and at first it seems like its simply a "luck of the draw" type game, but after 3 games its clear that there really is quite a bit of strategy involved.  

However, this game is extremely difficult.  In the first three games we played, we lost all of them!  The end of the game can get extremely tense and for us it boiled down to this question : "Which way do we want to lose this game?"  That said, this game is a blast to play!  

This was my first collaboration game and the change from competing against everyone else to all trying to work together was extremely satisfying.  I highly reccommend this game if you ever get the chance to play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A nice and simple co-op game. I like this better than Battlestar because the rules are more simple and elegant and the game is easier to learn. It is unfortunately also easier to beat, but everything comes at a price.

RATING: 8

The idea of all the players playing against the game itself is nice, and it works better in SoC than for example in the FFG's Lord of the Rings. I have played games which are "greater", but I usually pick SoC from my bookshelf if I have guests who would like to play boardgames, but don't know too many of them. SoC is simple and quick enough, it's not too competitive (not too serious minded), but there's always much fun when playing it. A very nice game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[4 plays] Not very deep, but a fun social adventure. The strong possibility of a traitor in the midst is the thing that really creates the experience. I didn't feel the need to own this game myself any more, so I sold it, but I enjoy it well enough to get involved almost any time if it is suggested..

I wish the card mechanic was somehow more suited to the the theme than basically forming poker hands, but I still think it is ok. This game has lots of motions, bells, and whistles - but the overall tensions and rewards could be probably achieved for me quicker and better with Pandemic, poker, or Werewolf.

Most recent play 12/8/12 with Michael, Corey, Corey's buddy Sandy, Brian P, Carter, and Donovan. Something about Michael's happy nonchalance placing siege engines gave him away as the traitor to me very early on. Following through on my vow from the previous game, I accused him as soon as it was legal to do so. He was the traitor indeed, but our overall play wasn't helped by the reveal and we lost fairly rapidly anyway. I'm afraid I made the game less fun and tense for everyone, which is a shame that the game can be legally broken this way if an early correct accusation happens.

2nd most recent play 3-14-08 with Carter, Donovan, Alex, Michael, and Garrett. Alex was the traitor, and I was 95% certain, but I failed to accuse him before the game spiraled into the drain.

RATING: 7
This is almost a great game. The components are wonderfully evocative of the theme, but otherwise the theme is thin, in terms of actual gameplay. The cooperation element is welcome, but the traitor function is problematic. A small game with a traitor is impossible to win, and a big game without a traitor is too easy. But some players don't want to be the traitor, and a traitor who has been successfully accused should be eliminated instead of becoming an ongoing hassle.

The last time I played, we had seven players... the game ended in a flurry of inaccurate accusations of the traitor, and Camelot fell even though we didn't actually have a traitor.

RATING: 6.5
Decent enough game, but after just ONE playing on normal mode (i.e. No traitor) it seemed too simplistic.  It only took one play which resulted in a loss to figure out what to do and what not to do.  4 games after that we won landslide victories in our favor.  I guess my expectations were raised after reading multiple session reports of people who had played and played and still not achieved victory.  Oh well, you win some, you lose some.  ;D

The game is MUCH better played with a traitor. It adds a completely random element and makes you second guess everybody else's motives.

But it still feels a little too much like the game is playing itself and I'm just a spectator in the process.

RATING: N/A
Unusual activity-based co-operative game. Mechanical in feel with card management. Not particularly tension-filled despite fighting against the deck and the limited number of actions given. Numbers do matter. Greater numbers of players will tip the game in favour of the Round Table while fewer will assist the traitor if there is one. There is probably an optimal number of players for balance. Game is highly overrated.

My first play was the only one to use the traitor.  We had it rough trying to manage all of the possible quests and it turned out to be a good test of teamwork.  In the end, we suspected a traitor but couldn't afford to be wrong in accusing him.  We should've done it anyway...

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I wanted to love this game, but honestly, I'd rather play most any of my other games first. SoC, to my thinking, is mostly a card game disguised as a board game (which isn't a bad thing - this is just a neutral description of what it is). Players attempt to get runs, pairs, and full houses before the game does nasty things to the Knights of the Round Table. The game is gorgeously produced, but this just doesn't make up for the gameplay and the large amount of downtime. Given the lightness of the game, it also just drags on for far too long for what it is. I love Arthurian legends, high fantasy, etc. But I'd play plain old Rummy or something similar before playing SoC again (hence, I traded it away). Now, granted, these comments are only based on one four player game, so give them whatever weight you feel appropriate. But from where I stand, I've played enough games to make a pretty keen assessment for myself. Being forced to play further games would have only driven my rating of the game down further - so I got out while I was ahead.

I am sensitive to the point that this is an "experience" game. Despite all our fun quoting Monty Python and making medieval jokes, the "experience" just wasn't that great. For an "experience" game, I'd much rather play Plunder or Pirate's Cove (piratey goodness, arrrgh!), replete with jokes about pinnaces, "arrrr, matey"s, and piratical derring-do - or Lord of the Rings, which provides very tense, thematic fun.

Update: Well, a second play with more people who know the game better sees my feelings about the game drop EVEN further. I feel as if, during this second play, I saw the game at its best. That said, my biggest problem with Shadows is the lack of meaningful decisions. There are no "deliciously difficult choices" to be made in this game, from my perspective. Couple that with the fact that one's turn often consists only in moving from the Round Table to a quest or playing a single card (with no immediate effect), and watching other people make similarly banal moves, and you get a recipe for ho-humming. Even with a traitor (or more correctly, the possibility of one), Shadows just has no where *near* the tension for me that Knizia's Lord of the Rings does. The latter game I have played a bunch of times now, and get so much more out of. When Shadows was released, many people made the claim that it borrowed things from LotR: the corruption track becomes the black vs. white swords, and so forth - but they are very different cooperative games to my mind. Objectively, after two plays I'd say that SoC is a better game than I first thought - perhaps on a purely objective scale it would get a 6 from me. But I don't want to play it any more than I did after my first play. When this game debuted on the Geek, it was quite the darling. I obtained it right after it was published and didn't see what the fuss was about. Ironically, I kept wondering how so many other people could find SoC so fun and engaging, and I could not. What was wrong with me?!? The hivemind of Geekland now reveals, of course, that I was/am not alone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Game was fun for awhile, but after playing it enough the game started to get old and the length and other mechanisms starting to hurt it.  The expansion helped its life and I got a good amount of plays out of it but it is never played anymore.  Other games do the traitor element better like Battlestar Galactica and Dead of Winter.  

The traitor element is just poorly designed.  If the traitor gets lucky and gets the card to reveal themselves early on then the game is lost.  They can sit there adding catapults every turn and I don't think they can lose.  Otherwise they are playing the game out and most of the time the game doesn't care if you play as a traitor or not.  I have helped the other side as much as possibly even as a traitor and they still lost.  Playing the traitor is just really boring.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
When I first played this game I thought that this game was dry and systematic. I knew that this was undoubtedly an effective and efficient system, but I also felt that the game could run a bit clinical.  

After the first playing I didn't realize how group dependant this game was. I was surprised at how something that should be light fun, in contrast was so cold. 

Then I played this with a completely different group, it was loud and fun and silly.  Lots of accusations and still down to the wire.  Excellent tension as we beat back the odds. 

Ultimately, it is a great experience game, based on a boring contract rummy mechanic. It requires verbal, gregarious people that don't expect much in the way of gameplay.

I'm not sure how the replay on this one is going to be, but this will be an excellent game to pull out a friend's copy once a year and play over a couple bottles of wine.  

(Still, as far as co-operative games go, Arkham Horror beats this, hands down.)

UPDATE: I have nothing against this game, but I have no desire to play this again.

RATING: 7.5
Complexity: Easy-Medium
Players: 3-7 (8 with expansion)
Expansions Owned:  Merlin's Company

Cooperative game with a hidden traitor mechanism.  The game looks intimidating at first, but the gameplay is actually fairly simple and fun and serves as a good way to draw people into the hobby.  I tend to think of this as a lighter alternative to BSG and Dead of Winter.  One drawback is that I think this game would actually get less good the more plays a group has, since suboptimal play would be a dead giveaway for the traitor.

Oh, and it has *great* components.

RATING: 8

We had to engineer a situation to finish with 13 swords so that we could survive a traitor revelation. I must confess that the game is starting to wear a bit after several plays. It may be time to toss in some expert rules. On a recent game, we seriously curtailed table talk to the point where we didn't voice the need for help on multi-knight quests nor hinted to Arthur what cards we needed. This made the game more difficult, and the traitor won.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a cooperative game with a hidden traitor much in the same vein as Battlestar Galactica.  There is one key difference with that mechanic that sets this game apart from other games like BSG though, no matter how many players you play with there is always a chance there is no traitor in the game.

In games like BSG you know there is at least one traitor among you and you know how many possible ones there can be.  You might not know who or even when they start working against you but by being observant and discerning enough you should be able to figure out who they are.  In this game there is always a max of 1 traitor and with any player number may not be any.  With more players there is more chance of there being a traitor of course because more of the 8 role cards are handed out, but even with 7 there is still that chance.

This gives the game a sense of delightful paranoia because catching the traitor before he is revealed can be beneficial to the team but accusing a fellow knight of being a traitor has serious consequences.  So not knowing if anyone at all is even working against you has you double-guessing the signs you see and perhaps even seeing signs that aren't there and I love it.

Past that the game is standard cooperative fair.  Players each have a special ability, spend a certain number of action points on their turn, and are smacked around by an event deck each turn.  The game is won by obtaining sword tokens and these are obtained by completing different kinds of mini-games on the map.  This is entertaining enough but the real game is the mind games of trying to figure out if there is a traitor and if so, who.

Even without a traitor, this game is HARD.  If your game does have a traitor in it, it may be almost unwinnable because you are not only playing against the game but also this player and have one less player on your side and who knows how long or how badly he has been sabotaging you.

Everything I've said above is true but I've become less and less a fan of this game with each subsequent play.  I love the "there might or might not be a traitor" mechanism in the game because it does create the delightful feeling of paranoia even when there may not even be a traitor among you.  I just wish it were attached to a better game.  The decisions aren't as interesting as I would like them to be and this game has a lot of downtime when it isn't your turn as there is very little else to do.  Plus it tends to take quite a while, which is never a good combination with large swaths of downtime. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
This game is extremely well-balanced, and kudos for clear rules and the amount of attention and care given to the art design, which in addition to being beautiful offers any number of little visual aids to playing the game and remembering what's what--though the rules are pretty easy to learn. Some aspects of the game come off to some as little more than a card game akin to rummy or multi-player solitaire, but there's so much debate about what to do next when we play that we don't mind. Easy to learn, easy to teach, and always a suspenseful ride. Plays just fine solo.

RATING: 7
Not a bad experience.  It's a good co-op because it's light enough for most people to pick up, yet treacherous due to the traitor mechanic.  I've seen quite a few games lost because of errant accusations earlier in the game.

The thing holding it back, ultimately, is its simplicity.  Playing full houses and straights isn't much of a game mechanic and decisions are often obvious.  Got 3 or more grails?  Go to the grail quest.  Got nothing that matches?  Go to the Excalibur quest.  I don't think there's anything inherently wrong with that, but the game feels very samey after a while.  It mostly boils down to lack of interactivity.  The game feels like it would be more fun if you had more to do than just lay cards down.

RATING: 7
A thematic, gateway, collaborative game that is ideal for larger groups. This is great fun and very interactive. The only issue I have with it, is that it gets somewhat repetitive after you play it a few times. So it ends up not being played as often simply because it becomes a second tier choice for the evening. But not so if you have a large group (say 6 players). I always play it with the traitor, which is what makes the game tremendous fun. The fact that you may have a traitor among your fellow mates, makes all the difference. The components are top quality and beautiful. There aren't many other games quite like this one! Guaranteed group fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a very cool co-operative game with a delicious little twist.  The twist, of course, being the possibility that one player is a traitor.  And what a remarkably well-done game it is!  Everything from the design of the game itself to the physical components has received a lot of tender loving attention to detail, which of course is standard fare from Days of Wonder.  The first glance at the 2 rule books might be initially intimidating, but after a single read-through of both books I felt like I had such a good grasp on the game that it seemed as if I had already played it.  The fact is, learning the game is surprisingly simple, even though the rules could have been slightly better organized between the 2 books.  It is mastering the game that is the deceptively difficult part.  After a 7-player and a 6-player game, both with traitors, and a traitorless 4-knight 2-player game, I still have not achieved a victory.  [Edit: I finally won a game with a traitorless 4-player game.]  And I'm glad it is so challenging - I would not want it to be easily beaten.  My only quibble with the game is the fact that a revealed traitor is still quite powerful, which doesn't leave enough incentive for the traitor to remain undiscovered, and the role of the undiscovered traitor then becomes fairly boring.  Game design: 4.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 4/5  Total: 8.5/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Decent enough card-engine co-op game with typically absurd Days of Wonder overproduction. It's OK, I just don't understand why you would want to play it: as clearclaw's comment here says, it's just flipping cards and doing pointless things while the game plays itself.

I'm not averse to playing against an entropy generator, but Camelot has none of the elegance of Pandemic, nor the brilliant immersion of Space Alert. The traitor mechanism does add a little spice, which is all that saves the game from an even worse rating.

RATING: 7
Very good theme play.  Fairly easy to learn, but easy to play.  Game play offers many choices and is challenging.  Many of the characters have interesting abilities.  Game play is heavily dependent on the dark forces card draw - the game can be too tough and very short at times.  The traitor element adds another dimension to the game without being overpowering.  The components are of excellent quality - mounted board, plastic playing pieces & somewhat durable cards.  Rulebook is clear.  Game length is not consistent.

RATING: 7
[several plays] It has been a fun game to play.  A good unique cooperative game.  A few times it has been super tight games down to the wire game.  This means there have been very fun exciting finishes. It has a good simple interface for how the cards and quests work.  However, at some point the fact that it is a game about drawing and playing the right cards keeps this game from being great, and being a game I want to play all the time.  At its core it seems like it is mostly a card drawing exercise to get the right combinations of cards to defeat the quests.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[DoW 2005 edition] {Medieval; cooperative with internal competition, secret identity, variable-player-power, player elimination, hand management; scalable} SoC is a very good gateway game. It has a strong theme and is very true to the original story. Players are just engaged in the game. Excellent player interaction: full of chats, cooperation and even intrigue. It needs a very good teamwork, esp. with more players, to win. They have to plan their actions and properly assign knights to quests.

It takes some time to teach the rules but the players can master the rules after first few rounds. Usually, the first play is a mess but it's getting better and funnier with more plays. 

I prefer playing it with this variant: turning over white swords, instead of adding black swords when losing a quest. It makes the game more tactical and exciting.

SoC is scalable. With more players, it becomes more difficult to control a quest because black cards appear faster in a quest and the knights may not react in time. With fewer players, it becomes easier to control a quest, but the power of traitor is stronger. Therefore, regardless of the number of players, SoC is alike challenging. 

The traitor shall have good bluffing skill in order to win. It's a good rule that a traitor is not out of game even if he is revealed; o/w, it's much more difficult for a traitor to win. Besides, the knights have to judge if it's good to accuse a traitor even though they know who he is.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First cooperative game that I've enjoyed. Less processional than Lord of the Rings, excellent theme, components and the ganging together to complete certain quests have created  great do or die camaraderie in the group. The the Strategy is very deep but there is certainly enough to challenge the group. The order in which the black cards appear together with the combination of white cards that you get make for a surprisingly different game most times. Excellent roll play and theme; superb components and a great mid weight strategy game.
While it takes the most enoyable aspects of patience as a basis it develops this hugely into a more varied, strategic, co-operative and altogether satisfying game. 
It's certainly not intensive stategy. However I like how some of the turns flow fast when you know what you need to do and others require more careful consideration.
The fact that you can see all the quests building up on each turn adds to the sense of impending doom.

My only concern is whether there is enough in the game to make it last.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Coop

I have over 20 games of this under my belt with various people and each time it was a hit.  I had to go out and purchase card sleeves as the cards were starting to get worn out.  Although not as easy to introduce as Ticket to Ride this is a game that works GREAT for new boardgamers once you get through the first few turns.  If you plan on trying to play this cerebrally - forget it.  This is a game of twister, not chess.  It is more about player interaction and subversion than min/maxing the cards.  If your group plays socially - this is a game you should simply NOT let pass by.

Update:  Time and more coop games have moved this down my rating.  Still a good gateway game for introducing to new players but I prefer to pull out games like Pandemic or Ghost Stories over this one now.

RATING: 8

Oddly it%u2019s almost a sort of basic cardgame with more going on.  I saw very few things about this game that I didn't enjoy, everything worked well, and everyone had a good time even though we lost.  I love that the traitor is has so little chance of being there but you always question the other players actions.  The pieces are very well produced and eye catching. I would vote for this to be the best game of 2005 simply because I had so much fun.

Addendum: Played it again and won this time, still alot of fun.  I do find it a little too long though.

RATING: 8

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Days of Wonder usually hit a sweet spot for me.  The games have a good enough mixture of mechanics and fun to keep me interested, but are sufficient accessible that I can table them in any company.  Shadows over Camelot is no exception.

The mechanics here are pretty bare-bones, and if people take too long agonizing over the small number of decisions that are made the game can get a bit tedious, but on the flip side the game accommodates 7 (with drop-in/drop-out at any time), and moves enough of the interesting information onto the cards and into the player's hands that there isn't the same scope for one player to quarterback the whole team (c.f. Pandemic, for instance).

As with any "coop-with-a-optional-traitor" games, you have to decide whether to put in a possible traitor on a first game.  For Shadows, the mechanics are simple enough that a first-time player who pulls the traitor card is probably going to be able to be an effective traitor without having to ask rules questions that will obviously reveal his disloyalty.

Includes Merlin's Company expansion

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Culled - First wave; Comics Place contribution

Why we culled it: SoC is a powerful sign of its times. It is a co-op game that wears its theme in great detail, and it serves as a wonderful soft entry point to the hidden-traitor mechanism. It is very much a classic co-op - The board is a puzzle rigged to defeat you, and it does very well until you solve that puzzle. Then the game becomes a walk in the park for the quarterback who ushers the team to victory, and a chore for the rest. Hidden traitors spice up the game to some extent, but the traitors lack a robust playground to do much relative to games with similar systems. SoC is perhaps the best gateway into games like BSG, but once you're playing BSG, it loses most of its relevance. I donated it to a game shop where it sees a lot of play, so I'm happy.

RATING: 1
This is not a game.  There are no real decisions to make, no problems to solve, not even a clever mechanic to enjoy.  It is shameful how much hype this title has garnered, and it demonstrates an enormous gulf between gamers who wish to actually "game," versus those who seem satisfied with spectacle and atomospherics.

If games were dates, this one is a dumb blond.

RATING: 6
I really enjoy many aspects of this game after a first play through especially the decisions with advancing evil. Playing Dead of Winter before this has given me an appreciation for this as a more simplified/streamlined traitor game. I'm looking forward to playing this more. 

*Update* The first time my group played this it was fun at times but dragged, at first I put this down to a first play but after a second play I've come to the conclusion the game just isn't that interesting. The game is very simple perhaps too simple and it often leads to players feeling like they have no really decisions to make on their turn. The game also fails at having any tension as the pace of the game is so slow at times that you can see you've failed 7 or 8 turns ahead and its just merely a formality. The game is also far too long for what it is and I think many other social deduction games such as the Resistance can give you the same fun in a much quicker time frame. This game is hitting my trade list I'm sure many people enjoy it but for my group its fallen flat.

3) Can be a little to 'gamey' ie: Once we needed to fail a quest ASAP in order to win the game(just to fill the table with swords)

RATING: 9
A great classic. The traitor mechanic is everything in this game so make sure you have a high chance of drawing one. The different characters are fun. The card play is okay. The theme is cool but the mechanics are largely unrelated to these. Strategy gets a bit repetitive in this after many plays. 

Between this and Dead of Winter - I strongly prefer this with 4+ players and DoW with at most 4 players. This one flows very smoothly regardless of a high player count. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fantastic "introductory" semi-cooperative game (a game where it's the group vs. the board plus a secret traitor). Your enjoyment will be greatly enhanced if your play group gets into the flavor of being Knights of the Round Table and going out on glorious quests. Otherwise, the game play can be kind of dry. You basically just draw cards and then decide what the most efficient way to play your cards so that they match up with the quests.

Once people are comfortable with this, they should "graduate" to the granddaddy of epic semi-cooperative games, Battlestar Galactica.

RATING: 7
I love the production quality of this game.  The components are beautiful and the theme is really well done (and immediately understandable by new people).

The balance is pretty good too.  We lost the first couple of games - just trying to do everything at once.  But now, even with some beginners playing, we can pretty much get it each time - although it can be a close thing.

I still haven't played with an experienced traitor though - waiting to see how that changes the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoyed playing Shadows; it seemed to strike the right balance with its difficulty level and fun factor.

I think the real success of this game is that the Knights must work together in order to achieve the objectives.  If they try to run off and do each quest piecemeal, they are toast.

I've played it with Merlin's company, and enjoyed the traveling cards, Merlin's presence, and the new Knights.  

Update 11/20/09: I've heard it said in various reviews and comments that Pandemic is a superior cooperative experience; rubbish!  Shadows over Camelot may be a little older, but it is a much better cooperative game that rewards strategy and gives you waay more options as a player.

RATING: 8
A fun semi coop game thats super hard. Mechanically, there isnt much going on you're playing cards down one at a time. But when you add the traitor into the game, it brings so much to the game. The core to this game is that player interaction. The more subtle mechanism in the game can lead to great, what i like to call, advance techniques where there are many actions that you can do that can go both ways as a honourable knight and evil traitor would do the exact same way; adding to the semi coop feel to the game.

With that said, it is still a fun game, but not the first game I am grabbing out of the game closet.

I don't know. I still really can't find anything wrong with the game--to me it is great game on my most treasured traits: interaction, interesting decisions, and fun. allows for really clever thinking.

I guess it is just that it has a hard time finding an audience. too heavy for nubes, too lacking for a seasoned group to pull out repeatedly. I love it, but others seem more tepid and that makes it hard to play enough.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In most games, players compete against each other to achieve victory. Shadows over Camelot proposes a journey of a very different kind, where you and your fellow players, as Knights of the Round Table, will collaborate to jointly defeat... the game!
At first glance, this task seems simple enough. After all, shouldn’t a band of young and noble Knights - fleet of foot and sound of mind - easily defeat a game that plays itself? Alas your quest is further complicated by the ever-present possibility of a Traitor in your midst, biding his time, waiting to strike at the worst possible moment...
But enough words... Don your cloak, climb astride your warhorse and gallop into the Shadows to join us in Camelot!

RATING: 6

RATING: 6.5
First thoughts:  Fantastic.  Somehow better than Lord of the Rings, because the theme and the game itself are more open to interest from others.  Plays quickly and well, with enough battling the game, ability to try tactics and intrigue in the traitors actions to provide a great balance.
However, it takes a couple of plays for folk to understand the dynamic etc, which is needed before adding the traitor.  These couple of plays can make or break it for people and can feel like hard work.

Second thoughts:  Hard work to teach newbies.  Only really works when everyone knows what they're doing and when 7 people have that, is this the game they'll want to play?  Somewhere, this SHOULD be a great game.  Somehow, it just doesn't work out that way.  I'll keep trying tho and kinda like it...

RATING: 6
Brilliant design, excellent production, perfect theme. Looks complicated but systematically easy to learn and manage. Gameplay involves teamwork, intrigues, and smart decisions. Suitable for more players, say 7. Repeated gameplay within the same game group will however make the interest level drops because players tend to cheat or exploit the game systems. Suggested to play with different game group, with guranteed fun and tension.
I give this game a decreasing rating. Hope a future expansion may address and fix the game problems.

RATING: 6.5
Played twice (with four and five players) and really liked it. Ultimately, I think it is better that Lord Of The Rings (that other co-op game), mainly because you really feel like you are spreading your forces thin across many battles and constantly have to choose where to step in next. The art on the boards and on the cards is beautiful and the feeling of control is really much better than I anticipated. It is rock hard though...even without a traitor! I do have some doubts about its replayability.
UPDATE: After my third game, I had enough. Been there, done that. There are definitely better co-op games out there.

RATING: 6
12/2008:4

I wanted to like this game in the beginning, really wanted it, but not anymore. 5 plays later, this game is just too much hype. The cooperative mode is fine, but to expect people to kinda talk about what they have and try to conceal it is silly at best. In addition, the game is quite tough for newbies and losing in order to win the game is really bad. Hmm, on second thoughts, I think I will pass on buying this game.

OK, I finally manage to trade for this game and will give it another go. It can't be that bad, right?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Man, do I have mixed feelings about this one! On one hand, the overwhelming feeling of gloom and despair are really captured by the mechanics of the game: so much goes wrong or is just barely averted. 

On the other hand, the very fact that the game is about struggling vainly against overwhelming odds means that I hardly ever feel happy or accomplished when I play and win/lose. It's such a soul-crushing exercise in despair (even when you win a quest, it makes other bad things happen faster) that I hardly ever have fun. 

This wouldn't be a problem if I only ever played this and Red November (and even then, at least Red November is humorous!), but the fact that I can get better game play and a feeling of hope and accomplishment from Pandemic just makes SoC an absolute slog.

It's a well put together game, but it personally takes away any joy I have in playing games, which is the main reason I do so!

RATING: 6
I thoroughly enjoy this game.  The traitor mechanic adds a lot in terms of the suspicion of other players.  Games are often, but not always, tense at times.  When this tension comes at the end of the game and you pull out a win, this game provides a game moment like few others.  
Be warned, though, this is not a pure strategy game - it is more of a cooperative adventure game in the style of Lord of the Rings (obviously) and Betrayal at House on the Hill.  If you're looking for something along the lines of Puerto Rico or Princes of Florence, this is not it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I absolutely love Shadows over Camelot. The reason why I like it so much is because of all the player interaction that is involved and the hesitations you have because somebody might be the traitor. 

Everybody is a knight of Camelot with a special role and you go out to compete task to get more white swords than black swords. Some tasks are solo while others are cooperative. It seems from the very beginning that things are going against you, however the game would be too easy if there wasn't a traitor. It's actually not that difficult to play the traitor however and you can be very subtle while still ensuring the other team loses. Each quest does not use great mechanics, most are either getting poker hands or discarding certain cards, but I don't think that's really the point of the game. 

The point of the game is trying to figure out who the traitor is because they are doing sketchy things and to try to explain why you are doing what you are doing. My favorite coop for sure. Been playing a bit much lately though, so will need to slow down as to not get burn out. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I played the game twice, each time with 7 players.  The knights lost both times, first due to lack of cooperation (no traitor) and second to wily play of the traitor snatching victory at the end.  Very much enjoyed it, look forward to our next session.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great game.  Gets better the more comfortable people are with it.  It can be a bit of a drag and baptism by fire for first timers.  

I have to agree with so many of the comments.  Beautiful, engaging game.  Fun, frustrating mechanics.  Rage inducing time wasting trying to tell if that one weird friend of yours is the traitor because he's behaving like he might be, but he may just be weird and WHY WOULD YOU BEHAVE THAT WAY IF YOU'RE A GOOD GUY, YOU JACK***!?!?!  

Very fun times.  Always excited to get it to table,  I bought it long ago based on reviews that called it "An Essential" for co-op fans and I think they were entirely correct.

RATING: 8
Beautiful components.  Quite the fun little lark if you know some Arthur fans.  Relies on following the spirit of the game, so don't play this with dry min-maxers.  I can't stomach too many plays of this one over a short period of time, but I really enjoy trotting this one out every now and then.  It almost always makes for a light-hearted but tense game that everybody enjoys.  Great for introducing new gamers to the hobby, particularly those who have a predilection for fantasy themes.  I only wish I had the skill and materials to give these minis the paint job they deserve to make this game REALLY shine.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm a little torn as to how I want to rate this game.  It was fun, and I enjoyed the experience, enough to want to rate it a 7.  It just made me realize -- after thinking that the game had a similar feel to Arkham Horror and Pandemic -- that cooperative games are all similar in nature.  I suppose that's the nature of the genre, that you have to have bad events that pile up over time to make solving the game a challenge, but it makes me wonder what the next big breakthrough in cooperative games will be.  The traitor element makes it a little more interesting, but I wonder if there's enough that he can do to muck up the progress of the knights, since the knights won in the one game we played.

1 play: 6 players

RATING: 6
My first three plays of this, with four players, were gripping. My fourth play, with six, was considerably less enjoyable; downtime increased, as did the interest of one's own role in the game -- with less players, each player has more demand to be flexible which leads to more involvement in the game. I think this plays well with four, and it's a good game, but I'm no longer sure that it's a /very/ good game.

RATING: N/A
In most games, players compete against each other to achieve victory. Shadows over Camelot proposes a journey of a very different kind, where you and your fellow players, as Knights of the Round Table, will collaborate to jointly defeat... the game!
\13\\13\
At first glance, this task seems simple enough. After all, shouldn’t a band of young and noble Knights - fleet of foot and sound of mind - easily defeat a game that plays itself? Alas your quest is further complicated by the ever-present possibility of a Traitor in your midst, biding his time, waiting to strike at the worst possible moment...
\13\\13\
But enough words... Don your cloak, climb astride your warhorse and gallop into the Shadows to join us in Camelot!

RATING: 9.5
This is a fun co-operative game, and is fairly quick, compared to Lord of the Rings, and Arkham Horror.  Though I played with many groups, it seems to be straight forward once people grock the winning strategy, so it's more fun with inexperienced players, or with players who like to experiement.  As with all co-operative games, it's better to play with people who know all the rules, rather than playing with one person guiding everyone's actions.  Knowing the rules makes for informed participation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
While trying to put into words why this game didn't work especially well for me, I realized why I like Pandemic so much. In Pandemic, you don't know exactly what's going to happen, but the reshuffling of the used cards to the top of the piles means you can make a reasonably educated guess. Shadows just feels extremely chaotic to me. I've never played with a traitor, and I'm frankly not sure I'd want to, as I've never beaten the game just by itself. There are a lot of good things going on, but I almost feel like it would've been better off focusing on on fewer quests (maybe with fewer possible players as well) and making it more attainable. I do like the triage feel to Battlestar Galactica, so I don't know if I can quantify why this one leaves me more cold, especially as I don't think it's a bad game, just not as good as the other options I've mentioned.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like it enough to work through the various weird issues: messy communication rules, screwy incentives for the traitor, the endgame of winning by filling in black swords. In comparison to LOTR: not as complex, not nearly as deep, not as cooperative, not as thematic, not as tense, not as dramatic.  The biggest issue, though, is just how little there often is to do on your turn: there needs to be more options for participation. The expansion failed to touch this.

Despite all these things--and I hate that they're obvious--this is a good game. Everyone wonders a bit about the balance, the incentives, etc., but they've also demanded replays. Akin to Betrayal at House on the Hill, SoC is a truly great idea with some kinks in the execution. Some fan-based expansion ideas are really intriguing, and the game is malleable, which is a feature and a bug.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Beautiful game, I enjoy playing for that reason alone. However, it's a MUST to be cooperative, which makes it difficult without the right mix of players.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game can almost be treated as a party game since it plays so many and is so quick and easy to teach.  I think it's great, but all of the game's critics are right: The decision density is very low.  Over the course of the game you will have many turns in which you will not have to think very much at all.  The game is still very fun despite this thanks to the traitor mechanic, which adds a significant amount to the meta-game.

One other mechanic that I like is that, unlike many other co-op games, you get to choose your "evil action" each round (from three possibilities).  This adds some much needed decisions and gives the players more control, which is also very good.

Overall, the biggest problem to me is that the game is just too easy.  I read many reports by groups that have never won and it boggles my mind.  The traitor has won exactly once in about ten games for us, and games without a traitor are a breeze.  Are our traitors simply ineffective or does everyone else just waste too many actions?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The Knights of the Round Table theme is very strong on this game.  It is a cooperative, and there is so much going on it feels like an action movie.  I really enjoyed it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
I really do dislike this game.  It gives the illusion of activity, but your actions are pre-ordained for many turns when you show up at a quest.  Very few decisions, and what decisions you do have are dictated by the poker suits you have in your hand.  Yes, poker suits.  Did I mention the theme is non-existent?  Traitor aspect is the most interesting part of the game, and that doesn't salvage it.  The first time I played it, I was amazed that you actually would try to lose quests to end the game... This is a significant problem with the theme.  Communication rules are a serious mess also, people can't show each other their cards but they can talk in "code."  

Played 4 times. Bleh.

RATING: 7
Very pretty game - Days of Wonder production quality is as usual thumbs up.  The beginning always feels fine,  buthen things start heating up.  Endgame is tight,  and I'm the traitor aspect makes things nerve-wracking.  The actual quests are just "play the poker hand",  the only die rolling is fighting siege engines in Camelot.  The table talk is always hilarious though,  especially when people get vocal about there accusations.  People's actions can get railroaded by too much "That's what the traitor would do" advice though.

Depth-wise,  the game is carried more as a group puzzle - individual actions are pretty small.  The die rolling is just a bit of extra annoying random factor.  The traitor hunting game is what carries it mostly - don't expect fancy strategic choices to carry the day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In bag

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Outside of Hanabi, this is probably one of my top co-op games.  There is an optional traitor element, which is always fun.  And the game is tough as nails.  I have heard great things about the Merlin expansion, but have yet to try it.  Word of advice… go ahead and just house rule in that you can say what cards you have.  The game is co-op, let it be full co-op.  That way you won't have to make up a code to communicate your hand.  

I have recently downgraded this game from an 8 to a 7.  I still enjoy the game, but there is just something about the poker hands in this game that just takes me out of it a little bit.  Still good, still recommended, but I may be moving on.

RATING: N/A
A cooperative game where you and your fellow players, as Knights of the Round Table, will collaborate to jointly defeat the game.

Alas your quest is further complicated by the ever-present possibility of a Traitor in your midst, biding his time, waiting to strike at the worst possible moment...

Awards
2006 Spiel des Jahres Special Award for "Fantasy Game"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.195
Arthurian Co-op game.  Travel to different parts of the map and face various challenges using cards from your hand.  Attempt to cooperate with other players without being allowed to refer to your cards.  You lose if you fail a majority of your missions, if too many catapults gather outside Camelot or if everyone dies.  The game is set up to allow people to drop out or be dealt in at a moment's notice, which is quite nice. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What sets this game apart is the traitor aspect (which has been used in many games since). There's plenty of options to sabotage, without it being too overly obvious.
I like that it takes a lot of people and just scales with it, and even allows people to just drop into the game after it's already started.

RATING: 8
The first time I played this it was because two wonderful people we know brought this over for game night. Few of the newer co-ops can really compare. This is a beautiful game, with components I would be happy to just sit and look at.
As for the game, it is a co-op and one that holds its 'Arthurian' theme well. The prospect of a 'traitor' gives the game a new kick, but without it, the game still would hold a top spot on my best games list, if I had one, which I don't.
I would recommend Shadows over Camelot to anyone who looking to play a co-op game with a small or large group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
When initially unveiled, Shadows over Camelot was rightfully recognized as an impressive package that significantly broadened the cooperative genre.  Though largely a numbers game, SoC made tremendous thematic headway with its high-quality production, special powers, heroic actions, quest variety, tense discussion, and a traitor who can't wait to celebrate your death and failure.

As the traitor, though, I do wonder whether there's much to do besides dispensing bad advice in a convincing tone.  But hey, ask my wife: Questionable advice comes easy for me.

Finally, be sure to mind your manners and take the "keep it to yourself" rule seriously.  The games definitely loses its charm and respectability if players are permitted to hint at the contents of their hands.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Beautiful game. The traitor makes the game playable for me. I want to love it but it just misses. The cooperative nature is good and it does fit that requirement.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like the theme a lot in this game and the idea that you are playing against the game itself.  Also, works well for larger groups and is easy enough for newer gamers to learn.  The downside is the group think.  You will likely have one or two players trying to tell the other players what to do because some strategies work a lot better than others.  Even if the more experienced gamers are not vocal, they will be frustrated by the actions of new players.  Often I don't know who is the traitor because many of the loyal players are playing (unintentionally) badly enough that they might as well be the traitor.

If you play with all experienced gamers, than it is too easy to win, without adding a lot of handicaps in which it becomes more a game of luck with the draw pile.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Lo' the great Sir Gawain arose to repel the dragon with his might and cunning. "What dost thou require," spoketh his knave, "thy sword and thy shield?" Sir Gawain replied, "Nay, good sir, nay ... a full house."

RATING: 8
Game does a lot of things right, but ultimately falls into the "good" not "great" game category in my opinion.  I love the co-op & traitor element; however, it feels you are far more prone to the luck of the draw then you are an effective strategy.  Battlestar delegates this portion of this type of game better.

That said, it has great theme, components, good replayability and is generally a fun game.  Just not something I would tell someone it is a "must get" game.  You are not going to have a lot of reminiscing with a game like this as you would with Battlestar.

RATING: 7
A solid co-op game. You honestly don't even need/want the traitor in there unless you have 6-7 players (I guess 5 is acceptable). It is difficult enough. DOW, as always, knocks the production quality out of the park. So much theme, when you ARE the traitor, the slow build of revealing yourself is very nice. I will always be down for a game of Shadows Over Camelot.

Artwork- 8/10
Mechanics- 7.5/10
Theme- 8/10
Fun- 7.5/10

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Shadows over Camelot is, along with The Resistance and One Night Werewolf, by far the biggest hit with my friends. Co-op, not too hard of a game, stunning components and look, and (best of all) the potential of a traitor. There's a lot of talking, consulting, accusing and overal nonsense, and that makes it fun! Being able to play with 8 players is a good sign, as well as the possibility of people dropping out or coming in mid-game. Most of the time, people are constantly involved and turns often take just a few seconds. This is a great design. Too bad about the mediocre and disappointing expansion. I wish there would be another one, but that's probably never gonna happen. I'm actually messing around with some variants on my own, because I notice the game is getting rather simple for us, even with 2 traitors.
