RATING: 5
This is what the LOTR cooperative game should've been.  Even without a possible traitor, this game is a blast to play and feels like there is an actual game with decisions going on, rather than people flipping over cards and watching something unfold as in LOTR.  The traitor is an awesome mechanic and was a lot of fun playing the one time I drew the card.  Top notch box, components, etc. too.  The only problem with the game is the difficulty, which is high by default and is raised to impossible if there is a traitor.  Once revealed, the traitor should also be much less powerful.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Difficult one to put my finger on.  At times it's a ton of fun, other times its more like an argument session, as everyone tries to make one another play the way they think the game will be best played - being a cooperative game and all.

The first two tries at this one resulted in frustration for the players. Unless the players understand how to make wise decisions and budget thier actions appropriately, things go down in flames quickly.

The game is at it's best with 5 or more people. The more the better, with 7 it's a great game for non-gamers, almost a party game.  Non gamers like the traitor dynamic and understand the poker-hand similarities in the combat quests.

With every play our group likes it more, provided we can get at least 5 to play.

RATING: 8
I'm always going to prefer Battlestar Galactica, simply because it's more social, there's more ways to be shady beyond card-denial, and the evil players have to activily WORK to win the game whereas here it sometimes feels like the traitor wins by default. Plus, it's another one of sloppy rulebooks that I can't stand, made even worse by being triple-subdivided for no reason. Oh, and did I mention that its ruleset paints itself into some really strange corners: healing yourself by discarding identical cards that cant be verified because they have to be face down; and secrecy rules that defy all common sense.

And yet...there's no denying it's a trendsetter when it comes to Co-op with a Traitor Games, and it really looks fantastic on the table.

RATING: 6.5

Great production value, great theme integration... But definitely not for everyone. However, with a good group and the right attitude, a great experience.

RATING: 6.5

It really prolonged the game unnecessarily and resulted in a lot of down time.  I can see replayability being a problem if your sessions are too close to each other, since the variety of quests, cards and actions are limited.  I'd imagine expansions may broaden the scope of the game, but for now I'm glad to own it and would definitely want to try this with different groups and players.

RATING: 8
Upgraded to a 9 - and then downgraded to an 8 again. I really like this one, but I want to like it more than it deserves. It's an interesting mix of abstract Eurogame mechanics onto a theme-heavy cooperative game, but the immersion when you play is weak and the number of choices you have on your turns are too few - if you already are on a quest, you just play another card onto it. Still like it, though.

RATING: 8
I enjoy this game, when you first start playing it it's pretty hard, either people will solve one of the missions too fast and then too many catapults will be added, or they will ignore a mission and it will fail very quickly which has the same effect.  This game is all about finding the balance of pace along with team work.  We play where the only thing we can say about gameplay is what quest we are planning to visit, but not about what help you need or how long you will be there.  That small change stopped it from becoming too easy.  The fact that written on the card is the turn order and all the options in the order is great for helping new players, or players who are playing after a long break too.

RATING: 7
Cooperation game in which you can play as a famous knight of the round table. One of the knights can be a traitor, which adds a paranoid element to the game.  Great components and good theme. 

This is one of the best coop games for new players. 
After several plays I however see some problems the game has : 

*deterministic roles of some knights (blue is especially prone to this) 
*quest balance : whoever goes to fight the black knight is doing kind of a traitor action. 
*the game says you can't say what's in your hand, but allows to give hints, basically telling what's in your hand. I feel that the less talk there is the better the game gets.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pros:

Excellent components and artwork.

Plays up to seven players.

Well executed co-op mechanics with the chance of a traitor (which I like even better than knowing there's a traitor, like in Battlestar Galactica).

Cons:

The mechanics for much of the cardplay feel like glorified poker hands. The transparency of the combinations shows too well, is what I mean: 2 pairs, full house, straight...

The game can feel slow. When your entire turn could literally be "travelling" (i.e., pick up your figure and put it right back down again in a new spot, nothing else), it can try your patience to have to wait for everyone else to play before you can actually DO something.

RATING: 8
A light-medium alternative to Avalon, which I also own. Surprisingly easy to teach, and is a great coop game. May the traitor never come out.
